name: Zijne Majesteit Willem-Alexander koning van Nederland.
text: Mr President, Members of the European Parliament, it is a special experience for me to be in your midst during the Dutch Presidency of the Council of the European Union. You represent the citizens of the Union at European level. Their wishes and expectations, but also their worries and their fears. Their ideals and their hopes, but also their disillusionments and their anger. Everything that moves the European electorate comes together here and can be said and heard here. You have an important task, a difficult task too, especially now. There's a strong wind blowing in Europe. Much of what is dear to us Europeans is under pressure. Two months ago, this city, this district, was hit by extremist attacks that killed thirty-two people of different nationalities. We are thinking today of their families who have been scarred for life by pain and grief and those who have been injured and are working to their recovery, as best we can. Brussels, the city where Europe meets, was touched in the heart. As well as Paris, last year, and so many places in the countries around us. I mention Ankara, Aleppo, Beirut, Baghdad, Sousse, Lahore. Violence and oppression control the lives of millions of people in the regions around Europe. Entire societies have been disrupted. In the end, many feel compelled to flee. This requires many of the countries that receive the largest flows of refugees: Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey and a number of countries in Africa. The Member States of the European Union are also affected by the refugee crisis, some more than others. This puts the social strength of the Member States and solidarity within the Union to the test. People need shelter, a place where they can really feel at home. As the German philosopher Rüdiger Safranski wrote: "Wir können global kommunizieren und reisen, wir können aber nicht im Globalen wohnen. Wohnen können wir nur hier oder dort." It is important to always have this human attachment to a place in the world of its own. For many Europeans, one's own country is an important anchor point, with its history, tradition and customs experienced as its 'own'. This also applies to the seventeen million inhabitants of the European part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. The Dutch love their country and are proud of the legacy of Erasmus, Hugo de Groot, Spinoza, Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Cornelis Lely and Johan Cruyff. But in all the attachment and love for one's own country, it must never be forgotten what we owe to the wider European civilisation and to the peoples and cultures around us. And it is not about the least values. It was the Greeks who laid the seeds for the democratic state form that we cherish. The Italians gave us the Renaissance, a vibrant source of innovation in culture and science. It was the French immigrant Christophe Plantin who published the very first dictionaries of the Dutch language at the end of the sixteenth century. German and French thinkers like Leibniz and Voltaire laid the foundations under our Enlightenment. And it was our British and Polish allies who fought Dutch freedom with great sacrifice in 1944 and 1945. Achievements are rarely purely national. The deeper you dig, the stronger the root systems of our countries and cultures are intertwined and connected. You can delineate a territory, not a culture. Europe also represents a civilizational ideal of personal freedom and human dignity, equality and humanity. Twice my mother addressed your meeting, in 1984 and in 2004. It recalled the high expectations many young people had of Europe in the early 1960s. "What had begun with such prosaic concrete building blocks as coal and steel grew into a movement that would remove the dividing walls in Europe, keep the peace and give our continent new resilience and energy," she said. I was born in 1967. A defining moment for my generation was 1989, when dividing walls between Eastern and Western Europe that seemed untouchable shook and fell on their foundations. The end of the Cold War was the beginning of a new era. There was room for new connections. It became clear that European countries have a common responsibility. There was gradually another realization. The position of Europe and the world has changed within a few generations. Europe no longer automatically sets the tone in thinking. We are no longer the centre of the world, neither economically, nor geopolitically, nor culturally. The values we consider universal are not taken for granted everywhere and are under pressure in many places. Precisely because we believe in these values and in our common tradition, our cooperation is so Important. No longer the past, but the future forces it. In these times, we have to ask ourselves: what Europe do we stand for? What do we dare to be proud of? The main focus is often on the problems, the flaws and the worries. But these concerns, however large and justified, must be seen in the context of what has been achieved through European cooperation. There's nothing that gets used as quickly as peace. Since the Schuman plan, no Member State has fired a shot at another Member State. In our Union, power relations are embedded in legal relations. I am one of the first generation of Europeans in history to share this happiness. And I wish future generations the same happiness. (applause) The choice of European integration was a choice for a common anchoring of a free and open society in a common legal order. Five hundred million Europeans have found each other in a Union of shared values. The achievement and enforcement of this has been and is accompanied by a great deal of discussion and emotion. Tempers can run high, even here in your Parliament. When translating abstract values into concrete laws, rules and plans, there is a fierce debate. The differences can be big. This is sometimes seen as a proof of Europe's weakness, but it is a testament to Europe's strength. Critical reflection, freedom of expression, debate and democratic control are all part of our lives. Only in dictatorships there is no public discussion.  Why is it important that we keep moving together? We give the answer to that every day. In almost all the major challenges we face, there is a call for better cooperation. Controlling refugee flows. Combating trafficking in human beings, terrorism and crime. Improving our energy supply. Climate change control. Enabling economic growth and new jobs for the more than twenty-two million Europeans who are out of work. And also: strengthening our position as a morale beacon against the powers that threaten freedom. In all these tasks, we need each other.  As Erasmus wrote 500 years ago, "Nothing is easier than overcoming those who are divided." Europe is one in its diversity. Everyone's input is essential. The European bouquet is not complete without the Spanish carnation, the French fleur-de-lys, the Greek acanthus, the Danish margriet, the German cornflower, the Austrian edelweiss, the Croatian iris, the Dutch and Hungarian tulips and not without the English rose. The European Union can face the world with its head held high. But that does not absolve us of the duty to be open to criticism and also to look critically at ourselves. Often we do not address urgent common issues until the need has increased so high that there are no more alternatives. This has happened in the banking crisis and, more recently, in the humanitarian crisis caused by the flow of refugees from Syria and other conflict zones. Anticipation is not Europe's strong suit. After all, Europe cannot move faster than the Member States allow. The interaction between the Union and the Member States, and between, for example, this Parliament and national parliaments, on new challenges and problems on the horizon is therefore more important than ever. At the same time, this also places demands on the way Europe operates. This also applies to the strengthening of our economy. Our young people are our future capital. Are we doing enough to provide good future opportunities? The untapped potential of our internal market has been estimated at EUR 1 250 billion. Sixty years after the creation of the common market, that has to give an explanation. Economic and social perspective for all is essential. The work on this involves much more than just driving economic growth through the single market. After all, our common legal order is also a social legal order. It is also about equal opportunities. The right to study, work, undertake and make use of facilities in another Member State is a fantastic achievement. But we must never forget the perspective of those who stay at home. They experience not so much the extra possibilities, but extra competition. Europe now means to some: to spread your wings. And for others: arrange. Many people's concerns about this Europe are easily met with unease about the way in which the European Union is governed. Some see Brussels as a bogeyman and meddler rather than an ally. A long effort has been made to maintain a European ideal. An image of an ever-expanding expansion of European construction. But as with the construction of a stable bridge, the material laws of tension and stretch and the anchoring of the base must always be taken into account. In order to prevent a breaking point from reaching. This need to 'strengthen the support structure' is recognised within the European institutions and also within the European Parliament. The answer is: not more rules, but rules that work better. Concentration of European attention on the main issues, which really require a common approach. Decision-making as close as possible to people themselves. This not only strengthens the effectiveness of the EU, but also addresses the concern of citizens losing their grip on developments and losing their cultural identity. Citizens can only become European citizens if they continue to feel at home in their own country, city and village. Europe starts at the kitchen table. A proud European is - and should be - a proud Finn, Frenchman, Pole, Portuguese, Brit, Bulgarian, Greek, German or Dutchman.  No political order can do without a close relationship with the public. The European Union must not be an elite project; all citizens of the Member States must be able to feel at home in the Union. After all, the European Union is ours. From the professor, the truck driver, the small business owner, the job seeker, the retired factory worker, the refugee with a residence permit, the school leaver. Every year, one in three Europeans visits another European country. So two-thirds do not. For all these citizens, the European Union must have sufficient powers of say. Our Union is there for the travelling and for the fasts. As a directly elected institution of the European Union, you have a special responsibility. Compared to your electorate, but also to the many who make their voices heard in Europe only through national elections. The results of elections and referendums - including in my country - can complicate developments in the European context. But the European story can only be written together. It can only be further advanced if voters and elected voters want to listen to each other, in Europe and at home. For 60 years, European cooperation has been a bridge that we are building into the future. Initially, the bridge was narrow, but over the years the base became broader, the requirements were larger and the ambitions extended further. Whether the construction can carry us is up to us. Everything depends on the extent to which we manage to keep the connections strong and the structure stable. You, as representatives of the citizens of Europe, are essential in all their diversity. But no matter how great the diversity is and how much we differ from each other, there is more, much more that unites us. I wish you all the best of luck in your important work. (The meeting stands up and applauds for the speaker)

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, today the Commission made a major advance towards creating a true Digital Single Market for Europe, with two new packages of initiatives. The first will boost cross-border online trading across Europe: removing barriers, raising consumer confidence and ending discrimination. The second responds to new digital realities, with a modern policy approach to online platforms and broadcasting rules. Both packages reflect commitments that the Commission made in its Digital Single Market strategy that I presented to this House in Strasbourg one year ago. Both are vital for a properly functioning Digital Single Market across all countries of the European Union. Let me begin with the e-commerce package. We want to open up the e-commerce market so that it becomes truly pan-European, with fair conditions for consumers and business across the EU’s internal borders. While more and more goods and services are traded over the internet, cross-border online sales within the EU are only growing slowly. This should change. Consumers as well as businesses deserve better. They should not be limited to their domestic markets. They should be able to make the best of the opportunities offered by Europe’s single market in the digital age. Our package addresses three main areas. First, it will prevent unjustified discrimination, online as well as offline. In a true single market, you should not be discriminated against based on your nationality, residence or place of establishment. However, that does not mean making companies sell or deliver goods in every EU market. But if a consumer comes to their online store, they should be treated as if they were locals – not treated differently. But this would not include the obligation to deliver: traders would not be required to deliver cross-border but sell to them as to customers from their own country. Second, it will increase transparency of parcel delivery prices, encourage competition, and make regulatory oversight of cross-border parcel delivery services more effective. This will help consumers get a better and affordable deal, also a wider choice. It will help small e-retailers to reach new customers. It will create more business for delivery providers. And to be clear: there is no intention of imposing a single price across Europe. Third, our package will raise consumer and SME trust in e-commerce by clarifying the nature of unfair commercial practices and strengthening the enforcement of consumer rights across borders. It will also strengthen cooperation between national consumer protection authorities. Together, these measures aim to remove the main barriers to e-commerce. Online platforms are a new reality to which Europe should respond and should embrace. In a short time, they have transformed our daily lives: how we sell, shop and travel; how we learn, create and are entertained. They bring many benefits to consumers, to wider society, to industry, business and SMEs. The guiding principle and objective is to create the right conditions for platforms to innovate, scale up and grow in the Digital Single Market. But they should do so in a fair and open atmosphere. That means equal conditions for fair and open competition. Everyone involved in the market – traditional and online service providers – should play by the same rules, with no discrimination. Our assessment has shown that platforms are innovative, have a positive impact on our economy, and increase competitiveness. It shows that the EU is quite good in areas such as the app economy, health, finance and the collaborative economy. In order to thrive, all platforms – including European ones – need a legal environment that gives them certainty. This is why we are very clear in our communication: there will be no horizontal new regulation or regulator for platforms. We will not change the current e-commerce framework and its liability provisions. Of course, platforms – as well as all internet providers and online intermediaries – have to respect EU law and fundamental rights. They also have to act responsibly regarding content, and keep their activities transparent. These are important principles. This is why we are taking a problem-driven approach. It means that if we see an issue with platforms in relation to copyright, we solve it in our copyright rules. If there is an issue related to telecoms, we solve it in our telecom package. The first steps in this have already been taken today, with our proposal on the Audio-visual Media Services directive, where online platforms are a part of this instrument’s new scope. The principles that I mentioned also apply to broadcasting, where the significant presence of online platforms and video-on-demand providers has transformed viewing habits and behaviour. Today’s rules need to change to reflect this new reality, and make sure that everyone follows the same rules. Since it has worked well, there is no need to change the ‘country of origin’ principle. Media service providers will continue to be subject to the rules of the country where they are based. Our proposal will also bring more flexibility to advertising rules, and bolster our efforts to promote European creative work by raising its prominence. It will strengthen protection of minors who go online to view content. It will strengthen the role played by national media regulators. I look forward to working closely with the European Parliament, so that together we can turn these two important packages of proposals into a reality. They are essential for building the Digital Single Market that Europe needs: one where all Europeans will gain.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which First of all, Vice-President Ansip, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, congratulations on this package. We believe that the European Commission – at least from the point of view of the European People's Party – has taken the very right steps that need to be taken now, while at the same time taking caution in the areas where we need to get a little more exploration from the markets to be sure that we are taking the right steps. The important big point you are making is the proposal on geo-blocking, the last area in which businesses have re-established themselves in the European internal market in recent years, where consumers end up being left behind. The example of Disneyland in Paris has been the most prominent, there are many others. Here, I believe, you have set the right priorities in the right interfaces, where uniformity is really needed in the European internal market. Of course, we will have to deal with this critically in the course of the consultation at one point or another. Some say that more is possible in certain areas, but we want to do so to the extent that all Europeans ultimately benefit from this package. Commissioner, you have also said that you want to reject the platforms of horizontal regulation. This is probably the right step on the basis of the findings of the sector inquiry, but in our view this does not mean that there is nothing to be done about it. In the area of network and information security, we have already taken the first steps in platform legislation. You yourself have announced that, where necessary, you want to take further steps in a sectoral way. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats are very keen to follow this path, because we believe that fair competition between online platforms in Europe across the EU, but also with those who work here from outside Europe, is necessary to ensure that the European internal market with 500 million consumers benefits in the end. This requires further steps, which we are now happy to discuss in the parliamentary procedure.

text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Ansip, I would like to thank mr Ansip for his Thank you for presenting to us this package of measures that the European Commission is planning. It has taken a long time, but it is finally here, and I can only congratulate you on that. Our Parliament has been working since 2011 to finally get this package off the way. I think in the analogue world it would be completely unthinkable for a buyer to be turned away in a shop simply because he lives in another state. This is exactly what is currently happening on the Internet. That is one of the things that we must definitely prevent in geo-blocking, because it is simply discrimination against people depending on the country they are from or whether they have a credit card that has been issued in the right country. This is unacceptable in an internal market in which we want to put people at the centre of our concern. You have also said that you do not want a horizontal approach to the platforms. I congratulate you on that. As we in our report in January, we in Parliament said that this would be the wrong way to go, because the platforms are so different that we cannot find a solution for everyone, but that we must address the specific problems in these areas, if they have to be, also in a sectoral way. I think that's the right approach, so we can move forward. What also needs to be addressed, and I hope that this package will also be very strong for consumers, is that we also have more transparency when shopping on the Internet, so that citizens are not over-privileged by the fact that there is non-transparent information or hidden fees or that the company says only at the end of an order process. : Sorry, we can't ship to your country because, for example, the package costs are too high. This is the next issue, which is also very strong and very important, namely to organise parcel delivery throughout Europe in such a way that the online market is truly European.

text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! I have spent my whole life in this industry, and I have noticed time and again that Europe is unfortunately falling behind in this sector too. Do you remember the European computer manufacturer? Germany once had Nixdorf and Siemens, France had Bull, Italy Olivetti, the English ICL. In the meantime, the music is playing in America and more recently also in Asia. One reason for this is that we still do not have a Digital Single Market – certainly one of the most important projects of this Commission. Although our group always believes that we are suffering too much from Europe in many respects, I have to tell you that more Europe is appropriate here, and that is why we support the work of you and your colleague Mr Oettinger.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, I should like to thank the Commission Vice-President for coming to this House, but above all for proposing these new legislative proposals and communications. Mr Vice-President, I have to say you are doing well: keep it up, and please keep pushing all the institutions, including the Council, to deliver on the digital single market.  The adoption of several proposals this week is a good sign that the Commission is serious in its efforts to make Europe a leading part of the digital revolution. But, Mr Vice-President, I have to say that not all proposals have been winners with everyone – most, but not all. While my Group fully supports the digital contracts proposals, I encourage you to complete the Refit exercise as soon as possible so we can unblock both of these files.  On portability, a wonderful and straightforward proposal, we are seeing attempts to introduce extreme verification systems that would track users in order just to give them the right to watch a movie. The ALDE Group will fight for a balanced text but we will need your support. As to your proposals today, we welcome the proposal on unjustified geo-blocking and fully endorse to fight against discrimination between different EU citizens. When combined with greater transparency in parcel deliveries, we get closer to a single market that is built on trust and respect between consumers and businesses, and this is vital for e-commerce. But, Mr Vice-President, we will need more convincing on the communication on platforms and any further actions arising from it. The definition of platform is so wide that almost the whole internet fits inside it. This is a recipe for over-regulation and this must be prevented.

name: Dennis de Jong
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the Commission wants to harmonise all the rules on internet purchases and make it a single market. This is not illogical, but it is very much at the same time, and that also means that the concrete problems for SMEs and also for consumers are sometimes not solved. I would like to give you two examples, there are many. The Commission recognises that it is often difficult for SMEs to be clearly visible in the results of search engines, such as Google, or on price comparison sites. Large companies have more money to prioritise on platforms like this and the result is that the consumer does not get a comprehensive overview of all providers. Although this is an acute problem for SMEs, the Commission will first continue its studies for six months to see if this can be solved through self-regulation. I think that's a missed opportunity. Every day that a company is not visible on platforms costs revenue and further undermines the level playing field. I therefore call for more capacity in this area.  Another example: a practical problem that consumers face is the extortionate prices for concert tickets. In its proposals, the Commission insists that a website offering such tickets must charge the same price to all consumers in the European Union. That's nice, but a much bigger problem is the lack of transparency from the various ticket providers. For example, large batches may be sold privately and tickets on the organization's site sell out, but are offered on the internet through other merchants at extortionate prices. Is the Commission going to do something about this?

name: Julia Reda
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the long-awaited proposal for a regulation on geo-blocking could have been a really good proposal if you had been just a bit more ambitious, Commissioner. It has clear rules for banning geo-blocking, it addresses the concerns about the applicable law and the obligation to deliver it in a very clever way, but unfortunately at the same time it also misses the core of the problem. We all know that, when we ask consumers what they think about geo-blocking, the first thing they think about is ‘this video is not available in your country’. Video is, of course, completely exempt from the regulation and – apparently at the last minute – other copyrighted content has also been removed from the obligation to ban geo-blocking. Now you say that we will deal with copyright problems in copyright proposals, but the problem with this is that there is a lot of geo-blocking of copyrighted materials, particularly videos, that has nothing to do with copyright. So where will these issues be addressed? I do not see anything in the audiovisual regulation that would address the geo-blocking of videos that is not for copyright reasons. I do not think it is OK just to say that it is a copyright problem, because quite often it can simply be the seller who decides for commercial reasons that dividing the market will make him more money. So the Commission, and now Parliament, has to be extremely careful not to create any regulatory gaps, so that the end result will really be an end to geo-blocking in the whole of Europe.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Ansip, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his About a year ago, you presented us with a strategy for the Digital Single Market, which, among other things, provided for better online access for consumers and businesses as an essential point. This point included four sub-items. The first point is better rules for cross-border e-commerce. You said at the time that 11.7 billion euros could be saved for consumers every year if there were better online trade. The second point is that cheap cross-border parcel delivery is made from the knowledge that high prices and inefficient parcel delivery naturally hinder online trade. The third point is to prevent geo-blocking, and there is certainly a need to strike a balance between consumer interests and legal certainty for businesses. The final point is better access to digital content. I would say that the package presented today will certainly lead to an improvement in consumer protection. Online shopping will be easier and cheaper. Will consumers be satisfied? If they can buy online but the retailer doesn't have to deliver, it may detune some. But in general, it can certainly be said that it leads to an improvement. Confidence is also improved by removing fraudulent websites from the web and by improving identity identification. And I am sure that the national budgets will also be grateful to you by setting the 20% quota for the audiovisual content of European provenance. This is certainly a very interesting move, and the cultural budgets of the countries will be very pleased about it.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Commissioner, i would like to begin by thanking the In my childhood— I was looking around the hall —in our childhood, buying a product meant going to the store, withdrawing money, giving away money, getting the goods, going home again. That's how we all shopped in the past. Of course, since then, the world has changed a lot because of technological developments. Today very often \u2012\u2012 some of us even most often \u2012\u2012 buys a product instead of physically going to a store that is perhaps close to us, but we either sit down at the computer, take out a tablet, or even use our mobile phone and buy some goods using internet capabilities.  But the difficulty we face is that although we feel that we are here, we take and buy something, very often the place where we buy, not only is it not next to us, it is not even in our country, it is quite somewhere else in Europe. And the difficulty we know is that although technology allows us to do this process \u2012\u2012 could say \u2012\u2012 painlessly, without difficulty, there are separate laws or state regulations that actually discriminate against the buyer depending on which country he is in at the time of buying. Consequently, the same product may have different selling prices, including different shipping prices, although the distance does not justify this. This is what I very much welcome the Commission's commitment to eliminating so-called geo-blocking or discrimination, because if we want this single market, the digital market must also be single, just like going into a neighbouring shop and buying. There is no longer the weight in which country we are in and from which we buy.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today growth, unlike in the past, is based on two key elements, energy and electronic communications, if we want to aim for sustainability and the global dimension. That is why, Commissioner, we very much appreciate the digital single market, the implementing measures that are beginning to arrive and all the related measures, because they represent precisely the new architecture, the new rules, the new rights of this world that is now developing. Access free from obstacles and barriers to the single market will certainly give more opportunities, and it is a great step forward that citizens and businesses, consumers and operators can take their rights with them within the Union: digital rights, productive rights, consumer rights, rights and values; in short, they can turn without limits and obstacles. Small and medium-sized enterprises, commercial and productive enterprises, which are very afraid of these changes today, must also be helped to manage this transition, to seize opportunities and to manage risks. We in Parliament will pay close attention to regulation, as has been said in the speeches. It will be very much up to regulation to facilitate this process in a positive sense, reducing its risks: clear, flexible regulation, with a great deal of attention to all rights. I repeat, economic and productive ones, but also privacy, security in every sense and new rights, personal and collective. We talk a lot about services, but we cannot forget – I am from the Industry Committee – that digital is also investing massively throughout the productive world, and the new phenomenon is that manufacturing and services mix, mix in the ownership of companies, but also mix precisely in production processes, new business models and new industrial relations – I am thinking of the whole theme of "industry 4.0" etc. Infrastructure will be important. Without infrastructure, we will in no way be able to open up to the development of broadband, and I am thinking of the measure we are considering for the redistribution of frequencies, because privileged frequencies are precisely going to the development of services and telecommunications. But not everything is infrastructure and technology, there is also the human factor, and there is also training. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. "Dear colleague, you have spoken recently about industry, manufacturers and consumers. Don't you think that's the role of the Commission and that's what we should have seen in that proposal, namely measures envisaged by the Commission to strike a balance between consumer rights and business interests without putting any additional burden on or detrimental to one party or the other?

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I have spoken precisely about the related measures, because I think that the Commission's action converges on so many interventions. There are the acts of the digital single market, there is communication on industry 4.0, there are all the interventions on the other processes that accompany the production transformations, with the support of enabling technologies. So not everything is in these acts, but I have specifically recalled what needs to be developed in a complementary sense, because I see a market integrated into trade, industry, digital and also the use of new energies, because sustainability is a key factor in all this.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we do need to work together across Europe to make sure that the single market is fit for a digital age, but we must get the detail right, we do not want to put an unnecessary handbrake on the digital economy.  On geo-blocking: in traditional markets we do not force retailers to open their stores in all 28 markets. But now a store would have to work out whether or not they are complying with the national rules in all 28 countries, and this could be very burdensome especially for smaller companies. So instead of giving consumers more choice we just risk that smaller stores will not go online at all. On platforms, Commissioner, thank you for stepping back from the brink and not coming up with a new regulation, but please be careful. Platforms are growing because consumers like them, and I want to see more platforms, and more competition in platforms. Change in the intermediary liability could be very destabilising, especially for smaller start-ups in the shared economy and in e-commerce. And on media services, our consumers love the diversity of new media: new media services are not the same as traditional media offers and we need to make that distinction.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: –  Mr President, Thomas Edison said: ‘There is a way to do it better – find it’. I think this quote sums up very much what digital innovation is all about: doing it better and finding new ways to solve problems, from access to services and goods to environment and mobility.  The whole purpose of the Digital Single Market strategy is also about breaking down barriers, those that are often created by outdated legislation or practices. Modernisation of the relevant legislation will be key for Europe to be an innovative force behind the next wave of innovation which is data-driven.  On geo-blocking, two points. I believe that we need to be ambitious in addressing the reasons why companies geo-block, from parcel delivery to contract and consumer law and VAT and copyright as well. As long as the reasons to geo-block exist the companies will continue with these practices. The purpose of all this is to get more companies to sell online, not to scare them off. So there is still a lot to be done here.  The other point is about transport-related services. I do not really buy the argument that they should be exempt from this proposal. Those websites are very often used by older Europeans and they are very often geo-blocked or they discriminate among consumers based on their IP address.  So there is a lot to be done here, and the single market strategy is about breaking down barriers, so we will continue with this work.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I remind the Commission that the vast majority of Europeans are workers without consumers, because without a living wage it cannot be consumed. And that defining the digital market as a whole, bringing together productive realities and very diverse sectors, ends up ignoring the destructive effects of digitization on employment. A clear example is parcelry. Competition in the most lucrative segments of the postal market serves to dismantle public postal companies, precarize employment and increase the cost of services. Today's regulation contains elements that deepen in this regard and are absolutely unjustified. I am also concerned about the idea of continuing to treat digital platforms as if they were offering new services, as they only provide the usual services, only in another format. A driver must have the same rights, work in a taxi or for Uber. And the same in other sectors such as telecommunication or hospitality. The solution is not to force competition between the traditional and digital models, but to operate digital services within the same regulatory framework with the same rights and obligations as the rest of the sector. This is the proposal we expect from the Commission.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I can only agree with the previous speaker: we need to look at the issue a little more broadly. It is right and proper to make a strategy for a digital single market now, but we also need one for a digital society, and I miss that a little bit in this proposal, as you bring it. I have now had journalists, journalism students with me, who have asked me about the biggest problem for working in the European Parliament. In my view, one of the biggest problems is a lack of European publicity. That is what we need for a European democracy, for a European society. If I now look at the proposal that we want to abolish geo-blocking for games, but not for videos, you can see how much this proposal is market-driven and how little socio-political, democratic. After all, from the point of view of news, of producing news itself, of starting a public European discussion, video is far more important than games. This is not just about the market, it is a socio-political project that we should understand the Internet as, and I do not see that in this Commission. Commissioner Oettinger is not only Commissioner for the Digital Economy, he is Commissioner for the Digital Economy and Society. In this sense, we should work on this package, should add more, bring more in it and should not only regard the 500 million Europeans as consumers and protect consumers, but we should look at them as citizens, as voters, as participants in European democracy and work on the package in this sense. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. –I listened with great interest and joy to the speech of the representative. You clearly set out on a value-based basis to deal with this issue and not just technically as you have done so far. I would therefore like to ask you whether you have also considered how fair competition, democracy and freedom of journalism can be promoted, for example by increasing transparency in these algorithms. Personally, I am concerned that there is no mention of this at all.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. That's hard to answer in 30 seconds, of course. But I have already tried to explain: with geoblocking, for example, the criterion must be that we allow the widest possible public and that we do not design geo-blocking in such a way that it develops maximum profit for companies and that we only evaluate the commercial basis. We have already had this in discussions on net neutrality and in others. We come to different political decisions if we want to support a maximum profitable business model or if the perspective is to allow as much communication as possible for citizens. This is not the same thrust, and we as a Parliament should always choose the possibility, I think, which allows for more communication, more free communication for our citizens.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, once again you are essentially talking about open markets, a limitless opening, which will put Europe and its states under even greater foreign domination. You do not have a sovereignty strategy, even in Europe, in the face of foreign technologies that are technologies of domination. Your single market, therefore, will deliver even more European data to GAFA (Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon) working with the U.S. secret services, for America and its companies, against our companies. Yesterday, in 1990, we had the world's largest e-technology market with Alcatel. Germany's Siemens also held in a very good place. We should have created a European monopoly, which your competition forbids. Today, Alcatel is destroyed by its alliance with the United States, Siemens is outpaced in favor of American and Chinese companies, because there was no protection of the European market, as we had protection of the domestic market before European rules. Russia and China have pursued a policy of sovereignty to meet these challenges, Europe has not. Today, you offer a European cloud. It is ok! But will this cloud be in the skies of European states, citizens who want to protect their data? Your liberal approach makes me fear the worst. You will probably give it to companies outside Europe. Your digital single market, with no real strategy, relying again on European leaders to make them world leaders, protecting them first of all, in a protected European market, as Russia and China have done to preserve their independence, is a submission to the external powers. The Commission has no ambition, because it has no borders or sovereignty. It destroys, in the name of competition and openness, the states that had such ambition. I am thinking of France and Germany. It is time to go out, to build Europe with other institutions. (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: blue-card question. –  I heard your intervention hailing Russian protectionism and the Russian economy. As we all know, the Russian economy is declining, because it lacks inspiration and competition. There is a lack of rule of law. Would you like to tell us how you look upon the development of welfare and prosperity in Russia, which I understand is a model for you? Please come up and tell us about the protectionist, lawless, rude and capitalist robber market that we see in Russia! Tell us about it and tell us about the prosperity for Russians. It has declined year after year – and that’s your model? That’s a shame.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear colleague, you are going to get the first prize in caricature of the words. What did I say? I said that, for example, a market like China has managed to protect itself from the dominance of the United States in these kinds of technologies by protecting its market. I have also said - and I do not think Russia is an example - that Russia is a sovereign country, which has a sovereignty strategy and has been keen to maintain control in this area of technology, which is fundamental to the organization of society, our industries and our sovereignty. We do not have such an ambition, and that is what I regret for Europe.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – But perhaps first a few more words to the former, who behaves as if he did not know that the monopoly undermines not only the interests of the market, but undermines the interests of the consumer. And we want a market with competition, real competition. We want a barrier-free market and we want a European market where companies can economies of scale faster and well. And that will indeed give us sovereignty, not some hopeless monopolies that actually resemble dictatorial systems.  In the document presented by the Commission, by the Commissioner, there are a lot of very good initiatives – initiatives expected by businesses and consumers on the European market – and now is the time for Parliament and the Commission to work even closer and more intensively to respond to the expectations that European citizens have for the development of our common market. This is also what the working group I chair is for, and I hope that the Commissioner will soon be able to host this working group. The big challenge for the market is the unfortunate geoblocking, which irritates consumers and blocks the growth of entrepreneurs. Here, however, we need to identify very precisely the areas where this geoblocking is unjustified. Surely one such area is the delivery of packages and any possible barriers associated with it. The fact that a package costs more simply because it crosses the border is a complete absurdity and denial of the common market. The Commission is not yet proposing price regulation, but it is very important for operators to realise that we have one market, not twenty-eight different markets. We therefore need new ideas, such as to ensure that new operators have access to postal infrastructure. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". My question goes in the direction: we have a single internal market ahead of us on roaming charges next year. Do you believe that it is possible to move away from national borders in the case of parcel services as well, and therefore only to react to distance or to individualised markets? In the case of parcel services, too, we often have ten times the price, even if it is only two kilometres across the border.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Thank you very much for this question. This is exactly one of those areas that we need to work on with the same success, as is the case with the roaming theme that has finally succeeded. This long-awaited solution for consumers is on the table, it is starting to function, it will be fully operational next year. We need innovative solutions, not thinking only within one country and in the traditional delivery of parcels in one country, and to add completely unnecessary prices for those packages that cross borders. More collaboration and new ideas.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: –  Madam President, today is a black day for the ICT and hardware sector in Europe, as Microsoft announced in Finland that it will cut 1 350 jobs. These are the jobs of ICT-skilled people, mostly in research and development and manufacturing. I hope the EU will help with the Globalisation Fund.  But this is also a question of European industries getting along with globalisation, and this is a part of the Digital Strategy we have to bear in mind. We want Europeans to have jobs in Europe. I say no to a future in which all the manufacturing and all the hardware is produced in Asia and all the applications and all the content are provided by the USA. We need those in Europe too – so I believe, and I work for the Digital Single Market – as we see that the single market has also been a source for economic growth in Europe.  It is said that the Digital Single Market could add EUR 415 billion to the European Union economy, and it is said that the Digital Single Market will bring hundreds of thousands of jobs. I encourage the Commission to look at every step it takes in the Digital Single Market, so that it will also create growth and jobs for Europeans. So that is why I do not always like the Digital Single Market being the only keyword here, but it is the digital society that creates well-being and jobs for Europeans as well.  We still eagerly wait for the skills strategy as well as the telecom rules, and the infrastructure to go and make Europe deliver. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF)
text: Question "blue card." "Dear colleague, I share everything you have said. I just want to know: are you in for protection of the European market?

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I do not believe that protection is the right way to deliver. I strongly want to see the Digital Single Market, and these 28 rules are not providing the best we can deliver from the European economy. I do not think that France is better and stronger alone. I do not think that Finland is stronger alone because, although Finland was the frontrunner in mobile telecoms manufacturing, we did not sell them only to 5.5 million Finnish people. We sold them globally. So now we need to take the next steps and then we need to do it together for 500 million consumers.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I am concerned that these proposals misunderstand the digital world and the fact that it is consumer-driven. The geo-blocking proposal is ill-conceived and will drive small businesses off the internet. But I am very concerned about the proposals to make on-demand platforms meet a 20% European quota. This shows a lack of confidence in the European industry, which is booming, especially as Netflix and Amazon already meet the 20% quota. The proposal does not understand the nature of on-demand services: people watch what they want, when they want, and if the content is not good, they will not watch it. Now there will be a push to produce low-quality European content just to meet the quota, and this will undermine the industry and consumers.  There is also a question about what is European content in a globalised world? Game of Thrones is filmed mostly in Europe. Is it European? A UFC fight in Las Vegas featuring Conor McGregor, for example, is that European content? What about an app like Major League Baseball? Are Europeans who want to watch the New York Yankees going to have to be forced to watch the Essex Arrows instead? What about Crunchyroll, that specialises in Japanese anime? Or Core TV, streaming South Korean content? Are they all expected to have European content?

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the proposals are going in the right direction for a digital single market. It is important that we move on, but we are afraid that these proposals are half-hearted, that it is not principle-based, for example in the area of geo-blocking, to allow all of us to benefit from the variety of proposals and offers on the European market without being constrained by a fragmentation of 28 different legal systems in this area, and these proposals do not overcome that. They still carve out main areas from the benefits which consumers and also competitors on the European market may have. And it is the same for those areas where we still expect the Commission to act – for example on the platform regulation question, especially when it comes to big app stores for those mobile devices which we all use. The rules are rather discriminatory today, and there should be European standards across all 28 Member States that clearly say which information we should get and what duty we have to a non-discriminatory approach.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I today express some reservations about the Digital Single Market. The reason is that the European institutions are embarking on large-scale projects, without learning from previous failures in other market segments. We are talking about an open single market, but in the service area, the offer coming from the eastern states, including Romania, is constantly denigrated and abused. The cause is the competitive advantage given by the lower prices. So if this price decrease in services is not beneficial, why would we think that in the digital market it would be? Why does the Commission not address this issue, tacitly allowing the restriction of cheaper services from Eastern Europe? Similarities also exist with regard to the Labour market in the Union. If this liberalisation of the labour market was so welcome, then why are Eastern workers denied social security benefits? Moreover, time and again the authorities refuse to respond to a simple complaint made by them! If a digital market is to be, indeed free, competitive advantage and human resources must be protected from the outset.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner! My question is, by when will the technical framework for 5G technology be negotiated at the ITU? Are there any conversations with America here? I was in Washington last week to propose common standards. By when will there be a proposal for frequency harmonisation and uniform auctioning in all 28 Member States? Do you think that the Connecting Europe facility could help us to strengthen fibre links across borders and, above all, to implement the radio masts that we then need for 5G roll-out accordingly? Will 2018 be the time when Europe can introduce this new technology like other countries? My second question is this: in the area of unfair commercial practices, which this proposal also includes, I have now received a proposal less time ago to re-enact my Apple software, and I have read the terms and conditions; There are 600 lines to accept here. Is there any consideration from the Commission, the general terms and conditions that must be accepted when buying a device, updating software, updating an app, and also creating a legal framework for companies to rely on?

name: Petra Kammerevert (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Ansip, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The proposal on the AVMSD directive published today is, unfortunately, only a re-enactment after initial review and, in my view, should have been much bolder. Although video offerings on multimedia platforms are now included in regulation, the distinction between linear and non-linear remains, despite the fact that Parliament has now called three times for this outdated demarcation to be abandoned. Television and the Internet have grown increasingly together, and the audience has become completely uninterested in this separation. We must finally set a European framework that guarantees the availability of audiovisual media services in accordance with uniform rules, regardless of time and location. Your proposals on the direct participation of video platforms in national film funding funds and on making advertising times more flexible are to be welcomed in principle. In terms of content, this should be allowed to be advertised, which is also legal to buy. If we are too restrictive here – I believe that this is the case in some places – and global Internet advertising will, above all, threaten the advertising revenues of private television providers, and they urgently need it in order to be able to present us with a good programme. I will work to ensure that clearer rules on the discoverability of journalistic content are enshrined in the directive. The Member States must explicitly be allowed more room for manoeuvre in this area. I also believe that it should be made clear that videos and radio signals cannot simply be altered by third parties, for example by means of over-fades-in simming of signals that are not authorised. It must not be permissible, for example, for a news broadcast with third-party advertising to simply be blended over. We need clear rules here. All in all, it is a first step, and I am quite optimistic that we here in Parliament will actually be able to make a leap into the future of television.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: Madam President, I think everyone agrees that e-commerce contributes to the creation of growth and jobs. Two and a half million jobs in 2014, that goes without saying. But in a European digital single market, it is not acceptable for traders to refuse access to their website, goods or services on the basis of a person's nationality or place of residence. However, a trader must have the right to sell under different conditions in different Member States. After all, companies enjoy an economic and contractual freedom to undertake and adapt to local market conditions. Respect for basic market forces, but not discrimination against consumers. With regard to audiovisual services, the Commission wants 20% of the supply of on-demand services to be made up of European productions. I say no to digital protectionism. We must cherish our European content, but give private digital companies the freedom of enterprise. The imposition of European quotas hinders this and does not guarantee quality production.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE).
text: – Madam President, today’s proposals go in the direction needed and are a positive next step towards the completion of the Europe-wide Digital Single Market. The Commission’s initiatives show that it is working to ensure that consumers must benefit from opening up national markets. The expectations of citizens and businesses are very clear: break down those barriers in the online world.  I am a believer in doing things to the maximum, and I would have liked to see the proposal on geo-blocking being more inclusive. Copyright-protected online services, such as e-books and music, but also TV programmes, videos and movies, should not have been left out of the proposed ban on geo-blocking.  Every day on which the digital single market is not fulfilling its whole potential, European businesses and citizens are losing the opportunity to grow and have more choice. At the same time we as legislators, and European institutions as a whole, are losing credibility. To this end, we have to ensure future—proof legislation which we adopt swiftly. This is why I am certain that the Commission will come up with a proposal for a full ban on geo-blocking sooner rather than later. On platforms, they are so diverse and different, as you said, and I am glad the Commission has not decided to legislate on something that enriches our lives, that fosters innovation and, most importantly, can be regulated when and if necessary, as we have seen in the past through enforcing existing anti-trust rules.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, let me express my deep appreciation for the work of the Commission, which is slowly realometing the ambitious objectives of the Digital Single Market Strategy. Now, however, Mr Vice-President, we must try to turn good principles and good intentions into concrete opportunities, and that responsibility also lies with us in Parliament. The measures presented so far and the many that are coming up can offer new opportunities for citizens and consumers. Ambitious e-government plans will be able to develop a more effective and efficient, cheaper public administration and provide citizens with higher quality services. European consumers will benefit from clearer and more homogeneous contractual rules, the full development of e-commerce, the portability of online content, the removal of geoblocks and other barriers that are currently anachronistic. Finally, the business system can only remain a leading player in global competition by making full use of new digital technologies. Without fear of emphasising, I would like to say that at a time when the European Union is facing its greatest point of crisis, at a time when citizens have the perception of institutions far removed from their concrete needs, digital technology can be a key element on which to rebuild a new sense of belonging and with which to project our continent into the future.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the Commission on today's digital package. It is now taking the right steps to create a European internal market for digital services as well. We know that it is still a big problem in Europe, that at the same time as people, goods and capital are moving across borders, digital services often continue to stop at borders. It was downright astonishing to read that Commission report, which had examined 10 000 e-commerce, and more than 60% of these online shops were covered by country restrictions and, in fact, only one third of online shops allowed purchases between the countries of the European Union. So it is very important now that the Commission today has put forward a proposal to lift these unjustified land restrictions. It will hopefully boost e-commerce in Europe and increase competition. Of course, the challenge in legislation all the time is that technology develops much faster than legislation and, on the other hand, consumer habits and expectations change very quickly. In other things, it is important that the legislative framework is also flexible enough in that it encourages new innovation in Europe, because we know that one of the biggest challenges facing Europe is precisely how we are coping with competition in the digital economy, for example, compared to the USA or Asia. In that sense, the proposals made today by the Commission are quite justified and good, they are moving us in the right direction. (The speaker promised to answer the blue card question under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear Colleague, and I agree that the Digital Single Market package is very important, but do not you think that we now have a behind-the-top areas in Europe that, in fact, do not have access to, and by doing so we are in fact discriminating against a lot of people, a lot of citizens, and that the Commission should also prepare a support package for poor areas. , be able to access the Digital Single Market?

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: answer to the blue card question. – As I am sure my colleague is well aware, there are a number of different initiatives under way in Europe, which is precisely aimed at speeding up the construction of high-speed network connections throughout Europe. It is important that we have the existing infrastructure available, but of course people's digital skills are also what needs to be encouraged and, above all, those who have not had the opportunity to learn these skills must have access to help and support, because today digital skills are part of civic skills and it is important to become part of society as well.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – I am absolutely convinced that we are talking today on one of the most important, fundamental topics. For we live in the 21st century, in a modern society that is very mobile: where we are born, where else we are educated, where else we work, where else we live. This real world creates many barriers for this kind of society. We have failed, we have not succeeded in removing them in the common market. We cannot make this mistake by creating a common digital market, for two reasons: it is not only about the interests of entrepreneurs on the one hand and European consumers on the other – of course this is very important – but it is also the interest of the whole of Europe, of the Community as a whole, because we are, after all, operating in a global market. If we cannot cope with the removal of barriers, with increased freedom of establishment, but also of free consumer choice in this market – even though it is large – then of course we will lose competition in this global global market. That is why I welcome the Commission's proposal, but I also warn against the temptation – perhaps not even today, but in the future – to overregulate this market. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you Mr Szejnfeld for your contribution there. I agree with a lot of what you have said, but further to what my colleague Maria Grapini and others said, the skills agenda is also important when we are dealing with the digital single market and e-skills. I was wondering if you could maybe make a comment on the importance of e-skills in this debate, too.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "I absolutely agree. I will not argue with this attitude and with this position. Contrary. If we want to develop a common digital market, we must also support all those actors who will serve the development of this common market. Of course, these societies, or even local communities, have difficult access to the common market for some reason – probably also historically, also economicly. But I want to say, these are two different things. We should be very active and effective on one plane and on the other plane.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, we all know that digital transformation affects all sectors of industry, services and society. This false dichotomy between society and economics sometimes leads to some confusion. It is a whole: it is the economy, it is society; it's society and it's the economy. And so that Europe does not miss the opportunity to be at the forefront of this transformation, the digital single market is essential. And it is because it is the big accelerator that allows the economies of scale that are needed to make the European economy – that digital economy being developed – globally competitive. Today, another step has been taken to ensure that this 'flagship', which the Commission rightly defined at the beginning of the legislature, will come to port when this term ends. We will discuss whether some aspects can be improved, but congratulations because today we have taken it a step further. I would like to stress, because I find it interesting, a kind of spur left by the Commission on the issue that similar digital services have to have similar regulation and that this will have its consequences and its treatment in future legislative proposals, such as that affecting electronic communications or privacy, e-privacy. Congratulations on this. The pace, Mr Vice-President, must be constant and agile. We've got to keep going.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, regarding geo-blocking it is important to get rid of unjustified geo-blocking, but it is just as important to get rid of the reasons for justified geo-blocking. Different sales law, different VAT regimes, different consumer legislation, different copyright legislation: here is the big challenge. And that leads me to the second point: I do not believe in quotas restricting the supply of different sorts of entertainment in the global era. I do not think European culture and entertainment will develop because of quotas. It is much better to open up the opportunities for global champions emerging in Europe than to worry about global champions coming from other parts and competing here. Third, the new legislation we need is not to regulate the past or to freeze the present, it is to open up for the future and all its opportunities. Platforms are a phenomenon that will change all the time. They need to adapt to the rules of the legislation we have, but do not try to legislate them in a way that hinders innovation. We will see new platforms coming every year, every decade and we need to secure that we can be in the lead.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam President, an important part of the benefits of the Single Market of the European Union and the new time in which we live is e-commerce. I support the new rules presented by Vice-President Ansip, which will enable both consumers and businesses to take better advantage of the Single Market. Online shopping should be easy and secure, and due to numerous barriers and limitations, consumers often give up this way of shopping.  First you need to enter a number of personal information when buying, after that often the card they have does not correspond to the terms of purchase, and if they still manage to make a purchase, they are surprised by the shipping costs, the length of the customs clearance procedure in case of purchase outside the EU and the like. In the world of computers and business internetisation, it is safer and easier for EU citizens to travel to sellers. With this package of new rules we are making positive changes and I am looking forward to a future easier and safer internet business.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, a year ago the Commission presented its strategy so that Europe, its citizens and its businesses can harness the full potential of digital society. A year later the strategy needs to regain verve, regain ambition. A connected Europe requires portability of services and content, eliminating unjustified geoblocking, more spectrum coordination. A vigorous industrial Europe calls for an ambitious strategy beyond the investments already envisaged. A creative Europe demands fair protection and remuneration for creators. I encourage the Commission to comply with the compromised timetable and encourage it to be ambitious so that Europe does not lag behind and can harness the full potential of digital society, in accordance with fair, equal and balanced rules.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the digital single market could indeed help to stimulate the European economy, to the decisive growth of the Union's GDP and to the creation of thousands of new jobs.  However, this consolidation should be accompanied by significant investment in research and development of information and communication technologies, in which the European Union lags dramatically behind the United States and Japan. This is because the Union's economic model is based on the Euro Pact, that is to say, it supports the competitiveness of the Old Continent in the Chineseisation of wages.  In Greece, the Third Memorandum adds new obstacles to efforts to develop the digital economy. New obstacles to one of the few sectors that have experienced some signs of life in recent years, thanks to the potential of our country's young scientists in the field of information technology. Thus, in order to facilitate the repayment of the alleged debt, a new 5% fee was added to fixed telephony and internet services and even earlier than the timetable. This mockery must finally come to an end.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, The Single European Market, the digital market is to become europe's fifth freedom. I have already talked about this in this Parliament, but I am convinced that without it we have a truly complete fifth European freedom as a digital single market, there will be no competitiveness of ours against the United States, compared to China and other major markets.  It's the only path we have to follow, and all we see here today is great, is good, but I think we need to be even more ambitious, because if we're not more ambitious we won't be competitive. What I want to single out from the three points you've been talking about is the issue of purchase security in e-marketplace and e-commerce. I think that trust that is objectively falling more than growing today, on the e-commerce system we have to do everything to boost that trust, because otherwise we will lose out on competitiveness.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – I welcome and support the Commission's initiative on the Digital Single Market. In the 21st century, it goes without saying that the countries of the European Union must be a single digital market. The younger generation does not even understand how to talk about a common market without it. In particular, I would like to draw attention to the abolition of geo-blocking in one of the Commission's 16 measures and the need for further measures to make broadcasting available independently of national borders. I am convinced that, despite the business arguments, it is completely outdated to limit broadcasting to national borders, especially in view of sporting events that have become of great interest. At today's level of technical possibilities, it is unacceptable that it is impossible for citizens to watch certain sporting events in the language in which they wish – even if they have a subscription to the programme of that service provider.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, developing the digital single market and boosting the Digital Agenda in trade agreements and the World Trade Organization will pose enormous potential but also enormous challenges. If the European Union wants to maintain and improve its competitiveness, it will have to implement the necessary policies to digitise all sectors and to create and develop a genuine digital single market. The European digital strategy must reconcile innovation with security, with the protection of personal data and with the guarantee of the privacy of citizens. It is necessary to provide adequate digital skills to SMEs, workers and users, to ensure legal certainty of net neutrality and to find balanced solutions that guarantee the rights of creators, fair remuneration and user access. And, of course, it is essential that digitisation benefits workers and that the European Union leads new forms of job creation and collective bargaining. An important step has been taken today, and I encourage you not to cease your efforts to achieve a single European digital market.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, go raibh maith agat as seans a thabhairt dom labhairt ar an ábhar seo a bhfuilim ag obair air le cúpla bliain agus comhghairdeas leis an gCoimisiún as na moltaí atá curtha romhainn anseo inniu. Without a doubt the single market was probably the most important aspect in the development of prosperity in Europe. My own country probably benefited more than most. And now of course, as we move into the digital age, we must complete not just the single market, but the digital single market, and remove barriers to it. People have spoken all day about geo-blocking, which is true, but other aspects are very important, such as high-speed broadband being available consistently and reliably across Europe, especially in rural areas. VAT rules have to be looked at. Also delivery and proper postal addresses – an awful lot of goods are returned because the postal addresses are not properly described and the places cannot be found. So all these things will help us to complete the digital single market.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, effectiveness, accessibility and security are the prerequisites for the creation of digital services that are truly able to cross national borders and guarantee open services in three main areas: industry, digital innovation and the digitalisation of public services. I would like to focus first of all on the fact that the new package of measures makes it possible to raise the level of consumer protection both in the security of transactions and in the usability of the goods purchased, without geoblocks. Indeed, while it is true that the European Union is the right level for the digital age, as Commissioner Ansip said, it is also essential that this level of intervention makes it possible to unify national legislation, to tidy up what is regulated at Community level, but above all to create positive repercussions in the everyday lives of European citizens. The right balance must therefore be struck between the objective of supporting the strategy and consumer protection; in the end, a new approach to welfare and job search must be sought.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, my role is very complicated right now because I have got so many questions and I have only a couple of minutes to respond to those questions. But first, I would like to thank you for your strong support for the package we are proposing today. I am looking forward to having really fruitful cooperation with you. I am ready to come to all the parliamentary committees and all of the party groups of Parliament to discuss these issues. Regarding geo-blocking, we all know that this is a real headache for our businesses in the European Union and also for our citizens. We know those fears about mystery shopping surveys but, once again, 2% out of all the people who tried to buy goods or services from another Member State could not get access to those websites because their IP address was wrong, from the wrong country; 27% of those people who could get access could not register because once again they were from the wrong country; 32% of those people who were lucky enough to register were faced with delivery problems; and the 26% of the people who did not have any kind of delivery problems could not pay. We have the Single Euro Payments Area (SEPA) in the European Union, but 26% of people could not pay! All in all, just 36.6% out of all those people who tried to buy goods or services from another country were able to do so. This is not a single market. This is not at all the single market we have to have in the European Union. We have to fix those problems. Our proposal was to set an obligation to sell like at home, which does not mean that there will be an obligation on the deliverer. Sellers have to treat those buyers coming online from other countries differently from local people and I cannot agree with Vicky Ford, who said that we will put some kind of additional obligations on our small companies. No way – they have to sell like at home. This means that the sellers’ law has to apply.
