If I want to buy a bottle of water, as a consumer, I will take those risks and I do not care if there is French writing on the label rather than Estonian. It is my risk. If there are some defects in goods or devices, then I took this risk and I have to take the equipment back to the place where I bought it. So there will be no additional obligations and no additional risks for sellers. Our proposal will make the role of businesses easier and it will also be easier for our citizens. Regarding parcel deliveries, some people said that this is already a well-organised area and there is really no need to intervene. Yes, it is well organised in some countries. In the Netherlands the difference between domestic parcel prices and cross-border parcel delivery prices is just 1.6 times as much, but in one EU Member State this difference is 22 times as much. We do not want to start to regulate those parcel delivery prices, but we would like to ask for more transparency. We believe that if there is more transparency then we will get real competition and our citizens and our businesses will get more affordable prices. Regarding the scope – a question which was raised by Julia Reda, Jan Albrecht, Eva Paunova and many others – of course we can be more ambitious, and I would like to be more ambitious, but my aim is not to be the most ambitious guy in the world. I would like to achieve some concrete aims and if those proposals are too ambitious then I think it will take years and years and we will not achieve any of our aims. But our aim is to take a step-by-step approach and I am sure that then we will achieve some aims, but of course this was a compromise. Consumer organisations asked for a wider scope but, for example, those who represent the music industry in Europe were against it. So we had to make some compromises. Regarding platforms, we decided not to take a horizontal approach but to take a preventive approach, which also means that there will be action. Today we already made our proposal about the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, and our aim was to make those advertising rules, sponsorship and product placement, more flexible. Today we also made a proposal about the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive. This also means that there will be more transparency for platforms. At the end of September we will make our telecom rules proposal, then a second package proposal on copyright, and an e-privacy proposal. It will also be all about our platforms. I am sorry, my time is over, but I would like to continue with the discussions we have just started. If you invite me, it will be my pleasure to take part in your party group meetings and committee meetings.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The European Commission communication on the supposed upgrading of the single market contains pompous announcements that do not correspond to reality. There can be no competition on equal terms when Member States, or at least many of them, give a variety of opportunities for multinational companies in particular to avoid tax at the expense of other Member States.  We therefore need harmonisation of tax legislation, as well as a pan-European deposit guarantee scheme, in order to eliminate the uncertainty that undermines banking systems, particularly in the Mediterranean Member States and especially in Greece.  This is the only way to smooth out the huge differences in business and household borrowing rates between Member States, which result in investment apnea and an increase in unemployment in the economically weaker Member States of the Union.  Instead of the Commission exposing to us the advantages of an inactive single market in practice, it should propose concrete actions to smooth out these glaring inequalities, in a spirit of solidarity between member states. Otherwise, the prolonged existence of these distortions will, sooner or later, threaten the very foundations of the European unifying process.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – There are many gaps in EU legislation that hinder the proper functioning of the digital single market, allowing the EU to generate profits of up to EUR 415 billion per year by 2020 and a GDP growth of 0.4%. Infringements of intellectual property rights are a big problem. In 2013 only, the customs authorities recorded as many as 87 000 cases of such fraud, with an estimated value of EUR 36 million of articles retained amounting to more than EUR 768 million. In this context, the European Commission has presented a three-pillar e-commerce development plan aimed at preventing the above-mentioned problems and achieving the objectives of the Digital Agenda. Its elements are: preventing unjustified geo-blocking, reducing costs and increasing the efficiency of the delivery of foreign parcels, and better protection and enforcement of the law. As regards geo-blocking, the new package takes equal account of the consumer's right to shop freely online in different countries and the legal certainty needed by businesses. The proposal also reflects the Commission's new approach to online platforms. After a thorough assessment of the social and economic role of these new actors, the EC concluded that a one-size-fits-all approach was not appropriate to address the diverse challenges of the multitude of types of online platforms.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – Long awaited proposals on boosting digital single market were presented. Although aimed to tear down digital walls, unfortunately the EC proposal does not seem to reach far enough. Measures concerning geoblocking, geodiscrimination of online sales, content and payments are to be welcomed, but they seem to be more of a cosmetic nature than substantially enhancing the potential of the digital single market. I hope that the EP and the Member States will expand the proposals on e-commerce. I welcome the measures foreseen to make parcel delivery costs transparent that could push the service providers to change their price policy and by that boosting cross-border delivery service and e-commerce. It is regrettable that the provisions on online sales do not aim to completely abolish geodiscrimination and are limited only to sale, but not to delivery. In my view everyone should be able to purchase goods online everywhere in the EU and have it delivered to their home country paying the existing parcel delivery price. Also, it is unfortunate that whereas geodiscrimination of payment methods has been reduced, it would still allow merchants to limit payments to local cards, such as bancontact or girocard and therefore exclude everyone not in possession of concrete Belgian or German payment card.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Socialist Group welcomes a package that this Eurochamber has been working on since 2011. In particular, the Commission has published two new packages of initiatives: the first aims to boost cross-border online trade across Europe, remove barriers, increase consumer confidence and end discrimination. The second follows a legislative modernization approach for online platforms and broadcasting standards. Today, in the physical world we find it unthinkable that a buyer is rejected in one store, just because he lives in another state. However, this does happen today in online shopping, and it is precisely one of the things to avoid: ending the unjustified geoblock definitively, because it discriminates against consumers on the basis of residency criteria or even the country of issuance of their credit card. To relaunch and strengthen the single market, we need to put the consumer at the heart of our concerns.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The digital single market is essential to enhance the potential existing in this sector in Europe. Reinforcing the common market will enable our businesses and entrepreneurs to take advantage of the opportunities offered across Europe. Nevertheless a strong Digital Single Market should take into consideration the needs of the weak, I mean by that the SMEs, start-ups and digital professionals. Therefore we should not take for granted the benefits of the common market and should work together into steering the market in the direction that can help quality job creation.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – I consider enforcement of consumer protection rules to be one of the main priorities of single market policies, because even the best consumer legislation cannot work without proper enforcement. From a number of consultations with representatives of supervisory authorities and consumer organisations, I note that there is great potential to strengthen and improve cooperation between public authorities at all levels in the enforcement of consumer protection rules. I also consider it important to look for new ways to strengthen and improve the enforcement of consumer law across the EU and the Member States, e.g. through greater involvement of consumer organisations. I therefore welcome the legislative review of the Regulation on cooperation in the field of consumer protection, and I believe that the debate here in Parliament and between the Member States will lead to an improvement in the existing framework of cooperation between the actors mentioned. I would also like to emphasise the contribution of coordinated control actions within the internal market, and I believe that we should make greater use of this instrument both to deal with cross-border cases and as an appropriate platform for sharing best practices in the fight against unfair behaviour in individual Member States. Although today's proposal is presented as part of the Digital Internal Market Strategy, please bear in mind that effective enforcement is far from just about the online environment.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – The Digital Single Market gives European citizens and businesses the opportunity to move freely in EU Member States, without barriers, or to provide online services in the digital world, while respecting fair competition, high consumer protection and data protection rules. However, despite living in the world of the digital revolution, many people, especially SMEs and traditional industrial sectors, have not yet fully adapted to the demands of the digital world. That is why the Commission's Digital Market Strategy for Europe, which provides a single and comprehensive regulatory framework, is important and welcome. The development of digital literacy is therefore important throughout Europe, and Hungary especially for young people, as it is very poorly developed in This area in Europe. At the same time, today in Hungary, the public debate is more about the total failure and failure of public education than about how to develop young people's digital skills. For months, the Hungarian teaching community, secondary and university students, parents and civilians who have expressed solidarity with them have been demanding without results the transformation of the dysfunctional education system and the opening of a constructive dialogue on this. While this may seem like an individual problem for Member States, it does warn that it is worth taking a closer look at the viability of individual education systems, where digital skills would be developed with EU support, if we really want to realise the potential of the Commission's strategy.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The internet revolution has had a huge impact on global trade opportunities. The new economy, which owes its creation to technological developments, was the engine of the changes taking place in the way commercial enterprises are conducted. Regulations in e-commerce should not discriminate against e-customers in any way. Purchasing opportunities should set the same rules as in traditional trade. Discrimination which is so important in the commercial transactions of the consumer must not be allowed only on the basis of his place of residence or the country of establishment. Regulating the working conditions of businesses in the digital market will, as a result, increase e-customer confidence in online shopping. The still unfair actions of actors on online platforms, which are part of the digital reality, should be eliminated. They have increased opportunities for consumers and businesses to shop and do business. Regulation must be introduced, which will, as a result, create fair competition. Fair functioning of operators will give all market participants a level playing field.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Union needs, in order to consolidate and combat the risks of political, economic and social fragmentation, to strengthen its strategic stakes. The Digital Union, of which the digital single market is a central component, is one of those priorities.  The market for 500 million consumers and the dawn of a new digital age are opportunities that the European Union cannot miss. Anyone who wants to operate in the European digital market has to comply with the rules of that market, but to do so, these rules must be appropriate to new technological challenges and avoid unnecessary barriers to the development of trade, in the context of equity in access, inclusion, the protection of consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises, and respect for individual and collective rights.  The decision to move forward with three legislative proposals for e-commerce (eliminating unjustified geo-blocking, regulating cross-border delivery costs and enhancing consumer protection) and a Directive updating the rules applicable to audiovisual services and online platforms, is timely and partially recovers the delay in implementing the strategy set out in the Communication of 6 May 2015.  It is important that this impetus will speed up the realisation of the Digital Union.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, President Juncker is travelling as we speak to the G7 Summit in Japan and has asked me to address you on his behalf, ahead of a summit that will address a number of urgent priorities. The economic backdrop is one of gradual recovery for our economy, despite a difficult global environment. EU annual growth reached 2% in 2015. Our first-quarter growth this year was higher than that of the United States. Unemployment is certainly still much too high in some Member States but, across the board, it has fallen to its lowest in five years. Today, there are five million more jobs than in 2013. Confidence is gradually returning – we see it on investment, on consumer spending, on lending. But we must remain alert. Our main trading partners’ slower performance is a cause for concern. Last year, growth outside the EU fell to its lowest since 2009 as emerging markets performed less well. Against this backdrop of uncertainty, growth will depend on the opportunities we create for ourselves. We need investment, structural reforms and responsible public finances. We need to stay the course. This Parliament has played a vital role in this strategy. You made it possible to launch the Investment Plan for Europe at record speed. In less than one year, it has triggered EUR 100 billion in new investments, and delivered finance on better terms to more than 140 000 SMEs. It is generating structural change. Until now, European investment has often been dominated by a limited number of large, expensive projects. Today, we are starting to see more local projects, which are smaller and more diverse. Public money is mobilising private finance, and supporting structural reforms. We see more interaction between the European Investment Bank and local institutions. In short, we are beginning to see the kind of investment that the market has often failed to deliver. Our Fund is helping to find new treatments for Alzheimer’s disease; transforming old industrial sites into new offices; bringing energy efficiency into our homes and cutting our bills; and lending a hand to start-ups who were turned away by other lenders. Investment is high on the agenda of the G7. And we have a good story to tell. We will also deliver better news on Greece. Last year, we fought hard to keep Greece in the euro area. Today, the economic data is better than expected. Greece should return to growth in the second half of 2016. Unemployment fell in 2015, and the government reached a primary surplus of 0.7% of GDP. The stability support programme agreed last summer has laid the ground for long-term stable development. Above all, we have managed to secure Greece’s place in the euro area. This week’s agreement on the completion of the first review of the programme only confirms that. Discussions on reducing the Greek debt burden have now started. This recognises the collective effort made by the people of Greece. Today, the Greek economy can turn the corner, and we are confident that international investors will follow. Within the G7, the European Union has always fought for a global economy that is governed by rules, increasingly transparent, and as fair as possible. In other words, we strive to export our best practices to the global stage. At this week’s summit, we will continue these efforts. Together with our G7 partners, we need to demonstrate that global trade can work for everyone – not just for every country, but for every part of our society. We know that, in the short term, globalisation produces winners and losers. This has helped to fuel populist forces around the world. And so our challenge is not only to shape the rules of the game and to ensure that they are respected, but also to argue that our long-term prosperity lies in openness and exchange. Over the last year, the European Union has taken the lead on tax transparency. We now have a ground-breaking agreement on tax rulings, and earlier this year we adopted a new proposal on country-by-country reporting. Our message is clear: everyone must pay their fair share. We must now work with our G7 partners to ensure that this is a truly global effort. If our own Member States have agreed to put in place central registers of beneficial ownership, then our partners must do the same. For those that try to evade their duty to society, there must be no place to hide. We must be equally firm on those countries that do not play by the rules. Free trade must be fair trade. I can assure this House today that the European Commission stands by a robust trade defence system. If somebody distorts the market, we will take action. This Commission has launched a record number of trade defence measures to respond to the dumping on Europe’s steel industry. At the G7, we will argue that offending countries need to produce clear and measurable plans to cut over-capacity. International monitoring must ensure that everyone complies. Let me now turn to the global refugee crisis, which is rightly high on the G7 agenda. This Commission has argued from the start that only global solutions will work. Here, once again, this Parliament has helped to deliver a European strategy that is comprehensive: saving lives at sea, providing humanitarian assistance, strengthening our borders, supporting the countries most under pressure, relocating and resettling people in need of international protection, returning irregular migrants to their home countries, and creating safe and legal routes for asylum-seekers from outside the European Union. In 2015 and 2016, the EU will have devoted more than EUR 10 billion to managing the crisis. This strategy has given us the breathing space to look to the future. Together with our G7 partners, we must now develop a truly global response, backed by proper resources, and capable of addressing the root causes of migration. An international resettlement programme is urgent and necessary. Only by giving asylum-seekers a legal route to safety will we convince them not to risk their lives. This is the best way to break the business model of the smugglers. And the best way to restore dignity to those who genuinely need our protection.  Let me conclude with climate and energy. This week’s summit of the G7 is the first since the Paris agreement. The real work starts now: modernising our economy and changing the way we produce and consume. This in turn requires new incentives across the entire spectrum of policy. The best of our businesses have read the signal: leading European companies are changing their business models, and creating new jobs that require new skills, innovative processes and investments. The European Union must have the ambition to be a world leader in renewables: the sector now employs over one million people and generates EUR 130 billion in turnover each year. European companies today hold 40% of all patents for renewable technologies. But major obstacles remain. In 2013, across the world, subsidies for fossil fuels amounted to almost EUR 500 billion. That is a lot of money being spent very badly. The G7 has promised to phase out those subsidies by 2025. Next we must push the G20 to do the same. As we approach this week’s summit in Japan, the need for political coordination at the global level is as compelling as ever. From a slowing global economy to a global refugee crisis, the countries of the G7 need to show leadership and join forces. As the European Union, we will continue to make the case for a global economy that is governed by rules, and an open society that seeks prosperity and security in its exchange with others. In today’s uncertain world, our contribution really matters.

name: Paulo Rangel
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to greet the Commissioner, Vice-President Timmermans, and I would like to say this.  It is clear that the agenda of this G7 is extremely broad. Here, the Japanese Presidency did not hesitate to put, at last, a kind of passage through all the themes and I would like to focus on four main themes. The first is about investment and then, frankly, I think the European Union has to make some effort. I do not think the Juncker Plan is enough because the most relevant economies of the European Union are also represented here individually (I am thinking of Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy). They themselves have to make their efforts and, in particular, some of them are able to make an investment in quality and qualifying infrastructure, which can play a start-up role in the European economy and the global economy, and therefore, as President Obama said in his very recent Hanover speech, it is important that the G7 countries also make an effort to make that investment. Secondly, I think it is essential and that affects us too, the European Union, is the tax issue and especially the issue of tax havens where I think we can do much more and the G7 has great responsibilities. It is also important to involve these countries and not just Europe in the refugee crisis. Canada, Japan, the United States, Australia cannot isolate themselves from this fight. And finally, I'd like to leave just one word, and with that I'm done, on an essential point that is the Zika virus. We talk a lot about Ebola but Zika is coming to Europe, it is already reaching the southern shore of Europe, and it is essential that the G7 tackles this problem. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You have given due emphasis to economic issues. But do you not think that this meeting, this, could be an unrealistic opportunity for Europe to make the main economic forces understand that Europe really needs solidarity now. Not least because a little bit others feel this is a European problem – in terms of migration issues. In other word, I ask: do you see the possibility that the event is now about solidarity?

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. "Thank you so much for your question. What I said is exactly, in a double vein, that.  Firstly, on the issue of economic start-up, the idea that we ourselves, the most developed countries, have investment obligations and, in particular, those countries that are more unobstructed, which can pull from others, and this applies to the global economy as it applies to the European economy.  And on the issue of refugees, I have no doubt that Europe should not face this challenge alone, although it can do a lot and is already doing something. It must face this challenge precisely with the support of the other countries that have the most economic power in the global framework. They also have a responsibility, they are also responsible for the refugees.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, global cooperation must never be strengthened and given effective answers, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D).  A new globalisation, less indifferent to those who do not directly benefit from it, is the only response to those who draw on fears and revitalise ideas that we had hoped had been overcome forever: nationalism, separatism, xenophobia and walls. The agenda of the summit in Japan is very ambitious and so, we hope, are the conclusions, from foreign policy, to climate change, to sustainable development. A central point will be global trade, on which we need a new impetus that will strengthen isolationist tendencies and which will ensure that the rules are respected by all, because only by complying with these rules can global cooperation work. In this respect, in line with the resolution that this Parliament voted on two weeks ago, we hope that a coherent way of relations will be found with China, a fundamental partner, but one that must also be involved in the definition of fair and sustainable trade. This applies above all to the question of granting market economy status, as well as to overcapacity, especially in the steel sector, and to respect for common rules for market access. Finally, we would like to stress with satisfaction the inclusion on the agenda of the issue of gender equality. The European institutions, which have always been at the forefront of promoting women's empowerment, will be able to take the opportunity of the G7 to support proposals aimed at reducing all gender gaps with concrete and coordinated measures.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work At the top of the G7 agenda is the global economy, and I believe rightly. There are the following reasons for this. Firstly, the world economy is not growing as fast as it used to, and third-world countries will suffer above all. Secondly, the main engine of the world economy, international trade, is stuttering. And thirdly, of the regions represented at the summit, the eurozone has been holding the red lantern for some time. That is why I would like to give some advice to Presidents Tusk and Juncker on their way to Japan. Firstly, make a commitment to a fresh start in world trade. Key words here are TTIP, CETA and TPP. Globalisation is not just an economic phenomenon. It brings not only goods, services and goods around the world, but also ideas such as democracy and human rights. Secondly, resist the sweet poison of a possible devaluation race. And thirdly, you will certainly be asked why the eurozone has been floundering for years. The answer lies in the one-size-fits-all currency. Currencies must correspond to economic realities. We must stop subjecting the economic, financial and fiscal cultures of the countries to the needs of the currency. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Dear Mr. Henkel, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. They have referred to the supposedly fading eurozone. Do you agree with me that this supposedly so simmering zone had greater economic growth in the first quarter of this year than the possibly so vital United States of America? So could it be helpful if you reconsider your view of the eurozone, if you take note of the reality in this world?

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – A note: the truth is, of course, part of the consideration of reality, and the truth cannot be pinpointed to the results of 90 days. My statement relates to ten years and, incidentally, to the official forecasts of the OECD, and these clearly show that this year, too, the euro area is lagging behind the United States, behind the rest of the world and, incidentally, behind all the countries in the EU that do not have the euro.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Madam President, let me start by saying that clearly the Dutch Presidency does not attach that much importance to the G7 summit, but I am glad that the Commission does. I also share a lot of what the Vice-President has said on a number of important points – I think points that are relevant for the agenda, points where the EU has a lot to show. Against the background of the all the crises that we are facing I think that there are plenty of positive messages, and I am glad that you have raised this.  I also appreciate what you have said about investment, structural reforms and of course sound finances, as well as the distortion of the market and the response the EU has to make in this respect. But you have also used the word confidence, confidence in the markets – I would use ‘confidence’ in a different context: confidence in the G7. I think that the reality is that from the last summits of the G7 we do not have that much to cheer about. The G7 for me is an important forum and it can be a very successful one, but there are ingredients which are absolutely key.  Problems identified – we have mentioned some of them and I think we have plenty of those. Then we need to be able to arrive at a certain degree of consensus if not unanimity. That seems to be much more problematic, which brings me to the third ingredient, namely that it might be key – and that might be an opportunity for the EU,  not just on concrete issues, but in general – to take up leadership. Clearly what the G7 is lacking in recent years is leadership, and the outcome of the G 7 reflects that. That is a reality, and if we look at the agenda, the agenda is full and relevant, but we already know in advance that it is going to be extremely difficult to agree on the common growth strategies. The ministers were unable to agree on it. Hopefully the summit will do better, but on one of the key points on the agenda, clearly we are unable to agree or we have difficulties.  So I would expect President Juncker and President Tusk to show leadership in this respect and not just to show in our windscreens what we can be rightly proud of, but really take up the leadership and deliver. We are not delivering and I think the public expects that.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – You know that climate change is a great threat to our future and it is linked also with migrants coming especially from the sub-Saharan area. Do you not think that the European Commission President and the European Council President should take the lead at the G7 meeting, because you were talking about confidence, and should call on the Heads of State of the seven countries to ratify as soon as possible the agreement made in Paris in order to set an example to other states?

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, if I spoke of leadership I meant it ‘en bloc’. I think that all the issues that are on the agenda are absolutely relevant. But leadership also means that we are able to find an agreement on all those issues. Leadership does not always mean by definition that we are well ahead while the rest of the world lags behind. And on climate change, relevant as it is, we need a global deal, and we need everyone to really put in the effort so that we have a harmonised effect.

name: Tania González Peñas
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to share with you our concern about the European Union's position on economic strategies to combat this growing global economic uncertainty. However, far from taking advantage of these forums to curb global speculation and regularize tax havens, decisions are still being made that perpetuate the problem.  This economic uncertainty which now terrifies world elites is the consequence of the anti-social practices encouraged by the Commission. Indeed, there is a global investment crisis, and it is citizens who see how major powers continue to promote global financial speculation rather than seek solutions to people's lives.  It is not too late for Mr Juncker and Mr Task to make self-criticism, to stop improvising plans to save the usual ones — not new businesses, the usual ones - and to seek solutions that keep in mind the peoples who expect something else from the European Union beyond cuts and misery.  And, Mr. Timmermans, fair trade is not the TTIP. That's the trade of 1% of multinationals. It's not trade for most, for 99%.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Timmermans, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his I would like to make two brief points. At the G7 a year ago, the big buzzword was decarbonisation. The big promise was that we would make the global economy climate-friendly and, at the same time, provide economic recovery. You yourself mentioned it: at the same time, the countries that are now regrouping are still investing large sums in coal, oil, gas, etc. You have criticised the fact that environmentally harmful subsidies continue. I wonder at this point: what are we doing in Europe in this regard? Is there a proposal that, after what you have just said, will now come to put an end to the environmentally harmful subsidies? Instead, I see in the European semester that the proposals on ecological fiscal policy have been reduced and not strengthened. So be brave in this area yourself, and the G7 should realise what it has announced. My second point is that two months ago, this House adopted a report, the Goulard report, calling for stronger rules against conflicts of interest, accountability and transparency of global institutions. Mr Timmermans, will you be taking the proposals we have made into the G7? How will the G7 itself implement these proposals, and how will the European Commission implement these proposals in its work in the G7? I would be looking forward to an answer.

name: Patrick O’Flynn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the sad truth is that the European Commissioners are going to be excluded from the only meaningful action at the G7 summit, which will be more blood-curdling warnings to the British not to dare to vote to leave the EU. You see, the likes of Mr Juncker and Mr Timmermans, and Mr Tusk as well, are judged to be counterproductive even to Project Fear as a reminder to voters of eurozone folly and wider EU economic failure. How embarrassing it must be for the EU’s representatives to turn up to each G7 with yet another excuse for economic failure. This time, according to the Commission’s own fact sheet, they intend to claim that despite a more difficult global environment the EU’s recovery continues. That reminds me of the old line about never letting the facts get in the way of a good story. We are told the economy in all Member States will grow next year, albeit unevenly – that is one word for it. The Commission’s G7 factsheet says that investment, although still low compared with pre-crisis levels, is ‘gaining traction’. Traction in my country is what we put patients in when they have serious fractures. Let me remind you that the crisis was in 2008, yet recovery has still not taken a firm hold. The fact sheet hopes to get average unemployment in the EU below 10% in 2017. That is not a fact sheet, it is a wish list. And it is always ‘jam tomorrow’, is it not? As the much-loved British sitcom character Del Boy used to say, ‘this time next year we could be millionaires’. It is not going to happen under the euro, the euro is a losers’ currency. It is not a case of the eurozone battling against the global environment so much as the euro dragging down the global economic environment. And instead of facing up to this, no doubt even now you will be dreaming up your excuses for the 2017 summit, predicting that 2018 will be your year. Face it: the dog did not eat your homework, the euro killed your growth.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, by a ruse of history, the European Union is the eighth participant in the G7 summits, theoretically reserved for seven states. Mr Tusk and Mr Junker will therefore represent her at the next summit, which will take place on 26 and 27 May in Japan. I am afraid, alas, that they will have a negative influence on the resolution of three problems that will be discussed there. In economic matters, they will advocate, as usual, ultraliberalism, which is the misfortune of the European peoples. Will they have the audacity to welcome progress in the TAFTA negotiations, as they did at last year's G7? I bet they do, because they are deaf to the concerns of public opinion. In terms of foreign policy, they will probably be attacking Russia, while Russia is objectively our main ally in the fight against the Islamic State and against terrorism. And when it comes to the migration crisis, they will strengthen the G7 states in their mistake. The only solution to solve it, in the long term, is to provide assistance to education and economic development to the states that need it, in order to fix the populations at home. But who cares? At the World Humanitarian Summit in Istanbul, which just ended on 24 May, the G7 leaders were not there, and today the Council is not even represented in the European Parliament. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear Colleague Llobreton, the financial leaders of the G7 countries have adopted an action plan calling for increased exchange of information in order to prevent the financing of terrorism. Don't you think the G7 is an outdated structure that no longer represents the strongest economies, given the absence of China and India, of a number of Arab states there, and in practice their decisions have no particular effect? And don't you think that this structure duplicates other similar structures, and in fact a similar debate is, to put it mildly, a waste of time?

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. Thank you for this very interesting question. I think the G7 is an interesting tool among others to solve international problems. As far as the exchange of information is concerned, this exchange is of course necessary in many areas, particularly in the fight against terrorism. I am a representative of a political group that advocates cooperation between sovereign states and I therefore believe that this kind of exchange of information is acceptable provided that it is not taken over by the Brussels Commission, which inevitably overturns the right projects.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – In itself, we should be pleased that the issue of the migrant crisis is also on the agenda at the G7 summit. And it is stressed here, also by the Vice-President of the Commission, that the press statements also state that this must be solved as a global task. That's right, it's true. But what do we consider a task? The declaration lists the financial burden on the European Union. But it is not enough that global partners contribute to this on a solidarity basis. This is about responsibility. In particular, the responsibility of the United States, which, in an armed attempt to export Western democracy, created the Arab Spring that brought this region into anarchy and made a fundamental contribution to this influx of migrants. So we do need this call for responsibility, and the United States has a way of allowing refugees not to come to Europe through Saudi Arabia and the rich countries along the Gulf.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have five million more jobs than in 2013 in the European Union today, and many of them have been created because of and thanks to globalisation. On the other hand, we are currently worrying hundreds of thousands of people, for example in the steel sector, partly because of globalisation. That is why I would ask you to use the G7 summit to increase opportunities and reduce the risks, so that we can continue to have a positive attitude towards globalisation in our European Union. Why? Take the example of China. We currently have one billion trade volumes a day between the European Union and China. On the one hand, this is a huge market for us and on the other hand an important supplier of goods and precursors for our side. Because of China, many jobs have been created on the one hand, yes, but on the other hand, many workers are also concerned about this: do they abide by the rules? Don't they make everything flat by unfair trading practices such as shoes, solar cells or now in the steel sector? How do we shape our relations with China and other key partners? That is why I would ask you to take the opportunity of the G7 summit to shape and talk about rules of globalisation with the international partners, so that we can continue to have many new jobs and fewer new concerns in Europe. On the one hand, I would like us to have open markets. But I hope that we will continue to have industrial jobs in Europe in the future. That is why, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, rejoice when new offices are created from old industrial wastelands. Please, please, also work to ensure that industries in Europe can survive and that new industrial jobs can also be created in Europe, otherwise our prosperity will be threatened.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: Madam President, at the beginning of this month, Japanese Prime Minister Abe toured Europe to prepare for the G7. He had a clear message for his European colleagues: governments must do more to boost the economy. There is more reason for this now than ever, because China sees economic problems and the other emerging countries already have those problems. And the G7 has traditionally been the forum to achieve some form of economic coordination.  It is not surprising that Shinzō Abe makes a plea. He's obviously the inventor of that. He wants to break the deflationary spiral in Japan, but unfortunately the European reaction is no surprise either. The European economic superpowers continue to refuse and, in particular, Minister Schaüble of Germany. After last week's G7 summit of finance ministers, he gave the only answer: structural reforms.  But the Japanese Prime Minister is right: structural reforms are not enough. European governments will need to do more to stimulate demand and drive investment. I am afraid that the G7 summit will end with a rebuke to The European divisions in order to face the problems that we have here, and which we cannot turn to abroad.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the G7 conference is incapable of providing solutions to the problems of the world economy, as it insists on austerity and continues to support the casino economy. In a multipolar world, the smug shape of the G7 cannot provide answers to the modern economy without taking into account the rising power of the BRICS. That is why we do not trust the conclusions that the forthcoming G7 conference will draw on Greek debt, as yesterday's eurogroup decision confirms that Greece's lenders are "skinning the ox twice".  So instead of the European Union and the IMF to cut the Greek debt and settle the repayment of the rest with a growth clause, as they have already done in the case of Ukraine, they ultimately refuse to write down the nominal debt, demand austerity measures and uninterrupted fiscal adjustment, as well as a ninety-nine-year sell-off of public property.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, what role does the G-7 play today? You just have to see how it was founded to understand what interests it defends. The G-7 is part of defending an old correlation of forces. Born in the 1970s in a multipolar world, he does not understand that we are facing the end of the second globalization, that of which he told us that all sovereignty should go to the United States, all the sovereignty of the world. We're on the way back from a multipolar world. THE BRICS remind us of it every day. The Vice-President's intervention is clarifying. He talks about the global economy and the damage of globalization and steals the economic agenda that you have taken. And then he talks about populist forces, trying to end democracy and democratic debate. He talks about fair trade. Let me laugh. Or the dispersion of markets, which we're going to act on. What does the TTIP agenda mean for a stance on new emerging countries or the cause of emigration? Sir, this is not a problem of emigration but of refugees. More of the same: defending a multipolar world and its unjust world of neoliberal exceptionality.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I also welcome The First Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Timmermans, and thank him for presenting the key positions of the European Commission ahead of the 42nd G7 Summit, an important global governance forum that has been giving the European Union an opportunity for around 35 years to jointly articulate positions on those issues on the world agenda. In this context, its analysis of the fact that most economic factors and indicators have been improved at EU level should be a boost to those countries of the European Union that are not at this level, neither in terms of growth nor in terms of reducing employment and implementing structural reforms. In this regard too, the European Strategic Investment Plan should be a benchmark and an indicator of the direction of further development of a number of Member States.  What seems essential to me for this G7 meeting is that in addition to the topics mentioned by Mr Timmermans, when it comes to jointly finding solutions to both the migration crisis and the refugee crisis, we need to see what the contribution of the European Union can be in linking this crisis to the objectives of sustainable development policy of the European Union and agenda 2030.  Of course, dialogue on strengthening overall trade relations globally, concluding agreements where we take into account the interests of our consumers and our public health standards should also contribute in this regard. It is also important to agree on further cooperation at the level of global security and foreign policy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the global challenges we are facing have been well versed in this House: terrorism, the migration crisis, energy and climate change. And we are still grappling with the consequences of the financial crisis, so the main aim for the G7 has to be to address this. We live in an interdependent and interconnected world where we really need to find solutions together. The G7 are the most powerful economies of the world and they must tackle the level of unemployment we face. They must tackle this to increase job creation, because only together can we really tackle the challenges that we face. Rightly, this meeting is concerned about the outcome of the UK referendum on its membership of the EU. Members of Britain’s leading tax and spending think-tank have warned today that leaving the EU would force ministers to extend austerity measures by up to two years to achieve a budget surplus. Thus, the message is clear, if we want our voice to be heard on a global level we want the UK to lead and to stay in the EU. As Gordon Brown stated elegantly this morning, when it comes to the UK relationship in the EU ‘it should be about clout and not about out’.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to focus on the reconstitution of the G8 and the economic and political reopening to Russia. I believe that we urgently need to review relations with Washington in the run-up to the British referendum and the US elections: better to prepare before than after, better to predict our disintegration with both Brexit and non-Brexit. As for Moscow, I wonder whether Europe has an interest in a quadrupled US and NATO military presence on its eastern borders, which will alienate Russia more than ever. Washington will move away from Europe with Trump or use it, if Hillary Clinton wins, as a tool for failed policies in the Middle East, Syria and Libya. Preparing means re-discussing these policies, having their own. From those policies were born Isis, wars and what we call the "refugee issue", when it is "our question", "our débâcle".

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to stress two points that are already on the g7's broad agenda and add a comment on an item that is unfortunately lacking, in my opinion, guiltily. The first issue is the fight against tax avoidance and evasion. The OECD proposal is a small proposal, insufficient. I believe that it is also important to go further in terms of bilateral relations and multilateral relations, that is to say, to have solutions that are more binding, more transparent and that introduce reporting, country by country, at international level. The second issue is that of international trade agreements. There is a lack of transparency, we cannot watch helplessly negotiations the content of which we do not know, especially when they concern social, environmental and consumer safety standards. The last issue, which is lacking, is the activity of multinationals and respect for human rights. I believe it is important to guarantee the UN's guiding principles on business and human rights. All too often the production chain goes so far as to cancel rights that affect people, even in some cases children. I believe that this is no longer acceptable.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would just like to make a reference to the question of international trade. We must improve the international political environment in order to prevent the nationalist virus, which is manifesting itself on a large political level, from the point of view of the international trade relationship. But that does require a great deal of effort on the part of the world's major powers and European opinion plays a very important role in creating a more favourable environment, with greater transparency from a commercial point of view, from a budgetary point of view and also from a fiscal point of view, to combat tax evasion and fraud. Because if we do not, in fact, we are creating the conditions for protectionism to come back in force with all the tragic consequences that may result. The second thing I would like to mention here is precisely the need to project the treatment of the refugee issue at the global level. The European Union has tried to respond, sometimes better, sometimes worse, but the truth is that we have to find the capacity to create a global concern for the handling of this issue and I believe that this is an especially favourable occasion for this issue to be placed on the global political agenda.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Commissioner, you have made a summary of the Commission's main concerns for the future, reviewing the achievements of the last two years. I admit that I was surprised by your statement on poorly spent subsidies - around four hundred billion for the reduction of emissions. But what guarantees do we have that the following subsidies will not be spent poorly? What guarantees do you give us? You have talked about tax evasion, but here it has been some time since the Panama revelations, and we do not yet have concrete measures to prevent a new Panama case. What will you decide on the G7? I liked that you said about trade: it has to be free, but it must also be fair. Do you think we have all the measures to have a fair trade? I believe that no, and that is why I believe, Commissioner, that you must find targeted measures for trade defence, to harmonise standards when concluding trade agreements with other markets, such as the US, Canada or China. Europe must be reindustrialised intelligently if we want jobs, and I believe that yes, the global economy must be governed, only these rules must be fair. What do you do not have two more Europes, Commissioner?

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Timmermans, colleagues, the G7 summit in Japan is of utmost importance as it takes place at a time when the world is facing numerous global challenges. The deepening of the global humanitarian crisis, the decline of the global economy, the growing threats of terrorism, the impact of climate change and ongoing ethno-religious conflicts are urgent issues that the world's leading powers must offer a solution to based on specific priorities and specific commitments. That is why the European Union must play a significant role at the upcoming G7 summit in Japan. We need to focus on resolving the refugee crisis, fighting terrorism, developing free trade, but also respecting all humanitarian aid commitments made at the Humanitarian Summit in Istanbul. The European Union must insist on strengthening international cooperation in the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance.  Last but not least, the European Union must show that it is ready to fulfil its commitments.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I will make just a few remarks. I have to say to the Honourable Member Giegold, who had two specific questions for me: on the first question I will have to get back to you in writing because I cannot answer you immediately; on the issue of expert groups and conflict of interests in expert groups, we have had a long debate also with the Parliament and with Dennis de Jong, another of your colleagues, on this, and the Commission’s position will be forthcoming before the end of this month on this specific issue. In general, I would like to say that indeed we face huge global economic challenges on the issues we have discussed, but I think drawing up the drawbridge and building walls is not going to get us out of this conundrum. So all those who say we should break with neoliberal policies are right... but I am not sure that is what they are talking about. I think global trade will be necessary to create innovation and growth in the European Union. If you look at the challenge we face, given our demographic situation, then if we stay where we are, the best possible option is to defend what we have, which means, very simply, that we will slow down decline. So if you really want to use the opportunities that global developments are offering, you need to move towards a sustainable economy, you need to embrace the digital single market, you need to create an energy union and you need to make sure that your economy becomes circular. For all of that, you need change. You need to take the necessary steps in that direction. That is the only way we can create enough economic growth which is sustainable, which does not deplete the Earth but which maintains our natural resources and which will enable us to create the social environment that is wanted by the vast majority of Europeans. We need growth for that, given our demographic challenge. That is what the Commission will be advocating in the G7 – to use the opportunity that global trade offers without being naive about the abuse of the elements of global trade if we do not stick to the rules and if we do not have fair play. That is the essence of what we are doing. I do agree with all of those who have said that we need to have an enhanced attention towards implementing the Paris agreements. Again, if you follow my reasoning that we need a sustainable economy, we need to make sure that we slow down global warming and that we actually do what we promised in Paris. For that, concrete measures are necessary and they need to be discussed in the G7 framework. Finally, let me emphasise – and I cannot say this enough – the migration and refugee crisis is here to stay. It is not something that will end if, at last, the war in Syria comes to an end. Look at the huge demographic pressures we will see from Africa and elsewhere. It is in our essential interest that we create sustainable growth in our neighbourhood. And when I talk about our neighbourhood, I mean the wider neighbourhood, including the whole of Africa. The G7 should be talking about that as well. This is about migration, this is about opportunity, this is about decent, rule-of-law-based government and all these things have become factors on a global scale for the decisive choice Europe needs to make: whether we want to export our stability and our prosperity, or whether we want to wait until we import instability and poverty from elsewhere. That, I think, should be the position of the European Union in the deliberations in the G7.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, first let me apologise for my late arrival to this important debate. I have already apologised to Mr Telička, Mr Lebreton and also other colleagues here today. We really had a big conflict of interest because of the visit of His Majesty the King, but we have made sure that we made notes. I have heard your comments and would like to reflect also from the side of the Council on some of the issues that you have mentioned in the debate. Now, as the First Vice—President of the Commission said, the G7 leaders will discuss various topics of global importance and, crucially, on which the G7 can provide leadership. The European Union’s internal and external challenges, as we know, are closely intertwined, and therefore it is important for Europe to make use – if I can put it in those words – of this important meeting. We have, more than ever, an interest in being at the G7 since our internal and external security are so intertwined. The issues of migration or terrorism speak for themselves, and we need to take a comprehensive approach to the challenges we face with our other colleagues in the G7. Let me start with an issue which, as you know, is very high on our agenda: the refugee and migration crisis. It is still one of the most urgent and immediate challenges facing us. I think it is not only a true test for our union and our neighbouring states. The European Union has pushed for the issue to be discussed at the level of the G7 in Japan because we are seriously impacted – the rest of the world, by the way, is also impacted – but we see it as a global challenge in need of a global response, and this is why Europeans are making sure these issues receive appropriate attention at a global level. I hope we can become as concrete as possible in these areas. Of course the G7 is not an implementation agency, but it can give the leadership to ensure that is also a global responsibility. Our leaders will update their counterparts on the measures we have taken to address the crisis. Our actions and financial assistance will be more effective if properly integrated in a global effort to address migration issues and promote international peace and security – think about the debates we will have on issues like Syria but, more generally, the transformation in the Middle East. Managing migration is therefore not a European but rather a global responsibility, requiring collective solutions in full respect of our obligations under international law. The G7 is expected to call for a global response. It is a privileged forum, not just to discuss these issues but also to forge partnerships and launch, I hope, collective initiatives for a more equitable burden-sharing. My second point is, of course, the global economy. I think we are constantly reminded that the global economy recovery is too slow, that it does not deliver enough jobs, that downside risks are accumulating, and therefore it is the right time for this group of G7 leaders to clearly signal that securing balanced and inclusive growth not only remains a top priority, but to recall that we have to get our own houses in order in our individual countries. But obviously there is also a collective responsibility. We have seen, I think, that those are the lessons learned by different partners in the G7; that taken in isolation, monetary, fiscal and structural policies do not suffice to boost economic activity in a sustainable way. Additionally, and given recent movements in currency markets, it would also be timely to reaffirm existing exchange rate commitments and call on all to refrain from competitive devaluations and to resist protectionism. This is a risk that we are all faced with, and I think the G7 will have to take some leadership on this. That brings me to the third point: international trade. In 2015, G7 leaders underlined the importance of trade and investment as key drivers of growth, jobs and sustainable development. Tomorrow’s summit will have an important role to play in strengthening the future of the multilateral trade agenda. In this context it is important that on 13 May the council confirmed the broad support for the Commission’s proposals regarding the EU strategic objectives for the post-Nairobi period. Importantly, I think, public trust and support for the free trade agenda has decreased in the context of disappointing global trade in recent years. So we need to get the people back on board, and I think leaders should be clear about the benefits of maintaining economies open and free from protectionism, as well as the importance of multilateral and bilateral trade and investment agreements for growth and jobs. I think it is important that we ensure that we have a much more equal level playing field, and addressing the issue of industrial excess capacity would be part of the solution. Besides that, we should honestly address the concerns of the public. If you look through the history of the world economy, you see that people’s social protection actually leads to openness of international economies and not so much the other way around. Ladies and gentlemen, let me finish with two other issues that I wanted to mention: taxation, another priority that we share with the G7. Now that Panama papers have shown how critical it is to develop and implement international tax standards at the global level, the EU has been at the forefront in fighting tax fraud, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. We have transposed the exchange of information requirements, adopted the fourth anti-money-laundering directive, which makes available information on beneficial ownership, and I am pleased to report today that the Council has formally adopted – after receiving your opinion – the fourth revision of the directive on administrative cooperation as regards country-by-country reporting for multinationals. I think this is important progress. The Council has also adopted conclusions on an external strategy for effective taxation, calling for the establishment of an EU blacklist for non-cooperative jurisdictions, and Ecofin is working on a possible general approach on the anti-tax avoidance directive. I think it is well legitimate to expect the G7 to show some ambition – I hope a lot of ambition – in this area as well. Then on the two last points: the fight against terrorism will inevitably be a key priority for the summit as well. The heinous terrorist attacks which countries nowadays face are every time a direct assault not only on our security but, as we know, on our values of freedom and equality and our way of life. We cannot and will not retreat in the face of this threat. Since last year’s meeting, while the territory which Daesh previously controlled has shrunk, especially in Syria and Iraq as the group has come under sustained military pressure, the threat it presents to the European Union and its partners across the Middle East and North Africa particularly has grown, and we just have to open the papers to see every day what horrific attacks we see in different parts of the world , especially in the Middle East. The summit here of the G7 will be an opportunity to take not only stock of the measures but to examine what additional steps the G7 could adopt. We hope and expect to endorse an action plan on countering terrorism and violent extremism which will highlight the G7’s commitment to making international cooperation against such threats as effective as possible. Furthermore, leaders will discuss the broader political situation in Syria, Iraq and Libya. They will also discuss Ukraine. It is vital that the commitments taken under the Minsk Agreement are fully implemented and that the parties remain fully engaged in the process. These are challenging times for the G7 on several fronts, for the European Union. That is why I think it is important that we enlarge our community of nations that work pragmatically, but on the basis of our common values, on the issues I just mentioned, on the basis of their commitment to the rule of law and human rights and, very important, to solidarity and promotion of rule-based international orders. These are values that also bind us together as Europeans, and in particular guide your work in this House, and I look forward to a strong message of confidence by G7 leaders and to their guidance on policy actions on the several fronts. Again I thank you for the discussion this afternoon.
