name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, Madam Commissioner, the Presidency attaches great importance to a free, open and secure internet. This issue is therefore an important one to me. In the digital age it is well known that personal data are of great value because of the information they contain. They enable businesses to personalise their offers to consumers and law enforcement authorities to track down criminals. Data flows offer economic and social opportunities. At the same time, the sensitive information that personal data contain needs to be protected in order to protect our privacy. It is key to ensure the public’s trust in data flows: trust that is based on a proper framework of protection. Of all transfers of personal data outside the European Union, the transatlantic flow is by far the most important one, be it for commercial or law-enforcement purposes. It is in the interest of the Union and its citizens that the European Union/US privacy shield ensures this certainty and trust, especially after the Schrems judgment by the Court of Justice of last October. This has shown there is legal uncertainty in this area of vital importance for the transatlantic economy. It is also important for European medium-sized businesses, as they are dependent on this adequacy decision – for lack of other instruments – to ensure safe data transfers to the United States. The Commission should fully take into account the Court’s ruling on the safe harbour regime. The new adequacy decision must provide a level of data protection that respects the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the Treaties, as well as the standards set by recent case law. Strong safeguards are the key to restore the public’s trust when it comes to transatlantic data flows. The Council trusts the Commission to ensure the highest possible data protection standards, including clear and directly-applicable principles such as purpose-limitation, rights of the data subject to access and correct their data or to object against the processing, and an effective system of oversight-enforcement and redress of possibilities. Furthermore, the Council supports the efforts of the Commission in working with the United States on improving some aspects of the privacy shield and hence ensure a legally and politically sustainable framework. In that regard I believe, for example, that bulk collection by the United States should only be acceptable under certain circumstances. In that same spirit I welcome the creation of the position of an ombudsperson as an additional mechanism for the handling of complaints submitted by citizens. For the transatlantic transfer of personal data for commercial purposes, the Council considers that the Commission should adopt its adequacy decision on this new transatlantic framework in a speedy manner while ensuring data protection rights. The Council also welcomes the agreement reached in the negotiations between the Commission and its United States counterparts. We are confident that the ongoing internal negotiations on the side of the Union between the Commission and national administrations will lead to a positive outcome, thus paving the way for the new framework to enter into force. As regards data protection in the area of criminal law enforcement, the Council aims at adopting a decision to sign the Umbrella Agreement in time for the agreement to be signed on 2 June at the EU/ US Justice and Home Affairs ministerial meeting in Amsterdam. Shortly thereafter the Council will ask the European Parliament’s consent to conclude the agreement. The agreement does not provide a basis for the transfer of personal data across the Atlantic but will enhance cooperation between the European Union and the United States by setting common data protection standards in this area. This is good news from the European perspective, as the US commits to respecting higher standards than in the past when receiving personal data from Europe, and I think that is very necessary. Thus the agreement will significantly contribute to restoring trust in transatlantic data flows for the purpose of fighting serious crime by adding a supplemental layer of data protection requirements on both the Union and the United States. The Council considers that the agreement represents a clear improvement to the current situation, notably as regards judicial redress, where the US has so far for the first time agreed to extend such rights to EU citizens. This means an EU citizen can now benefit from equal treatment and will have the same judicial redress rights as US citizens. That is why we hope that this Parliament will share our positive assessment of this agreement. The European Union has a great interest in facilitating smooth and safe transfers of personal data to the US that ensure the respect of our citizens’ fundamental rights, both in the commercial and in the law-enforcement area. For example, an EU citizen’s name is identical to that of a suspect in a transatlantic criminal investigation. Their data has been transferred from the EU to the US and erroneously gets collected and included on a US blacklist. The EU citizen now has the right to request their name to be deleted by the authorities. To give you another example in the area of commercial data flows, the privacy shield will offer a significantly-enhanced system of oversight and enforcement, which will enhance the credibility of the system. In the law enforcement area, we will be able to offer strict data protection requirements as well as basic rights to access and correction to our citizens in all instruments covered by the scope of the Umbrella Agreement. Therefore, we hope that the Commission will soon take a decision on the EU/US privacy shield that fully respects the data protection acquis and which will be good for business as well. We are also confident that the Umbrella Agreement is a step in the right direction, as it strengthens legal safeguards for our citizens and enables effective transatlantic cooperation to fight serious crimes.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr. President and honourable Members of the European Parliament, Mr Minister, Ladies and Gentlemen, I am pleased to be here again to speak on the important topic of transatlantic data flows. As you know, the Commission has been working on several fronts to restore trust in transatlantic data flows following the Snowden revelations in 2013. The key measures include the adoption of the EU data protection reform, the Umbrella Agreement for data exchanged for law enforcement purposes, and the new EU-US Privacy Shield to ensure a higher level of data protection for commercial transfers of personal data. The EU-US Privacy Shield arrangement is essential for the continuation of transatlantic data flows while guaranteeing our citizens the fundamental right to the protection of their personal data. We negotiated the Privacy Shield with the US on the basis of two sets of guiding principles. First, our 13 recommendations of November 2013 and, of course, the criteria set by the Court of Justice in the Schrems ruling. Following two years of talks, I am convinced we have overcome the weaknesses of the old Safe Harbour system. Let me briefly summarise the main improvements. First, US companies receiving personal data from Europe will have to comply with stricter rules on how to use and read that information, and their compliance will be monitored closely and proactively by the relevant US authorities. Second, individuals will have access to a number of redress mechanisms to ensure that any complaint will be properly investigated and resolved. Third, we have received written commitments and assurances on the limitations and safeguards when personal data are accessed by US public authorities. This concerns in particular the sensitive area of national security. More specifically, the US Government has assured us that bulk collection will be used only in exceptional circumstances and that even then it applies filters and other technical means to minimise the data collected. We have received an explicit assurance that there is no mass or indiscriminate surveillance. It is the first time we have obtained anything like this from the US side. It is a crucial and central element that makes for a more robust framework than the Safe Harbour ever was. Fourth, as part of the Privacy Shield framework, the US Government will for the first time create an ombudsperson mechanism that will ensure that complaints or enquiries from EU individuals on national security access are addressed in a timely manner. I believe that this too is a major and unprecedented achievement, and again, nothing remotely comparable existed under the old Safe Harbour. This will apply to all transatlantic data transfer be, they under the Shield or under the modes of transfer. Finally, once put in place, the privacy issue will be continuously monitored, in particular through an annual joint review. During this process, we will check that the various oversight and redress mechanisms are operating effectively, and we have formulated clear conditions for suspending our adequacy decision in case commitments are not met by the US or answers given in the annual joint review are not satisfactory. As you know, the independent data protection authorities brought together in the Article 29 Working Party issued their opinion on the Privacy Shield on 13 April. They have welcomed the positive elements in the shield and the improvements compared to the Safe Harbour. But they have also voiced some concerns and recommended further improvements. We take this expertise very seriously, and we are now working on the more critical aspects and are adapting the adequacy decision accordingly. Some of these recommendations can only be addressed in agreement with the US Government, and we are in discussions with them on those points. That includes, for instance, clarifying the independence and functioning of the ombudsperson mechanism and making more explicit the principle of limited data retention. This is an important exercise if we want our data protection authorities, individual consumers and companies to have full confidence in the new arrangement. The Member States support us in this approach, and we trust that our US counterparts also realise the importance of these further clarifications. Once we have reached the necessary qualifications and improvements, we will then submit the draft to the Member States in the Article 31 Committee. Our target remains to have the framework up and running by summer. That brings me to the other important file which will soon be submitted to the European Parliament for its constant: the Umbrella Agreement. This agreement seeks to ensure the protection of personal data exchanged between the EU and the US for the purpose of law enforcement cooperation. The signature of the Umbrella Agreement is expected to take place at the EU-US Justice and Home Affairs Ministerial meeting in Amsterdam on 2 June. Parliament will be asked for its consent before the Council can decide to conclude this agreement. I seek your support for the Umbrella Agreement as it will bring clear improvements to the protection of personal data transmitted in the course of transatlantic law enforcement cooperation compared to today’s situation. As you know, the Umbrella Agreement is not an agreement that authorises data transfers, nor is it an adequacy decision. Rather, it adds the necessary data protection safeguards to existing transfer agreements between the EU or its Member States and the United States or where transfers are carried out based on national law. Many of these existing instruments for law enforcement cooperation with the US have no – or very few – data protection safeguards. This is the unfortunate status quo that the Umbrella Agreement seeks to tackle. Without the Umbrella Agreement, this unsatisfactory situation would continue for many years to come. Where personal data of US persons are transferred to Europe, they already profit from the high level of data protection afforded by other rules, be it at EU or national level. Therefore, the Umbrella Agreement aims at rectifying the existing imbalance of protections on both sides of the Atlantic. This way, the agreement will also restore trust in transatlantic data transfers.

name: Axel Voss
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Minister! Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her A successor to Safe Harbor is urgently needed, and overall I think the Privacy Shield is a big step forward with many improvements. In the end, the political dispute in the House was only about the 'sunset clause' and we actually agreed in the majority not to take over any, and that is why I expect, including the Liberal and S&D colleagues, that the amendments tabled by the Greens and the GUE will not be supported either. In my view, however, a 'sunset clause' is not necessary at all, because we have a strong annual monitoring mechanism, which can then also constantly eliminate the so-called left-overs. It is not necessary because we need a permanent, stable and legally secure framework, nor is it necessary, because that would ultimately make these annual reviews superfluous. I also think that we should wait for this new mechanism to work before it can even be stopped, and in the end it is really just a matter of distrust of the Commission to accompany this procedure sensibly. However, I also believe that the Commission has learned its lessons here. In my opinion, the demand for a data protection shield is also politically ridiculous, because one simply does not want to make a decision, is it enough to have a privacy shield or is not enough, and then you actually have a certain disorientation. However, it is important that we also ensure a certain degree of legal certainty for our companies, SMEs and start-ups, provide concrete frameworks for transatlantic data traffic, and that is why we would support the Privacy Shield. However, if the amendments are included, the PPE-DE will vote against.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her This is a subject that has been a concern for us here for a very long time. In fact, we have discussed Safe Harbour in a wide variety of formations, controversially, and there has always been an uncertainty, which was ultimately resolved only by a citizen's complaint, and this Schrems judgment has gone down in history and shown us that it is very important that we remove uncertainties. The Privacy Shield attempts to eliminate these uncertainties. You presented the guidelines to us in February, and it is clear that progress has been made, that we have also been able to clarify certain things with the American partners, also in accordance with the case law here. I believe, however, that it is still a situation where we still have uncertainties, where we do not really have the great clarity yet, and that, of course, also means the risk of ending up in court again. That would not necessarily be positive for our image as legislators, as executives, and it is not positive for industry either. We – the LIBE Committee – were in the Us last week, and we could see that there is a great understanding of the European position, that there is a will in the United States to updo the principles of jurisprudence. This applies to public authorities as well as to the data industry. I believe that more could have been achieved, but I believe that this resolution lays down the criteria that are very important. We need more clarity, especially when such phrases as 'written assurance' are used, what is the legal nature of this, we need clarity on the ombudsman. This was not so clear as we have seen, and the judicial redress, which is so important, should also be seen from this point of view, whether the phrase 'only for EU citizens' is not enough, because we also have third-country nationals in Europe who are protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights. So these uncertainties need to be removed. It is important that we have these agreements, and the framework agreement is also a great step forward, because we could not have achieved anything on our own. We can only do this together. But I appeal to you to really eliminate these ambiguities, otherwise we will have a new discussion with a new brand, which then somehow means... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, transatlantic data transfer is essential for our economy, security and trade. With the Privacy Shield, we are now achieving an unprecedented level of data protection.  It's a very big step in the right direction. The rights and legal protection of EU citizens when transferring data to the US are greatly improved. However, some political groups and MePs continue to believe that only a copy of European law can suffice. But this is simply not realistic.  The United States is an independent nation and an important strategic ally of the EU, but we must not forget that they are not members of the Union. Of course, the European Commission must look at how the Privacy Shield can offer the highest possible standard. The new rules must also be able to pass a possible test by the Court of Justice, so that our companies and SMEs are not in a situation of legal uncertainty. I and my group strongly believe that it is best for our companies, the European economy and the privacy of EU citizens to have an operational Privacy Shield as soon as possible.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by echoing the last words of Mrs Stevens that we want to have an operational privacy shield as soon as possible. The problem is that this privacy shield is very unlikely to be operational. We are here today thanks to a young man called Max Schrems who was stubborn enough to litigate before the court for many, many years and to do what the EU institutions should have done, namely stand up for the interests of the EU citizens. Because I recall that this House has called repeatedly for the repeal of safe harbour and the Commission did not move, so it took one Austrian student to make sure that safe harbour was repealed. Now I am not the least bit convinced that things like written assurances or an ombudsman or a review are going to do the trick. My doubts are shared and in different wordings by Working Party 29, Working Party 31, the EDPS and various legal experts. So I do not understand why we have to keep repeating the same mistakes over and over again. We have a responsibility and a duty to make good-quality legislation and here it seems to me that the Commission is ready to take a decision knowing that it will not stand up in court. This is not about making political compromises – you know, maybe I could agree with Mr Voss or maybe not – that is all not relevant. There is only one yardstick: is this, yes or no, Schrems-proof? And I am not yet convinced that it is. It is an improvement, it is a step forward, and I am glad that the Commission is willing to discuss further adaptations, but ultimately this is also about the US getting access to a market of 500 million consumers, so they too have an interest in moving. Finally, we did not say anything about the umbrella agreement in the resolution, we will come back to it, but I would really like two things. I would like, first of all, for the European Commission, before we talk about giving consent or anything, to finally declassify the reply it gave to the question of LIBE about the legal status and the scope of the umbrella agreement compared with other legal instruments – really give us this information. This is only a legal assessment, how secret can it be? Secondly, the Commission itself has clearly stated that removing the exemptions to the Privacy Act in the US is a precondition for the umbrella agreement to be valid. We all know that those exemptions are not going to be removed, so can somebody please explain to me how we can realistically expect the umbrella agreement ever to apply – please clarify this for me.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent A "Safe Harbor" doesn't get any better by calling it privacy shield. If you look at this sign, which is supposed to protect our fundamental right, the fundamental right of 500 million people here in the European Union to privacy, this sign turns out to be a sign made of papier-maché, which softens at the first rain. It is a terrible thing that it took a ECJ ruling to overturn Safe Habor. And now, with what it has presented, to the kind applause of the local grand coalition, the Commission is countering this very verdict. Not even the demand for a 'sunset clause' could be won by the majority of this House, that would have been the least. After all, everyone in this area knows very well that the repackaged agreement has no treaty character at all and is not enshrined in law. EU citizens can contact an ombudsman, but as John Kerry personally tells us in Annex III, the Ombudsman will neither confirm nor deny whether anyone is the target of surveillance, nor will he name an appeal. The US government could have ordered an answering machine as an ombudsman! Ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about the fundamental rights of 500 million citizens and it is not acceptable that we should actually sacrifice this with a kowtowing to an all-too-big brother! This must not be the style of enlightened democracies, and I think we should be clear about that.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Commissioner and his team have worked hard to achieve this result on the EU—US Privacy Shield. They have also worked hard to achieve the result on the umbrella agreement and, yes, there is progress. But let us be honest, on the EU-US Privacy Shield: what is in there is no significant improvement on the ground with regard to safe harbour. Yes, several issues have been clarified, but no, the legal system of the United States has not changed, and this is actually what the European Court of Justice has said: the legal system does not provide for adequate safeguards. And yes, we know – let us be honest – that those changes will not come tomorrow. We will not achieve that now. So the question is: while we are lining up all the criticism with regard to the insufficiencies which are out there, do we say: yes, there needs to be renegotiation in the future; yes, there needs to be re-opening of these files, because we are not there? Or are we saying: no, everything is fine, everything serves for adequate safeguards and we just will vote for it and for the future it will stand, although the Court may take it down again? I think that is dishonest. So the only honest action at the moment would be to set a sunset clause to limit the validity, and that is what we are bringing forward for this resolution. I am a bit surprised that the other Groups are not able to accept that. In order to be even more pragmatic on this, we have changed our amendment to a validity of 4 years. That is enough time for a new administration to renegotiate and it is enough time after the application of the Data Protection Regulation to renegotiate. So therefore I ask you all to agree to this.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to whom do the personal data that Europeans transmit in the United States with Google, Facebook or Instagram belong? What guarantees do citizens have that their privacy is not systematically violated? No. In fact, in the United States the government is free to dispose of the data of foreigners as an asset in its possession, which can also be used as it pleases by the secret services for "profiling" and registration. These figures are not a good thing for exchange, they are the lives of our citizens, and the European Court of Justice has reiterated this, tearing up the agreement in force. I would remind you, ladies and gentlemen, that until recently the telephones of this Parliament, our emails, the mobile phones of our presidents were spied on by the Americans, that is respect for the privacy of Europeans. The new data agreement that the Commission wants to sign with the United States does not provide for any truly binding proposals, it is an insult to the Court's ruling and to thousands of citizens who trust the European institutions to protect their privacy, but certainly the Commission does not want problems for TTIP, which will exponentially increase transatlantic data trafficking. I would now like to ask my fellow Members whether these are the preconditions on which they intend to sign it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, one of the greatest risks that the rapid evolution of technology has created in modern man is the interception of personal data from social networking websites and their processing by unauthorised persons. Particularly in the United States, this risk has taken on enormous proportions, because the legislation itself allows our intelligence services, our well-known C.I.A. and the National Security Agency, the NsA, to collect, process and retain such information, many times over a period of more than five years.  Indeed, in the name of the US national interest, these services may collect and process information not only of Americans, but also of nationals of other States, in their own states. In this way, however, human rights are violated, the right to the protection of personal data is violated, e-commerce is made difficult and, moreover, there is legal uncertainty for businesses and individuals.  That is why the European Union must take appropriate measures to ensure that, in the dialogue with the United States on the regulation of the terms of the 'privacy shield', improvements are made to ensure the data protection of European citizens engaged in commercial activities with the United States. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – In this debate today, it has been repeatedly stated that the specific situation of data places outside the protection of data and any legislation and procedures in relation to normal trade in goods, although we know the issue of theft and its consequences in normal trade. Do you believe that there are guarantees in this current convention that the mishandling of data will also fall into the criminal category?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), answer a question with a "blue card". Mr Szanyi, of course sanctions must be imposed, but first all those measures must be taken to prevent us from being diverted in this direction.  So both are required. And trying not to get to this point, but when there's a personal data breach, yes, we have to have sanctions.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: Mr President, transatlantic data flows are the largest in the world. No less than 15 terabytes per second are exchanged between Europe and the United States: extremely important for our economy. Our society is digitising rapidly and it is precisely in this sector that our opportunities for the future lie. The legal vacuum and the uncertainty that arose last year have led to a great deal of unrest. Especially among the 5,000 companies that used the former Safe Harbour rules, but especially small and medium-sized enterprises, the backbone of our economy, which is particularly vulnerable in these situations.  The new Privacy Shield should therefore strike two birds with one stone. On the one hand, of course, to protect the data of our citizens, but on the other hand, and certainly so importantly, to give a piece of legal certainty to our companies that use these transatlantic data flows. I welcome the work that the European Commission has done, the progress that many people here have appreciated today and certainly with commissioner Jourová's commitment today to pay attention to the remaining recommendations of the Working Party 29 in the coming weeks. Our appeal is actually very simple: make sure that this summer there is a good Privacy Shield, which European citizens feel safe with and which businesses can move forward with.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, last week I joined the LIBE Commission delegation to the United States and found a surprising reception of all our interlocutors, especially large technology companies, in relation to the general data protection regulation, recently adopted under pressure from this Parliament, recognising that this is an unparalleled global regulatory framework, through which they will be able to develop activities and offer services with respect for fundamental rights and more legal certainty. These are the parameters for assessing the privacy shield agreed between the Commission and the United States. It is extremely important in this digital age, which is not just a digital economy, to strengthen trust and security in transatlantic data exchanges and to ensure legal certainty for businesses and citizens, based on a robust legal framework, in data protection regimes that are equivalent and less vulnerable to criminal use, which clearly still does not happen in the United States. To that extent, we recognise the important work of the European Commission, from the lead by the Court of Justice in the Maximillian Schrems case, of the previous Safe Harbor regime to negotiate this Privacy Shield and the framework agreement. Nevertheless, serious doubts remain, serious reservations, as to the compatibility with European primary law and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, as required by the Court of Justice. It is worrying that the administrative and judicial means of appeal are excessively complex for an ordinary citizen, and that non-European citizens residing in the European Union are not available to non-European citizens residing in the European Union, and therefore discriminate against their fundamental rights. On the other hand, violations are not penalised sufficiently deterrently.  Like many of our American interlocutors, we also have serious reservations that the Ombudsman does not have a status with the indispensable independence of the administration.  In addition, the current version of the agreement still allows for large-scale, albeit targeted, data collection against criteria of necessity and proportionality prescribed in the European Charter of Fundamental Rights. It is in the interests of the authorities, businesses, European, American and other citizens to create a legal, coherent and stable regime. For this very reason, this Parliament must make reservations, these reservations, calling on the Commission and the United States to implement the recommendations of Working Group 29, to make periodic reviews of the adequacy of this instrument in the light of the new general regulation on data protection and in the light of the decision under the Maximillian Schrems case, and also to pursue the transatlantic dialogue to overcome deficiencies and improve the protection of citizens' rights.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the Union has already adopted several agreements which concern the exchange of information, from the pursuit of money financing terrorist organisations or the passenger name register. The Personal Data Protection Shield will help the economic environment, taking, especially from the shoulders of the small ones, small and medium-sized entrepreneurs who carry out transatlantic affairs, the burden of high bureaucratic costs. At the request of the European Union, the United States has adopted a series of reforms of surveillance programmes prohibiting, inter alia, mass data collection, protecting the privacy and civil liberties of persons outside the United States and guaranteeing legal remedies for Union citizens. We must recognise this progress and implement the provisions of this shield for the protection of personal data as soon as possible. There is a need for an assessment of how this assessment is applied, I am convinced, it will lead to even stronger protection of personal data, but let us start implementing it! We evaluate and make it better, otherwise we have nothing.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, we are voting on this resolution because the Commission is holding talks with the USA regarding the transfer of private citizens’ data. The motion calls for stronger data protection arrangements between the EU and the USA. Commercial companies have contracts with their customers, which include provisions on how their data may be used. Governments have no such contracts and they may enact legislation regarding the use of personal data which does not have the direct consent of its owners. Therefore, governments should treat the use of such data with the greatest respect and utmost caution. There are particular concerns about sharing data with the USA, which has reduced protection of its own citizens’ data under legislation such as the Patriot Act and which is never a respecter of foreign nationals’ rights. Therefore the UK Independence Party’s MEPs will vote against this resolution on the basis that any legislation should remain the prerogative of the democratic nation state.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Do you want transatlantic data transfer or do you not want it? I am convinced that we need the transfer of data to the United States, and we also need legal certainty, on the one hand for our citizens, but also for our companies, especially our small and medium-sized enterprises, which are precisely unable to secure themselves by means of standard contractual clauses or other instruments. The Privacy Shield is of particular importance to them. I would like to congratulate the Commission most warmly. Commissioner, you and your team have been negotiating well and hard over many months. If you compare the result now, I think it is a huge step forward compared to the Safe Harbour Agreement. I would simply like to congratulate you wholeheartedly on this. The Privacy Shield provides data security, it provides procedural safeguards to ensure that the data is handled with caution in the USA as well. At the end of the day, of course, only practice will show how this procedure is to be assessed. That is why I think it is extremely important that annual evaluations should also be carried out here, but not just evaluations: if you get the impression that the data in the United States is not carefully recorded, there are also ways of suspending the procedure. I think you have done a really good job. And if you now take up the proposals and improvements of the Article 29 group – now at the same time or in the course of further evaluations – then this is a good package for our citizens and for our small and medium-sized industry.

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we must recognise the steps that our American partners have taken over the last few years in improving protection for data flowing from the EU to the US in direct response to concerns arising, in particular within this Parliament. The US Congress and Administration have enacted more than two dozen reforms to surveillance laws and programmes such as the Privacy Shield and the Judicial Redress Acts, among others. As such, my Conservative colleagues and I see this debate as an opportunity for us all to welcome these efforts, which give added legal clarity for businesses and consumers alike. We must take this progress into trade negotiations such as TTIP and TISA, where setting benchmarks for data protection should increase confidence on both sides. Investment across the Atlantic is already worth around USD 4 trillion, and the steps the Americans have taken to ensure legal reciprocity, data protection and legal redress for EU citizens will help to boost this even further.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her We are therefore talking about the exchange of data with the USA or data protection for this data with the USA. The Commission is currently negotiating a new agreement on this, because there was a court ruling from the European Court of Justice that only a citizen had to dispute: a citizen had to find out that data protection in the United States is not guaranteed, that was not the Commission's initiative! We are extremely concerned that you are actually taking the interests correctly. Everything I have heard from you today has not really made me confident. You said that the United States has promised us, we have been assured, you hope so, you want to. I believe that if, in the end, we do not have an agreement that gives citizens enforceable and enforceable rights, then the whole agreement will not be worth as much as this beautiful ballpoint pen.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: –  Madam Commissioner, thank you very much to you and your team for an excellent job, and I think that now we are getting to the end of the story, which means that we will have a privacy shield.  We are all aware of the importance of data and transnational data flows in the modern economy. To ensure a right solution for transnational data flow is especially important for SMEs that have less legal and investment possibilities and which will be the important beneficiaries of such an instrument. I believe that we need the Privacy Shield to ensure that our data-driven economy grows, especially supporting SMEs. I believe that it is a good approach to rebuild the transatlantic trust and strengthen the data protection rights on both sides of the Atlantic. The presented instrument introduces many improvements to the protection of fundamental rights. Among others, it strengthens Member States’ data protection authorities’ role in the process of claims investigations. The legal remedies are strengthened for EU citizens and residents also by the creation of an ombudsperson, and it would work on both sides of the Atlantic. Americans also change their legislation and their attitude. What is now needed is to make sure that these legal remedies are really available to EU citizens and residents as well as the regular review of the implementation of the Privacy Shield. I see the role of the European Commission, EDPS and data protection authorities for this task.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would also like to welcome the progress of the discussions on the exchange of personal data between the European Union and the United States. The United States is europe's natural, positive partner, and these talks need to be based on trust, not suspicion. I am pleased with these decisions, including those preliminary decisions, with institutional ideas, with the redress mechanism. I think that we should ensure a maximum level of protection of personal data in this agreement, but at the same time guided by the principle of rationality. I have the impression that often the right to privacy is interpreted at the level of abuse, which is often at odds with other goods. In the area of security in particular, the right to privacy cannot be interpreted to prevent the protection of the security of our citizens, the security of Europe, the United States and the transatlantic community.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in previous speeches in relation to geoblocking, I have highlighted the stimulus coming from the important decision of the Court of Justice of 6 October 2015.  The new regulatory port for transatlantic data flows seems to have taken up this challenge, in order to ensure the protection of personal data and the development of business activities, but the basic reflection is that in the inert ities of the agreements with the United States, there has long been an injury to the fundamental principles of individuals, in the collection of private data flows and in the unconscious control of their lives. We must therefore enforce the strict obligations imposed by companies on the personal data of European citizens and the monitoring of compliance with these obligations, but first of all we must highlight the transparency obligations borne by the United States, with truly effective redress procedures. In this huge amount of sensitive data stolen, it is impossible to exercise effective national domestic control and, in the event of a possible infringement, the role of the Commission, which I hope does not wait for the Court of Justice again, remains emphasised.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the protection of data and privacy is a fundamental right of the citizens of the Union and every measure must be taken into account so that it is not infringed.  With regard to transatlantic data flows, the European Union and the United States have signed an agreement on privacy protection and legal certainty for businesses in the event of a transfer of data from the Union to the USA.  Of course, as defined under the new regulation, US public authorities are supposed to have access to personal data and do so, supposedly, under restrictions and under supervision, so that there is no generalised access.  At the same time, Europeans should have the right to request an investigation or to file complaints in the event of a breach of their personal data.  However, it is necessary to specify the cases of access by US public authorities to personal data and to strike a balance of security and freedom. Data protection in any transatlantic flow should be protected and not subject to the aspirations of the United States security services.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, would it be good if there was no transatlantic flow of data? Can this Parliament or should it oppose the existence of such a flow, which, by the way, is massive? Certainly not. But it must require that such traffic, that flow, be regulated by law and, therefore, the Commission has done its job of trying to agree and negotiate nothing less than with the United States a privacy shield, a privacy shield that does not fall from the sky, because it follows a strong judgment of the Court of Justice, which precisely overreulled the safe harbor agreement on the basis of the claim brought in the Schrems case. But doubts persist, and it is very important that we keep our guard very high to ensure the adequacy of this new privacy shield agreement with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. And here the annual review clause is of enormous importance for the Commission to monitor the exact compliance with the limitation and supervision guarantees offered by the US State Department to secure the fundamental rights of the European Union, and, in the event of non-compliance, to act before we have to attend a new strong and annulling judgment of the agreement of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, in the past many judgments of the European Court of Justice have been in the sphere of judicial activism and have served as a basis for depriving Member States of their jurisdiction. I must admit that I have been quite skeptical since then, but this ruling served as a good trigger for amending a somewhat outdated regulation that did not ensure the highest level of data protection and in this sense I am satisfied. Privacy Shield offers a full range of guarantees that the rights of our citizens will be respected on the other side of the Atlantic. Of particular importance, I consider the involvement of the US Ombudsperson to oversee complaints from European citizens and the introduction of a new mandatory 45-day deadline within which companies will have to deal with citizen complaints. I believe that our citizens will be satisfied that for the first time clearer restrictions have been placed on us institutions when accessing data, and there is a commission's control of the implementation of the system that will report on everything to this house. Significant progress has been made and we absolutely support that.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, I have no doubt about the Good Intentions of the Commission, I have no doubt about your good intentions, Mrs. Jurova, and I cannot help but say that, of course, what is being proposed to us and what you have presented to us is a kind of progress.  Let me also express a little doubt about the ultimate success of what is to be achieved. Safe harbor, later Privacy Shield, and the call for acceptance of umbrella agreements are good ideas, and even the names are very creative. We must say that those who want to get our data, those who want to harm our privacy are also extremely creative and can get our data. Unfortunately, I have no doubt that today who knows who does not know everything about me, probably everything about you, Mrs. Sophia in't Veld, Mr. Schultz, Mr. Juncker. Unfortunately, I have no doubt about that and I don't know when we will successfully prevent it until the end.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Honourable Members very much for this discussion. It is always very important that that we hold it and it is also inspiring for the Commission, both for myself and my colleagues. You are right that the flow of data from the European Union to the United States is really massive. We needed to come forward soon with the new system which will protect the data of European citizens, not because of big companies which have this data flow as a basis for their business, but, as has been mentioned here several times, it was also in the interests of European small and medium—sized enterprises, for which it was a real disaster that they appeared in legal uncertainty. This is just the circumstance which we had to take into account when we worked on this issue after the court ruling – and also before, of course. We needed strong assurances from our American counterparts. We needed to achieve legal certainty and to put an end to uncertainties where the companies were in a very difficult situation. During the negotiations I called our situation and the way we wanted to conclude these negotiations ‘trust and check’. We need to have elementary trust towards our American partners that they will comply with their own laws and that they will do what they have committed themselves to in the official letters signed at the highest possible level. I will share with you today that I cannot say that that Privacy Shield, as a mechanism to protect EU citizens’ data in the United States, is perfect. It cannot be perfect and I will never be totally satisfied with it, because there were objective reasons why we could not achieve more. One is the matter of the American legal order, which Mr Albrecht very rightly pointed out here. We do not have any power to change legislation in the United States, but we will keep monitoring developments in this field in the United States and we have expressed many times our conviction that the data will be better protected in America if they have the proper data protection law. We cannot do much more. The second objective, where we could not do more, is access to data for national security purposes. Look at the situation in Europe. Here the Commission and the European Union does not have any power to ask the secret services to be more transparent and to inform people whether they are using their data or not. Not even the Member States can do that. Certainly we wanted a similar thing when we negotiated the conditions in the United States. So these were our limits. I must say very openly that we are not fully satisfied, but we are satisfied in the sense that we achieved the maximum which was possible. But what is more important is that we must not be satisfied for the future. Satisfaction must not be our leading principle for the years to come, because the Commission has committed itself – I have committed myself and my colleagues – to monitor on a continuous basis what is happening in the United States. We will do it in a very transparent way through the annual reviews, where we expect all who are to contribute to input the trustworthy data showing the illustration of the situation as it stands, both in the United States and in the European Union. I think that this annual review and the very strong suspension clause is quite a strong safeguard and strong measure. I am convinced that we do not need any sunset clause, as has been proposed here. Mrs Sophie in 't Veld is absolutely right that the Schrems ruling helped us. I am sorry we waited for it from the moment when we knew that this has been lodged at the court, because we were already convinced before the ruling that the decision would give us proper arguments and proper benchmarks, which will help us negotiate this stronger position. I must say that it helped in the negotiations and we very precisely took article by article in the Schrems ruling and we renegotiated in a very tough way with the American partners, referring to the court decision. I cannot be sure that the new court ruling will not be as strict as the previous one, but I am confident that we tailored the Privacy Shield system on the requirement of the court. So again, we did our best. On the Umbrella Agreement, I do not know about a situation where we would keep some something secret. There were many written questions, which we answered, to the members of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). I would like to ask you again not only for your support for the Privacy Shield but also for the Umbrella Agreement because, as I said in my opening speech, this is a real improvement in the protection of data in the exchange between law enforcement authorities. We should take into very serious consideration that this is also about the data of witnesses and victims of criminal offences, and this plays an important role in the strengthening of cooperation between the EU and the US in criminal justice and security matters, because we all know that the security situation is worsening and that we will have to do everything we can to have better, swifter and safer cooperation between the law enforcement authorities in the United States and the European Union. So I would like to ask you again for your support.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, Ladies and Gentlemen. First of all, thank you very much for this debate, and thank you to the Commission for your clarification about the Privacy Shield and the further planning. I think this debate makes clear that smooth data flows can never mean uncontrolled and unchecked data flows. The basis of data flows should always be the trust of our citizens that the data are being used in a just and prudent way both in Europe and the United States. And if a citizen has the feeling that this is not the case, he or she should be able to object to this use. At the same time we know – and I think that many Members have expressed this today – the enormous importance of smooth data flows for governments, companies and American and European citizens, who are reaping the benefits of this. It means companies are being enabled to operate more effectively and efficiently on the European and American side of the Atlantic, and therefore we are talking about a very important issue. It also means we will be able to fight crime more effectively and increase the security of both our continents. So we have to see to what extent this can all benefit us, and I think the proposal that has been made is therefore so important. First, on the Umbrella Agreement. I think – and I refer to many questions that were asked on this – it is important to say that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data, it only supplements other agreements with a common set of data protection safeguards. I think that is very important. Finally, as you know, the agreement can be suspended in cases where the parties do not live up to it. So that is important. A few questions were raised on the ombudsperson. I think also here we have to underline the fact that the ombudsperson is an additional mechanism compared to other systems. So, in itself, it is not sufficient legal protection. It will not replace more substantive forms of legal protection, and I believe that it is a step forward that the United States has been willing to create this mechanism and trust that the handling of complaints submitted will be conducted in a proper manner. I would like to point out that the ombudsperson does not fulfil its position in isolation but, as stated in Annex III, works in cooperation with the internal regulators of the agencies who will need to provide information and answer questions. I would say that also many EU Member States provide for an ombudsperson-type oversight on intelligence activities in our countries. I think, correctly, it was pointed out that the arrest was, if you wish, a catalyst for something that is, I think, a very improved deal. The Court was important; it reminded us that an essentially equivalent level of data protection in a third country can only be met if government access to the third country meets the standards of necessity and proportionality. If a third country allows for massive and indiscriminate collection of data, the standards are not met, and in this case the representations by the various US government officials clearly indicated that the US has adopted laws and policies combined with a system of oversight and redress possibilities in order to avoid the massive and indiscriminate collection of data. The main rule is: targeted collection of data, bulk collection, is secondary, and bulk collection, if based on a proper legal standard and with sufficient safeguards to protect the rights and interests of data subjects, is acceptable, since it is not massive and indiscriminate collection of data. Then about the ‘sunset clause, I do not want to repeat; I agree with what has been said by the Commissioner. I know it is a big point of discussion also in your Parliament. I agree in this case with Mr Voss that we do not need such a sunset clause, since there is a strong element of annual review and monitoring foreseen in the agreement. Finally, I would say that we deem that the Privacy Shield and the Umbrella Agreement offer the safeguards needed to justify our citizens’ trust. We hope, therefore, also, that the European Parliament will consider all the positive aspects. It is also true here to say that the better is the enemy of the good. It is important that we can now make progress on this; it is important for our citizens and our businesses – EU citizens in particular – when consent is given, hopefully to the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Data flows between the EU and the US are the most intense in the world and are an essential element in trade relations, especially for US multinationals. In October 2015, the European Court of Justice invalidated the Safe Harbour decision by ruling that national supervisory authorities can assess the adequacy of the level of protection guaranteed by a third country and in the event of suspending the transfer of data. The Commission has thus drafted a new decision, known as the 'Privacy Shield' in order to ensure respect for the privacy and personal data of European citizens. This decision, however, does not guarantee an adequate level of protection and protection of the fundamental right to the protection of personal data. In the USA, in fact, the data of foreigners are nothing more than a good that can be used as best you believe without any respect for privacy. Also think of the intense and pervasive activities carried out by the American intelligence services, as revealed by Edward Snowden. Our task is to protect citizens from abuse, and with this de facto text we are legalising any kind of use of sensitive European data by the US.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Transatlantic data flows between EU and US intensify rapidly with every year. Since the European Court of Justice ruled the previous Safe Harbour as inoperative, we should aim to create a new ambitious framework for secure data exchange. I support EC position that EU- US Privacy Shield should impose stronger obligations to U.S. companies. U.S. should completely abstain from indiscriminate mass surveillance, it should commit itself to more transparency and as well to a better cooperation with European Data Protection Authorities. EU Privacy Shield has to serve the interests of EU citizens and European companies. Any access by U.S. public authorities to personal data must be a subject to clear safeguards.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Agreeing on a new framework for transatlantic data flows is of paramount importance for EU-US trade and investment. As a result of the digitisation of our economies, data transfer is becoming increasingly important for bilateral economic relations, contributing to economic growth and competitiveness. Businesses on both sides of the Atlantic need legal certainty to operate, and European citizens need to be given privacy guarantees and redress options. I believe that the new agreement must fulfil these requirements and create a clear and robust legal framework that ensures effective protection of privacy and data protection. It is important that the implementation of the commitments is closely monitored in order to restore trust between transatlantic partners. This could provide momentum and contribute to positive dynamics in bilateral relations and other areas of cooperation, strengthening the EU-US transatlantic link and supporting efforts to address common global challenges.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – Following the Designation of Safe Harbour as invalid, the European Commission has proposed a new data flow regime between the US and the EU, dubbed the Privacy Shield, following the European Court of Justice's designation of Safe Harbour. It is understandable that legal certainty must be provided for business between the US and the EU, but this must not happen at the expense of fundamental rights, which, unfortunately, is not reprehensible in the Privacy Shield. Furthermore, the Privacy Shield does not respect the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, such as Schrems, Data Retention and Google Spain, and the enforcement of the contract is quite challenging, as data must go through five successive procedures. The fact that, because of lower requirements compared to EU data protection law, the agreement gives a comparative advantage to US companies. I believe that there is also the possibility that the agreement will be found invalid in the future, just as it did in the case of the Safe Harbour agreement. For all these reasons, it seems reasonable to me to introduce a sunset clause which, after a few years, would require renegotiation and the signing of the agreement, which would allow it to be improved.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - The economies of the European Union and the United States account for more than 50% of global GDP, 25% of global exports and more than 30% of global imports. These are two of the world's most lucrative economies with a total value of transatlantic turnover in 2014 of one trillion dollars.  The flow of data between the United States and the European Union is about 15 thyrabites per second, representing by far the largest data flow in the world. I believe that the free flow of data between the EU and the US is essential for trade and investment growth, as transatlantic transactions and services between companies have become a reality, and consumers on both sides of the Atlantic are increasingly using the internet to buy goods and services. Internet access in the US has 85% of the population and 90% in the European Union.  The Internet is available everywhere in the world, and I am confident that a resolution on transatlantic data flows will open up the possibility for the European Union to expand trade and invest in developing countries. That is why I believe that there will be a growth in online international trade as well as the need for free flow of data. I see this resolution as a step forward in that direction.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. –   Madam President, honourable Members, once again we have on our agenda the sensitive issue of endocrine disruptors, and specifically the setting of final criteria to identify these substances in the context of the Biocidal Products Regulation. As you will remember, during the plenary session on 2 February I made a commitment to present before the summer final scientific criteria for the identification endocrine disruptors. So I can reiterate that the Commission has a very firm intention to comply with this obligation and with the judgment of the Court.  I stand by this commitment and I can only again confirm that the two draft measures are an issue which will be on the College’s agenda on 15 June. The criteria to be presented will be specified objectively and based on scientific evidence. This was not only reiterated by President Jean-Claude Juncker in a letter sent in March to President Martin Schulz, but also repeated by myself at several public occasions.  As honourable Members will know, two separate draft measures will be presented simultaneously. As soon as the College endorses these two draft measures, they will be published on the Commission’s website so as to ensure maximum transparency.  Madam President, honourable Members, it is our collective responsibility to make informed decisions in the full awareness of all the consequences of our choices. I therefore hope that together we will adopt the best decision on this very important matter. I would like to say that I have kept it very brief. Thank you, and I will listen to your debate.

name: Alojz Peterle
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – Protecting citizens from health threats is one of the three strategic objectives of the European Union's health policy, and we must put hormonal disruptors in the prevention centre. In the area of health, where we can bring a relationship closer to our citizens, only consistent action by the Commission is necessary and permissible.  The increased incidence of chronic diseases, including cancers associated with hormones such as breast cancer and prostate cancer, and the increased number of diabetic patients and reproductive problems obliges us to act.  All the more so because the hormonal disruptors we associate with all of the above have great potential for irreversible effects, and the cost of treatment is estimated at a high of €150 billion a year. Given the fact that, for a number of reasons, the health coffers are already limited, preventive action at union level is necessary and economically justified.  At yesterday's meeting of the Working Party on Health, we again heard scientific confirmation of the harmfulness of certain chemical substances, which are not only used in agriculture, all the more so if they combine or if exposure is long-lasting. I therefore very much regret the length of time in this case, which has also been condemned by the European Court of Justice. However, I believe that time has been spent wisely and well spent to bring the diversity of views closer together, to formulate criteria, and that, Commissioner, you have played an active role in this. Preventive activities are, of course, crucial for more health and sustainable health systems, and in the circumstances in the circumstances, a functioning Commission is particularly needed. I therefore expect you to overturn the motion of censure by submitting the long-awaited criteria within the forecast deadline, that is, by the summer. And thank you for the answer you've actually given.

name: Jytte Guteland
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you, Commissioner, for the announcement today and the statement before the June meeting. I'm happy about that. I am also pleased to see the opportunity to talk about scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors.  But I would like to remind you of the history we have. This is one of the more striking cases where EU law has been deliberately ignored and disregarded for other interests. For more than two years, the Commission has completely ignored the presentation of scientific criteria, although since December 2013 it has been obliged to present them. We must have these criteria. They are necessary to enable us to continue our work and phase out hazardous chemicals. I'll be clear in case the message hasn't gone through. It is unacceptable to ignore obligations imposed by the Commission under EU law. European citizens, the European Parliament, eu countries and the Court of Justice expect the Commission to respect its duty through the Eu Treaty, to promote the health of its citizens, and these are not trifles we are talking about.  Endocrine disruptors are all around us. They are found in food packaging, in our children's toys, in our clothes, in our drinking water, and they are linked to a wide range of diseases. Diabetes, various cancers and problems with fertility, and it is particularly ominous that young children and fetuses are particularly sensitive to these chemicals, the effects of which may manifest themselves much later in life. It is therefore to be welcomed that the Commission has now signalled that it will finally discuss the scientific criteria in the College in mid-June. The Commission can be sure that there are many of us who will follow that meeting closely, and I would urge the Commission here to take account of the European Parliament's previous positions on the criteria.  Led by the S&D Group, Parliament has repeatedly strongly opposed the Commission's proposal to introduce potency as a demarcating criterion for the definition of endocrine disruptors. Such a demarcation would unduly limit the definition of endocrine disruptors and make it scientifically deficient and therefore incompatible with the classification of carcinogenic, mutagenic or toxic to reproduction.  The fact that potency is not allowed to become a guiding factor in the criteria is a key issue, not only for us in the S&D Group and the European Parliament, but also for many Member States. I would therefore like to emphasise once again very clearly to the Commission that we will not accept such a model. Among the options analysed is the roadmap published by the Commission in 2014. At that time, the possibilities of an alternative without potency were highlighted as a criterion. I would urge the Commission to follow that road map. At the same time, I am now hopeful that there is a good chance that the Commission is doing the right thing and presenting these criteria that provide the highest possible level of protection for human health.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Madam President, I should like to thank the Commissioner for his opening remarks. The Commissioner has accepted the December court ruling and has publicly committed to hastening the adoption of the criterion. I welcome that. In addition, we have legal advice from Parliament’s services which has acknowledged that taking further action against the Commission would be superfluous given that, as soon as the criteria are published, there would no longer be a case.  So I look forward to the work that we will begin in June when we see the criteria. I would just like to take this opportunity to restate my own position, which is that these criteria must be scientifically robust and fit for regulatory purpose. They need to ensure that human health and the environment are protected, taking into account the possible consequences for the agri-food sector and the need to encourage innovation and the development of new plant protection solutions. Parliament must be serious about supporting the Commission’s initiatives on better regulation and improved evidence-based policy making. Then we should let it complete its work and save our energy for the evaluation and decision making that will follow.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Madam President, when I was elected to this Parliament in 2009, I really did not expect to end up in this debate that we are having tonight, a debate in which I have to call upon the Commission, the guardian of the Treaty for the European Union, to respect a ruling of the European Court of Justice and to comply with it.  Let me quote from the legal opinion from the Parliament’s Legal Service, which is really crystal clear – and be aware that people from the Legal Service are the most cautious people on planet Earth, and when they are so crystal clear, there is really something there. Let me quote: ‘There is no doubt that, to date, the Commission has not yet taken the measures required under Article 266 of the Treaty in order to comply with the General Court’s judgment.’  That is more than crystal clear. Simply, the Commission is not complying with the Court’s ruling. So when the Commissioner starts his statement with: ‘Once again we are discussing this topic’, this is not because we as Parliament want to continuously discuss this. It is because the Commission is refusing to comply with the Court’s ruling – the Court’s ruling that was crystal clear in saying that no impact assessment of the social and economic consequences was necessary before the independent scientific criteria would be set.  In the correspondence between President Juncker and President Schulz, President Juncker was still talking about the necessity to first finalise this impact assessment. Commissioner, can you please assure us that the Commission is not going to firstly finalise this impact assessment before setting these scientific criteria? European Union citizens are losing trust in the European Union. So the last thing we need is a European Commission that is not even complying with the Court’s rulings.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, hormone disruptors are everywhere. They sit in cans of cans, in plastic bottles, in cosmetics, in receipts and on sprayed fruits and vegetables. And it can make you very sick: breast cancer, testicular cancer, fertility problems. This is just a sampling of all the ailments you can get from it.  Just this week, doctors sounded the alarm because of these substances in medical devices, such as infusions and respiratory hoses. Children can get sick of this for the rest of their lives.  The European Commission is structurally refusing to remove these sickeners from the market, deliberately putting the health of 500 million citizens at risk. In doing so, she is ignoring her own laws and is flotiling a ruling by the European Court. That's a big scandal.  My group has today agreed to a resolution on endocrine disruptors, but as far as I am concerned this Commission needs a much stronger signal. As far as I am concerned, this Commission would not have been here after today either.  This Commission is in reserve time. If the Commission does not act immediately, I guarantee you that there will be another vote of no confidence before this summer. And I assume that the Greens, the Social Democrats and all the others who say they care about public health are not looking the other way. I have a clear message to you, Commissioner: you will not get away with this. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Madam President, the Commissioner said: ‘Here we are again’, as if we like being here again. The point is that, after several discussions we are having on the issue of endocrine disruptors, Commissioner, you continue to say: ‘We are working on an impact assessment’ and every time when we criticise, you say: ‘But the impact assessment…’.  It is not that we are against an impact assessment; the point is, for this required action of the Commission, an impact assessment is not required. And every time you then replied: ‘But what is wrong, are you against an impact assessment?’.  You were always dodging the issue and therefore we asked for another legal opinion. There is a very clear Court ruling saying the Commission is not complying with its own rules. So we asked again for a legal opinion – my colleague Gerbrandy has already quoted from it, so I will take some other quotes just to make it very clear once more: ‘The General Court rejected the Commission's argument that an impact assessment was required’. It has been rejected! And still the spokesperson of the Commission back in December, in response to the General Court's ruling, was saying: ‘We are continuing, we are on track for the impact assessment’. In the letter from Mr Juncker to Mr Schulz, he was also pointing out that: ‘We are here, working on an impact assessment’. And the conclusion from the Legal Service – and that is indeed the same conclusion that Mr Gerbrandy was noting – is that the Commission has not yet taken the measures required under the Treaty.  That is why we are discussing this here again. We want scientific criteria. You are still not delivering on that. That they will be coming in June, it does not matter, you are too late with that, but you are still using the argument that an impact assessment is needed. We think you are ill-advised by your advisers. But it is really crucial to say this: we have to make sure that the Commission is following the rules.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: "blue card" question. I have a blue card for Mrs Bas Eickhout.  I would like to know under what circumstances the Green Group would be prepared to support a motion of censure. What must happen for the Green Group to support a motion of censure? Because it seems to me that there are all the circumstances, it seems strange that you did not support it.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. –  I knew this question would be coming. The point now is that we will get a proposal from the Commission, and then we will have to have a fight on what scientific criteria will be there. For example potency, which all the scientists say is not a scientific criterion – a good reason not to have it in. Will it not be in?  That is a fight that is really about the safety of our citizens. That is the fight we still need to have. So, before we make all kind of symbolic changes, let us first make sure that the right criteria are out there. That is the most important concern of the Greens, and I hope that we can have that fight together, so that we are sure that the right scientific criteria are there. After that discussion let us see what the Commission does.

text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe, first of all, that we should explain to our citizens that endocrine disruptors are harmful substances, particularly for the health of our children during the age of development. name: Mireille D'Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, endocrine disruptors are a serious and widespread structural threat to people's health, as our citizens come into contact with these substances on a daily basis. That is why such a subject deserves the European institutions, which have regulatory and regulatory powers, to take real responsibility. And in this, the Commission has failed in its task. On the one hand, the reasonable period between the publication of the regulation and that of the delegated acts is not respected. However, neither institutional complexity nor the need for impact assessment is acceptable to justify such a delay in the face of the importance of the health issue. I also point out that, while the European Regulation is directly applicable throughout the Union, the Commission gives itself the luxury of hanging out to publish delegated acts. This is an illustration of regulatory opacity. It is good to want to legislate better, but it must be applied to oneself. On the other hand, the seriousness of the danger requires that there be no debate on the assessment method and that one does not wait for clear evidence to act. Worse still, using an impact study to try to define criteria for endocrine disruptors before the publication of delegated acts is a diversion from regulatory authority. The Commission therefore avoids its responsibilities and the disclosure of its true intentions. It also contributes to the deterioration of the sense of decision-making, the lack of transparency at the very source of regulation and the dispersion of power. The Commission has committed serious and serious misconduct and yet appears to be ignoring the requests of the Court of Justice. However, the motion of censure was a strong political act to punish the Commission. No, Dear Lamberts, this is not a disproportionate tool, it is part of the rules of power and, today, I have the impression that some unlucky groups want to get out of this case, where Parliament would be very complicit in the Commission for its inaction. We want clear answers from the Commission on these criteria and faults.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D).
text: - Commissioner, it has taken three years, we will finally see it. Personally, I am so glad that you brought us the news today that you will keep your word from February this year. I am very happy and looking forward to working together.  However, the European Commission, not you personally, at first did not respect the obligations arising from the regulation on the supply of biocides to the market. She didn't present what she had three years ago. Then the European Commission did not respect the decision of the European Court, special. The Commission has cast itself as guardian of the Treaties, so there are a few questions: 1) Why did the Commission decide not to respect the judgment of the European Court of Justice and completed or worked to complete the European impact study instead of presenting the criteria as requested by the Judgment of the Court of First Judgment? 2) Who is responsible for this decision?
