name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Madam President, the European Parliament continues to insist on the same thing. The scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors must be established. Health, believe me, is at the top of the priority list for every citizen. The problem is therefore becoming more and more common, and understandable: many studies link the increase in cancer cases, diabetes, obesity and infertility to exposure to endocrine disruptors, among others. In February, you promised that the Commission would come forward with proposals before the summer. That summer that started almost in May, so goes the lyrics of a popular Dutch song. I've listened carefully to you, it's going to be mid-June. Okay, that's just before the start of the real summer and the longest day of the year. But at least it's five to twelve. name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Let's summarize the facts, and I will add a few more facts to what we just heard from our colleagues here. Endocrine distruptors cause cancer, have an impact on fertility, even affect obesity. Even if I think of the thousands of people who kill these substances every year, which I cannot, the economic impact of exchasing people in the EU alone should be twice as high as the impact of mercury and lead pollution. I understand that you have strong support here in Parliament, but you must realise that, as a result of these criteria, we here in Parliament need to address the reauthorisation of dangerous substances such as phthalates, glyphosate, etc., the salami method, ad hoc objections, to play detectives and scientists in order to protect the health of the European population at least a little. I don't think you or we are worthy of it. We all have to start doing something together, and you do.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: –  Madam President, seven years ago this Parliament gave the Commission a legally binding mandate to come up with the endocrine disruptor criteria before 2013. So this deadline passed three years ago but the list is still not ready, and the General Court has stated that the Commission is currently in breach of EU law.  Both old and new inter-institutional agreements clearly say that impact assessments are not a substitute for political decisions. They must not lead to undue delays in the law-making process. But still the Commission is neglecting its duties and is tinkering with an impact assessment, thus violating both the inter-institutional agreement and the treaties when doing so.  Could the Commission, by the way, confirm if it is true that it was the TTIP negotiations, and the US negotiating position, that actually made the drafting of endocrine disruptor criteria so inconvenient? I hope that this is not true, because I would find it unbearable if the Commission is ignoring the Court decision for the interests of the US industries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, more than two years late and after a conviction by the Court of Justice of the European Union, the new criteria for defining endocrine disruptors should soon be made public, at least hopefully. The whole debate on scientific criteria is about one term: industry is calling for the 'power' criterion to be included in the legislation, while interest groups and the public are clasps calling for it to be excluded. There are substances whose potency as endocrine disruptors is low, but which have very high daily exposure – for example, pesticides – and there are other compounds, on the other hand, which have very high potency, but which are in very low concentrations, to such an extent that human health would be less affected. Allowing low-potency endocrine disruptors to be marketed would be very serious, as it would be risky for exposure to them that turns them into deadly poisons. I am therefore strongly opposed to the Commission's attempts to introduce the power criterion for defining endocrine disruptors, which would inappropriately limit the definition of 'endocrine disruptors', making it scientifically inconsistent and incompatible with the classification of carcinogens.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, we have not heard much from the Commission about endocrine disruptors, and we are very concerned about this. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that interfere with the hormonal system and cause fertility disorders, cause neoplasms and various cancers.  These substances are found in many products used daily by consumers, but they do not even know they exist in these products. They are found in toys, in food, even in water. Two years have already passed, Commissioner, of the Commission's complete inaction in taking measures to protect the public health of European consumers, although it should have done so.  Measures must therefore be taken to authorisation and restrictions on these substances in products. name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened closely to the debate and have taken careful note of your views. First of all, my simple answer about responsibility: I am responsible. Please tell me if I am wrong. I am responsible, I am honest and I will continue my job with responsibility, yes, because I am responsible for the Commission being in delay. Is that enough? Is it clear? Second, I would like to mention about scientific opinions. You mentioned scientists in common positions, speaking about potency and other things. Now, it was my intention to invite different scientists, to organise several debates, and then to organise a platform and today they have a common position. Of course in this position many issues are on the table.  Some of you raised questions about the issue that the Commission is in delay. Yes, of course. We started with a roadmap, with four options. It started with possibilities to deal with, how to describe and define, final scientific criteria. Interim scientific criteria are in place and you know this very well. And the Commission follows interim criteria. Some of you spoke about how to regulate. All things related to the Plant Protection Regulation and the Biocidal Products Regulation are under Commission supervision and we follow interim criteria, and our consumers are protected in this area. We must tell the truth to our society but not feed fear. We need scientific criteria, not politically-based criteria. It is completely different. In my hands is the document about those chemicals from 2012. You know it very well. It is a very good summary, a very good study, which shows how it is important. As you know, my professional background is as a medical doctor. I am very much interested in endocrine disruptors criteria. I know much more related to some problems which were just mentioned.  OK, we will keep in mind that we need very scientific and very reasonable criteria. Of course some of you mentioned the impact assessment. The impact assessment is one thing. But I started to debate about how to describe final criteria and it takes time. Two parallel processes were together, and of course an impact assessment helps us to make very informed decisions. This is also OK. I fully agree with the Court’s decision. Absolutely. But the Court was not against the impact assessment. The Court decision was very clear. Despite the impact assessment, despite different scientific opinion, the Commission must present final criteria. Of course the Commission was in delay, and we are ready to do our best and to present those criteria to you on 15 June once again.  And then it will be good to have not politically-based arguments but scientifically-based ones and I am ready to debate scientifically. And of course it has nothing to do with TTIP, absolutely. This is also a political argument to feed a lobby, industrial fears and so on, but it is not serious. The serious argument is that it is a very complex job. It is very difficult speaking about WHO scientists, about different scientific bodies, it is not so easy to present those criteria, and I am ready to do my best and present those criteria, of course, in line with the Biocidal Products Regulation and in line with the Pesticide Protection Regulation.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. On 16 December, the European Commission was condemned for failing to propose a definition of endocrine disruptors. However, this definition is essential for regulation. Present in many phytosanitary and food products, these molecules are at the origin of many health problems. It was the Commission's duty to protect the health of Europeans; it preferred to defend the interests of the industrial lobbies.  In response to this breach, a motion of censure against the Commission had been tabled and unfortunately failed. Only this motion was likely to put pressure on the Commission. But instead, we are being offered a resolution, with no binding value. It's an attempt to smoke. For those who have not asked for censorship, it is a question of making Europeans believe that they are concerned about public health. Patriotic MPs will not participate in this charade.  This resolution is a bad communication operation for the gullible. Meanwhile, nothing is being done to protect the health of Europeans.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Court of Justice of the EU considered that the European Commission infringed Community law by not respecting the deadline for publishing marketing standards for harmful chemicals such as bisphenol A, pesticides or solvents. The court's ruling does not include a fine, but requires that the document relating to scientific criteria to determine the harmfulness of so-called endocrine disruptors be adopted as soon as possible.  At the root of the decision is the case opened by Sweden against the Commission, which should have adopted the rules by the end of 2013. Two years behind schedule reported by several European associations that speak of a public health problem, when endocrine disruptors will be the source of various diseases such as cancers or even increased infertility. This is another sign of the interests that are defended by these institutions.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, it is hard to imagine a single market where public services are not available across borders, but it seems that new digital borders are appearing at about the same time that the EU’s physical borders have disappeared. The European Commission, Parliament and the Member States have been working to correct this. Together we have enacted legislation on electronic identities and signatures: e-ID, e-procurement, and of course the Connecting Europe Facility for digital service infrastructure. All of them will help to remove these digital barriers. It is now time to utilise this joint work so that we create a new generation of eGovernment services that will help to create growth and jobs, the digital single markets and to rebuild people’s trust in governments. It was with this objective in mind that the European Commission presented its eGovernment Action Plan in April. This plan can be the political instrument to advance the digital transformation of public administrations across the European Union. It will address the problems faced by people, businesses and public administrations through the strategic objectives set out in the Digital Single Market strategy. The plan has three main aims: firstly, to modernise public administrations using key technical building blocks; secondly, to achieve movements across a border using interoperable digital public services; thirdly, to facilitate digital interaction between administrations, people and businesses for high-quality public services. The EU eGovernment Action Plan runs to 2020 and will promote the take-up of eID, one of the digital service infrastructures funded by the Connecting Europe Facility. The European Commission is promoting this through awareness campaigns and also through public and private sector grants for its implementation. Digital-by-default is one of the underlying principles guiding the work of the new eGovernment Action Plan. Many Member States are applying or intending to apply the digital-by-default principle while keeping other channels open for those who are unwilling or unable to interact via the internet with governments. All activities and initiatives led by the Commission will be prepared in line with our better regulation standards. This includes assessing the ICT impact of Commission proposals. Public-private cooperation is required if there is to be a needs-based service delivery. This also applies to collaborative service creation and the private sector’s provision of services based on open public sector information. The Commission strongly supports this kind of collaboration as well as the private sector’s involvement in jointly creating online solutions. The Commission also funds several innovation projects under Horizon 2020 in this area. Since open data is essential for developing such services, the Commission recommends that the public sector make its data available electronically. It will itself guide the way forward by making its data available through the European Data Portal. ‘Once only’ is another key underlying principle of the eGovernment Action Plan. Applying this principle in the European Union could generate annual net savings of around EUR 5 billion per year by 2017. The principle means that people and businesses should supply the same information once only to a public administration. Public administration shares this data internally with due respect for data protection rules, so that there is no additional burden for people or businesses. Rather than forcing them to fit around these processes, it calls for the reorganisation of public sector internal processes. The Commission is considering applying the ‘once only’ principle in several policies. Under the Horizon 2020 programme it has called for a pilot scheme driven by Member States for applying the ‘once only’ principle across borders for businesses. The Commission is considering the gradual roll-out of this principle in its interactions with suppliers and grant participants. It will examine the possibilities for introducing the ‘once only’ principle for other interested parties. I would like to conclude by emphasising the need to support the use of e-ID. It is essential for ensuring a high take-up of digital public services. Together with the digital-by-default and ‘once only’ principles this will guarantee less administrative burden for people and businesses. This is good for the digital single market and it is good for European growth and competitiveness.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We very much welcome the fact that you, Vice-President Ansip, are taking part in the debate this evening on the use of electronic identification tools in the European internal market, and that you have also made it clear here that you want more of these electronic identification options to be used. The need for these digital electronic identification options is increasing on a daily basis, because more and more citizens are now also using services that can only be used safely – and certainly in the interests of citizens and users on the one hand, but also certainly in accordance with the legal requirements on the other. And for that we need secure, reliable services. There are, of course, – and you yourself come from Estonia – a number of Member States of the European Union that have already taken the first steps. The Estonian Prime Minister was only in Berlin at the beginning of the week at the Federal Government's retreat and presented these plans. In Germany, there is already a pioneer, which unfortunately is used very little, because the connection of the identity document to digital business must ultimately be done via an interface that has not yet been sufficiently clarified. Estonia has developed very quickly. However, I believe that we must agree that every new means that we use in the European Union has one imperative: absolute data security for users and absolute security, as far as it is required by the public. That is why we should try to establish the internal market through electronic identification. We should not now develop 28 different national systems, and then look at how we can combine them. At the same time, however, we should also take seriously the legitimate concerns of the Member States and economic operators for safe procedures and work together to find ways in which the European Union can take an important step into the digital future with the eGovernment Action Plan. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, Commissioner, will cooperate very constructively in this.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Ansip, thank you very much for the proposals you have put forward, which are a move in the right direction. Modernising society, which we need and these new resources made available to us through digitalisation, can also mean very many very positive advances, and we should make use of them. However, and I agree with the previous speaker on this, we must ensure that these funds that are made available are secure. Data protection is extremely important, and we must also ensure that it is important, especially for our companies, which sometimes also have to transfer sensitive data, that the hacking of this data is prevented, that security in these areas is particularly high and that it cannot be used by certain people for which the data is not intended. This is an enormous challenge, because it is not just about the means, the possibilities of combining one with the other, it is also about all the avenues and also the apparatuses on both sides, which must be just as safe. When we hear how easy it is to eavesdrop on something, we have to be very careful. That is why: yes to modernisation, yes to identification, yes to the new possibilities, but this must be prepared very, very precisely and well.  The second point, because I can only get to the fore now, is that we must also have an information system so that the people who work with it also develop confidence, because that trust is not there at all today.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, more and more governments are working to make life easier for citizens by providing new digital services. In my own region, Flanders, for example, we have already taken several initiatives on this, including the recent initiative "Flanders Radical Digital". E-government and everything that goes with it, such as e-identification, should be encouraged as much as possible. A legitimate question has already been asked about the visibility of the instruments that already exist, which are often unknown to citizens: a problem that we often have to deal with in Europe. In the context of e-government, I also think that it is very important that we make more and more use of the 'only once' principle, because the complex application procedures and administrative burdens that come with it often constitute a barrier for businesses and citizens. In this context, I believe that we must strive, especially within Europe, for maximum data sharing between the different administrations.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, this morning one speaker made a very interesting parallel between the industrial revolution and the digital revolution: that the industrial revolution brought many good things, but it also brought challenges like air pollution. So it is the same with the digital revolution. It creates new opportunities but it also has new challenges around cyber security and privacy, so therefore I think that the digital identity should be at the heart of our digital policies. E-ID will be the key to address challenges of privacy and cyber security and to the growth of digital economy. All these passwords, logins and all that is needed, are needed to be replaced by online measures which are secure. Edward Lucas wrote in his book Cyberphobia about this trend for passwords for everything, and he says that it is a recipe for catastrophe because it is a system which is very difficult for the humans to remember but very easy for the computer to guess. So many Member States have already developed means of online identification, but in some countries citizens are not even aware of this, because they do not have any online services that they can use e-identity for. So what is the incentive to do it in the first place? Therefore I have two questions for the Vice-President. Given that from September 2018 all Member States will be required to recognise all notified national E-ID means, what will be the concrete actions taken to ensure that this is implemented in time but also that Member States have the online services available for their citizens? The other question, as we need to lead by example: is the Commission intending to actually implement this in the Commission, so that the Commission will also recognise E-ID’s place, and when will this happen?

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, more and more activities linked to the exercise of fundamental rights, such as freedom of expression, are taking place online. The concepts of digital citizenship and digital governance are relatively new concepts, but they will become a reality in the not so near future. We, as legislators, have the task of identifying the potential and critical issues that technological progress determines, so that we can legislate effectively, protecting above all the weakest. When it comes to electronic identification and authentication services, certain fundamental issues must be borne in mind, such as the way in which personal data is collected and stored and whether or not the operators of such data and the provider of the identification service itself are public. I believe it is essential that identification services should be managed by the public, given the sensitivity of the information collected, yet this is not always the case in Europe. For example, Italy has also relied on private individuals to develop these services (Telecom Italia and Infocert) by allocating part of the funds of the Connecting Europe Facility. I ask myself and I ask you at this point: why did this happen? And what is the benefit for the citizens?

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, in a recent question to the Commission I raised the issue of the impossibility of identifying those entering the Union's external borders. In particular, many do not have documents identifying them and several refuse to give fingerprints. I have therefore asked the Commission whether it intends to equip the host authorities with facial recognition systems. This recognizes or confirms a person through a digital photo or movie and compares selected facial features of a person with a person's database. Commissioner Avramopoulos' response was that the Commission would evaluate and explore further technical and legal options. Such systems can be installed at all external and critical cross-border checkpoints. The sources of data and information are inexhaustible and can easily be worked with the existing EURODAC, AIS and VIS systems, as well as the europol databases and member states' intelligence services. This will strengthen the arsenal in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. That is why I call on the Commission and the Council to proceed immediately with the study and procurement of such systems.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Digitisation of documents is another element of our common market, our common functioning in the European Union and the disappearance of borders – as the Commissioner mentioned. They should disappear, and it is still in the digital world that these boundaries are felt and very visible. Digitisation of documents must be secure and accessible. We must have one European system for the whole of the European Union, otherwise we will work again for hours, days, weeks and years to harmonise this system, and it will be as difficult as harmonising the rights that have long existed in the European Union.  Mr Synadinos spoke (unfortunately) about digital documents in the context of refugees. I was in several refugee camps in Greece just last week, and indeed one of the main problems for those people who sit in camps for months is that it is so difficult to make documents. If we had electronic documents today, easily accessible and reliable, if this data, as we say in this House, could be collected once from everyone, not repeatedly, if fingerprints were more easily collected and stored securely, we would not only spare a sense of insecurity that our documents could be forged, but would spare the suffering of the many thousands of people who are waiing on our continent without papers. So I also strongly encourage you to speed up this process for us and for those who come to our continent. (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Madam President, honourable Member, I understand from your speech that you are a supporter of the idea of faster disintegration of national states and the transfer of responsibility to supranational authorities, but don't you think that the way cross-border instruments are introduced and the designation of national enforcement authorities needs to be further clarified in order to avoid the transfer of burdens and obligations on national laws and Member States?

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "Dear Mate! You just made me laugh so that I can't control the laughter. The harmonisation of digital documents, the harmonisation of digital documents in the European Union, as well as the harmonisation of different rights and provisions, do not necessarily mean the abolition of states in the European Union, of The Member States. And certainly, if you have a document that works in all countries, it will not take away your sense of nationality or take away your identity. I guarantee this to the Lord. I can give it a fingerprint.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, consolidating a robust digital union is one of the strategic priorities for combating the political, economic and social fragmentation that we are living in the European Union. And the digital revolution opens up a huge opportunity for society, for the economy, and today you have presented very important measures and pieces of legislation for the development of the digital market. But we have to complement that. We need a European data cloud, a simple set of processes so that businesses and citizens can take advantage of new governance models. Portugal has an excellent example, it is called Simplex, and the European Union needs to develop a European Simplex: easy digital identification, scanning by principle, online access to public and private services, integration or interconnection of databases to create one-stop shops and qualify users.  Commissioner, the future begins today and we must act quickly to achieve this agenda: European-based e-governance at the service of citizens and our businesses.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Madam President, thank you very much again, Commissioner. Today was a day when topics related to digital transformation and the European digital market had been discussed in a fairly extensive way.  We do not realize many times the extent to which public administrations play a decisive role in digital transformation and in the development of the digital single market. In Europe, the weight of public administrations remains extraordinarily high compared to other parts of the world, and in that sense there is a need to redouble an effort, which sometimes seems to be a little second, for this digital transformation to develop in public administrations as well. Electronic identification in this regard and with this objective is a key element, but the interoperability of public services in the European Union also plays an extraordinary role. An effort should be made to further emphasize the digital transformation of public administrations, because it is an extraordinary dynamizing element also for the digital economy and digital society. So what I am asking is that a greater effort be made, at least as a call for permanent attention.

name: Dan Nica (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome the Commission's proposal on the European Union Action Plan for EGovernment 2016-2020. The 'one-time only' principle is very important for ensuring interoperability, both at national level and outside national borders, as long as data protection rules are respected and no additional burden falls on citizens or businesses.  Secondly, the proposed eGovernment measures must be implemented together with actions for electronic identification, and the measure proposed by the Commission is the development of a prototype European catalogue of telecommunications and information technology standards. The expected date is 2017. I believe that it should be advanced for 2016, because it is a supporting action supporting the eGovernment implementation plan. This measure should facilitate interoperability in the acquisition of digital solutions by encouraging reporting to common sets of standards and profiles in information and communication technology in tendering procedures of contracting public authorities, and procurement criteria for public services should be linked to the ERDF criteria in order to comply with procurement rules.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, there is no possibility to go forward and to implement the digital single market solutions without some crucial technical and essential conditions. One of them is, of course, e-identification, supported by interoperability and proper standardisation. How can we develop public services accessible all over Europe without a digital identity? It means that we need to speed up the implementation of the E-ID project and go ahead with digital-by-default solutions and the ‘once only’ principle, which really simplify all kinds of services and make many relations between government and citizens much more open. How can we develop e—commerce without user-friendly digital identity, which is key for speeding up and scaling up the business processes, but also for the trust and for avoiding cybercrimes at the large scale? How can we develop portability of many services’ digital content without clear solutions in the area of e-identity? Discussing the digital content services regulation, we are trying to find various forms for the verification of the identity. It would be much simpler to have the national, but European-compatible e-identity. So we need it. We have a framework, we have tools, we have projects, now we have the action prepared by the European Commission and good proposals in the e-government communication, but what we feel is a lack, a deficit – the readiness to go in this direction at the same time by all Member States. The political will is needed first of all.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, my thanks to the Commission and to the previous speaker. So why does e-identification really matter? What matters is we have heard about access to public services in e-government and also to online shopping and e-commerce, and without it the best access that we can have would be limited and in the worst case scenario could be denied at all, so that is why e-identification is so important. What we are doing is creating one set of rules that covers 28 countries, covering 500 million people, and together we can tackle these challenges. Interoperability has previously been outlined, legal certainty also, because at the end of the day, e-identification really is about creating trust. Trust is key to e-ID, and by working together we can make this happen. In my country we have just 29 days before we have an EU referendum, and it is vital that we – Britain – remain part of the European Union. We have influence over this very debate on e-identification, but if we leave, if we walk away from our closest neighbours and closest friends, we will have no say in this debate and yet we will still have to pay to have the privilege to trade. In my own constituency there are 250 000 jobs reliant on exports to the European Union, and I do not want to see our workplace rights jeopardised. Therefore, if we were to leave, we would be poorer, isolated and diminished, and that is why Great Britain has to remain part of the European Union.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Commissioner, I have listened with interest to your speech. I very much welcome the fact that part of your Commission's digital agenda is not only the issue of digitisation of the internal market, but that the other area, the public sector, is equally important and that, therefore, the action plan you mentioned clearly states how public administration should be digitised. I consider this to be extremely important, because if we digitised only the internal market, introduced a strengthening of online sales here, etc., but the public sector began to lag behind, then this would not work very well in practice. I can see for myself in the Czech Republic, from which I come, that small and medium-sized companies make very significant use of online sales. We are at the forefront in Europe, but we are at the very end in the area of public administration. So please put pressure, if possible, on individual national governments to pay attention to this issue, because the overall digitisation, i.e. the public and private sectors combined, can only be this successful.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the implementation of e-administration has made it possible to simplify many administrative procedures, reduce costs and increase the very effectiveness of the public sector. It has also allowed for rapprochement and better interaction with the citizen. A key agreement was recently reached to make public sector websites, applications and content more accessible. Further steps need to be taken in this direction for the benefit of citizens and businesses to increase the accessibility of these services, which also requires continuously improving e-skills. Electronic identity is an essential element in ensuring trust in the digital environment, both within each Member State and especially for the creation of cross-border services, and facilitating the mobility of citizens and businesses. Ensuring full respect for data protection standards and network security are undoubtedly crucial elements in driving e-management and digital public services.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, in order to have cross-border and secure electronic transactions within the Member States of the Union there must be rules on electronic identification.  Thus, European citizens should be able to use their own electronic identification systems to access public services in other Countries of the Union. Of course, the existence of many databases that are not interconnected can create additional costs, as well as jeopardise the security and protection of personal data.  Therefore, this must first be settled is to have normal operating conditions for public services and public administration, alongside eGovernment. Moreover, bodies providing electronic identity confirmation services to other public sector bodies and systems should aim to reduce costs and facilitate the lives of European citizens.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, Pula is the first city in Croatia to introduce an e-citizen system. How important this was for our citizens, the economy of Pula, Istria and Croatia is evidenced by many very positive examples.  That is why I strongly support your intention, Mr Commissioner, to give this e-citizen and EU-wide identification system the right place as soon as possible. Of course, in this context, cross-border cooperation, i.e. cross-border e-identification of every citizen, any economic operator that has such a need, is particularly important to us.  On this occasion, I want to express my strong support to the Commission, as I believe this is the only correct way to make the European economy even more competitive and for our citizens to have an even better service.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, thank you very much for this really fruitful debate. According to my understanding, all the services provided by our governments had to be digital by default, open by default and cross-border by default. We all know that those e-governmental services will make our governments more efficient, more transparent, which is extremely important, but if those services are provided in a really transparent way, then this will not create the best environment for corruption for example. Not everybody will be happy about this, and also those governments which will provide internet-based services are, as a rule, more inclusive governments. But to involve our people it is extremely important. It is important by the governments to provide their citizens with a single digital identity, and this identity has to be strong, because this is all about trust. Once again, if people do not trust those internet-based e-services, they will never start to use those services. About efficiency. Single digital identity makes those governmental services but also private services cheaper than usage of traditional signatures. So it is not polite to provide examples always about Estonia. But in Estonia we think that just because of usage of digital signatures, we were able to save one working week per year, which is equal to 2% of our GDP, which is equal to our defence expenditure. We can say defence expenditure in Estonia is coming from digital signatures. So it is a question about efficiency. I would like also to underline the importance of the ‘once only’ principle. I know once again from my own experience how important it was to introduce this ‘once only’ principle. In Estonia it took six years to get those first one million digital signatures and then we introduce, the ‘once only’ principle. It means the state has the right to ask for information from their citizens or their companies only once, and it gave a real boost on usage of those digital identities. Now, in the country I know best, they are getting more than 1.3 million digital signatures per week already, and the population in Estonia is 1.3 million inhabitants. All those digital solutions provided by our governments had to be user-centric, and if those solutions included digital identities, they will be really user-centric solutions, then people they will use those solutions. If signing digitally will take four or five minutes, nobody will start to use those solutions. There are some really good examples. For example, in Austria I know people they are using mobile identities quite often, in some other countries also, it is common to use mobile identities instead to use those Smart ID cards. Those solutions, digital solutions, they have to be user-centric and then people they will use those solutions and our people they have to be absolutely sure that those solutions are there, also really safe and well protected. It is true that our registers do not talk with each other. We have in all the countries digital prior business registers, but it is very difficult to get information in a digital way, in a trusted manner, from another country from those business registers. If somebody wants to make business for example here in Belgium, but he is coming from some other countries, then how those local people they know who has mandate to represent this company here in this country? It is so easy theoretically to get information from business register, but in real life paper is needed. In the 21st century paper is still needed for that. We have some quite good examples about the regional cooperation, about mutual recognition of digital identities – I know best about this example we have in the Baltic States and between Finland also – but there are some other examples also. We have already eIDAS Directive which allows mutual recognition of those digital identities, but full implementation of eIDAS directive takes some time. We have implementation acts. There is cooperation networking in place. The eIDAS Observatory will be launched in the second half of 2016 to boost online trust security and transparency in the digital single market and to facilitate the use of cross-border electronic identification and trust services. But I absolutely agree with those people who say that the European Commission has to lead by example, and we will try to do that. So e-procurement it is a real challenge for all of us. According to analysis prepared by the European Parliament, if we will be able to use e-procurement across the European Union, we can save one billion euros per year. But also this service is based on strong digital identities. In the European Commission we have to be ready for full implementation of e-procurement. About organised crime and the refugee crisis. Once again, single digital identity based on biometrics is needed. As we know, just recently it happened so that one of those terrorists was able to change his identity in the European Union even 7 times. It is a shame. So we have to build up really good interoperability network and we have to introduce in all the EU Member States strong digital identities, and we have to fully implement the eIDAS Directive. I am looking forward to really fruitful cooperation in this field between the European Commission and the European Parliament.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Commission of the European Union calls for the widespread, rapid and efficient introduction of e-governance and the availability of cross-border electronic identification tools and online services. Digital borders are now completely gone, so politics must respond to this. The use of electronic tools and online services strengthens the digital internal market and responds to the challenges of digital public administration, such as the emergence of new technical elements, the daily use and use of electronic services. The Commission promotes accessible access to e-government through various action plans and campaigns, such as the e-Government Action Plan 2010-2015 and the HORIZON 2020 Innovation Programme thereafter. E-government has led to the introduction of electronic identity (eID), which facilitates the course of cross-border administrative procedures, such as setting up businesses abroad, moving and working abroad, online settlement of pension rights, enrolment in schools and universities. Thanks to digital systems, the public administration session becomes transparent and open, a way for both citizens and businesses to monitor the status of their cases and transactions.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I believe that the shift to e-government in Europe through the development of e-identification tools and a wide availability of online services is a very important milestone in the development of the Digital Single Market and the future of the European Union. It is essential for competitiveness, reducing costs for businesses and making life easier for European citizens and therefore requires ambitious initiatives. In order to ensure the adoption of online services, the deployment of a secure digital identity is necessary to build public trust and ensure convenience. In this respect, we need to support the initiatives for promoting awareness about the opportunities of e-identification. A secure electronic identification is an important step towards data protection and the prevention of online fraud. Citizens and businesses need to be able to trust that their data is treated in full respect of existing data protection legislation. Without certainty on the legal validity of all these related services, businesses and citizens will remain reluctant to use the digital interactions as their natural way of interaction because they will be unsure of the issue of a possible dispute.

name: Theresa Griffin
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the energy retail market in Europe is not functioning properly and citizens are directly impacted by this failure. Around the EU, consumers are overcharged for their energy bills. In my country, the UK, consumers overpaid GBP 1.2 billion a year for their energy bills between 2009 and 2013. Over 50 million citizens are living in energy poverty in the EU and are forced to choose on a daily basis between heating, cooling or eating. Around the EU, consumers are willing to invest in energy efficiency and self-generation projects, but are hindered by heavy administrative burdens and high upfront investment costs. Throughout Europe, energy markets are not transparent and are not competitive enough. In this context, industry fails to pass falling wholesale prices on to consumers. Energy bills are becoming increasingly complex and citizens are not able to compare offers easily. Many consumers are on outdated energy contracts, unaware of their ability to switch.  The ‘new deal’ report, on which we will be voting tomorrow, highlights key recommendations to address these problems. Regarding the retail energy market, to increase the transparency and clarity of bills, we need to include peer-based comparisons and information on switching in those bills. Consumers should be placed on the most appropriate tariffs, and suppliers should notify them about their cheapest offers. We need to eradicate termination fees and penalties for switching suppliers. And finally, social tariffs should be maintained for the most vulnerable. Regarding self-generation, we need to set up a common legal framework for the right to store and sell excess electricity at a fair price. We need to promote new business models, collective purchasing schemes and innovative financial instruments to incentivise self-generation and self-consumption. And on energy poverty, we need to focus energy efficiency objectives and funds on our most vulnerable citizens. We also call, Commissioner, for a definition of energy poverty and an Action Plan from the European Commission.  I was very pleased that the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy voted on Tuesday, on the energy efficiency implementation report, to place tackling energy poverty at the heart of energy efficiency. Energy efficiency can be the glue of social cohesion and European integration. I strongly believe that proposing a meaningful level of ambition in the revision of the 2030 energy efficiency targets is a necessity. For every 1% improvement in energy efficiency, three million more homes can be properly renovated and seven million citizens lifted out of energy poverty. As a conclusion, I want to highlight that energy is not a commodity: it is a basic social right. As a conclusion, I want to say that this report is about the widow in Bulgaria, unable to compare energy offers and unaware that she could save money by switching. It is about the student in the UK, living in a rented flat, poorly insulated, and with inefficient heating. It is about the young couple in Malta, willing to invest in a solar panel, but facing high upfront investments. And it is about the long-term sick person in Spain, too frightened of costs to turn on their air conditioning in August. It is about benefits for all, and 28 Member States working together to end energy poverty.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, putting citizens at the heart of the Energy Union and tackling energy poverty deserves our full attention and thank you very much for the report. The report is very timely because the energy transition and the new technologies are changing how the energy markets work. This can and must bring benefits to all consumers, be it households or industry. However, it is a fact that retail markets for energy are not working today for consumers as they should. Consumer satisfaction and engagement in the energy market remain persistently low, and we have seen a trend of rising energy prices for end-consumers across the EU. The New Deal for Energy Consumers is about correcting these shortcomings. Our objective is to deliver: a competitive, technology-driven and fair energy market which delivers high-quality energy services to consumers. This means removing barriers for companies with innovative products and services which try to enter the market. We want a market where consumers can make informed choices about the way they consume energy and about the sources of energy they want to consume. And we want a market-based framework to protect vulnerable consumers and fight energy poverty. In the short time that I have today, please let me mention a few issues to make this more concrete. We want bills to be clearer and easier to compare with alternative offers. Therefore, we are analysing possibilities for an EU certification scheme for price comparison tools. We have to work on removing the barriers for switching between providers. Barriers still exist and harm both consumers and innovative companies. I am pleased to see that Parliament recognises the importance of smart technologies in the energy sector. Technology costs are falling rapidly. This means that more and more consumers could reduce their energy bills by using technologies like rooftop solar panels, heat pumps or smart meters. Demand response and storage solutions must be developed. This is beneficial for energy efficiency and for consumers. But, as rightly pointed out in the report, we need to put the necessary enabling legal framework in place. We must adjust our rules to the energy technologies of the 21st century. We need a better framework for decentralised generation and self-consumption. We need more cooperatives, aggregators, and energy service companies in order to ensure access for those who are not in a position to self-generate, such as tenants and vulnerable consumers. And finally, we need a better and informed debate about energy cost, taxes, levies and subsidies. Therefore, we will publish in the second half of this year a report on energy prices and costs that will enhance transparency on the different components of energy prices in the Member States.  The cost of energy leads me to the second topic of today: Energy Poverty. Let me mention a few figures. In 2014, approximately 10% of EU citizens felt that they were unable to keep their homes adequately warm. Since 2000, the share of energy spending of the lowest income households in their total income increased from 6% to 9%, which means a 50% increase. This is significant for the small budgets that these households have. I know from my Energy Union Tour and from the country analyses which we drew up, that we have a very diverse picture in Europe but energy poverty is an issue everywhere. Of course, well-targeted social policy measures are the most direct and effective tool to address poverty. This is, correctly, the competence of the Member States. But nevertheless, the Commission is analysing if and how our work can support the Member States in addressing energy poverty. The fight against social exclusion and poverty is a cross-cutting policy issue, so let me mention just a few examples.  We are analysing if a definition of energy poverty is possible and how it could help address the problem. With your support, thanks to your pilot project on fuel energy poverty, the Commission is considering an energy poverty observatory. This will help us to quantify, monitor and identify best practices and we expect to launch this in 2018 following an open tender. We are working with the Member States to share good practices. As an example, Bulgaria was mentioned by our rapporteur and Commissioner Arias Cañete is travelling just now to Bulgaria to speak about the topic in the context of electricity market liberalisation, an area where the Commission services have provided support to Bulgaria in recent months. The Commission agrees that energy efficiency is the most effective way to prevent energy poverty. It reduces greenhouse gas emissions and energy bills. It contributes to better health and living standard, and as for all energy efficiency measures, it creates jobs in the local economy. We have underlined the importance of energy poverty from the very beginning, and we promised in the first State of the Energy Union Report that we would pay particular attention to the issue when reviewing key legislation in 2016. Therefore, the report and the resolution which we discuss today are very timely. I would like to thank Theresa Griffin and all other colleagues involved in this for their work. I would also like to acknowledge the resolution on meeting the anti-poverty target in the light of increasing household costs which this Parliament adopted on 14 April 2016. I can promise that we will examine all your recommendations on tackling energy poverty very closely. I am very much looking forward to this debate and I would like to thank you for giving me the floor.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, firstly let me thank the Commissioner for his good words and also Theresa Griffin for her work on this file and her willingness to cooperate and seek to find good compromises. I must say that it was a privilege to work with her. I think the report we will vote on tomorrow will send the right message. It puts forward some good ideas about how we can lower energy prices for all. We should not underestimate the importance of this issue in a wider economic context. Reducing energy costs, and therefore household costs, is a massive opportunity to ease the burden on already stretched household budgets across Europe. This can in turn boost consumer spending power, give a boost to businesses and help to bring economic growth across the EU. For me, the best way to deliver this new deal for energy consumers is by putting in place a well—functioning market and a well—functioning energy system. Competitive markets increase transparency and comparability of prices, and better-informed and empowered consumers will help energy become far more affordable for all. I think one important aspect of this is increasing the share of the retail price on which retailers can compete. In Europe retailers can only compete with each other on about a third of the price. The rest is made up of taxes and add-ons. Increasing this share by reducing the amount of government add—ons would increase competition, drive down prices for consumers and, at the same time, allow retail prices to better reflect wholesale prices, enabling proper market signals to occur. The other part of this debate we are here to address is energy poverty. I think the differing definitions of energy poverty in different Member States, based on different climatic conditions, is something we need to strongly consider before thinking about an EU-level action, but that should not distract from the importance of this issue. In Ireland, we define energy poverty as an inability to heat or power a home to an adequate degree. A household in Ireland that spends more than 10% of its income on energy is considered to be in energy poverty. As a country that has the third highest energy prices in Europe, this is of course a big issue for us, and I am pleased to say that we put in place a strategy to combat the problem early this year.  I look forward to further debate and progress on this very important issue. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Your words are almost entirely consistent with the words of Commissioner Šefčovič. At the same time, when I think of the country that I know best – my own country, Hungary – there is something else going on. A piece of public power is in the hands of virtually all power supplies, excluding competition, and there are no traces of development. What would you advise the Commission? How can our joint decisions here be enforced by the Member States?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, that is a problem, and that is why I identified that each Member State will have different definitions, different ways of dealing with it. But obviously, if we have an EU-wide regulation or directive, then the individual states have an obligation to deal with that and especially in relation to energy poverty. It absolutely make sense that all Member States should do everything they could to try and reduce or eliminate energy poverty, whether these companies are state-owned, private or whatever. That has to be a very important social issue that has to be dealt with.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I also welcome this debate, which comes to put an expensive face on it and introduces the social component to the energy debate. Energy has become a social right, a social good, the access of which we must guarantee, especially to the most vulnerable groups. As Colleague Griffin said, it is not a receipt that many elderly people in the European Union even die, in winter from the cold or in summer from the heat. It must be a priority within the Debate of the Union for Energy. Congratulations to my colleague Theresa Griffin on the excellent report, which highlights all those points on which we must influence to combat energy poverty. I would fundamentally like to highlight three points. Firstly, the role of energy efficiency as the first source of energy, and I thereby appeal to member States' compliance with the Energy Efficiency Directive, so that within their national plans they may establish a space, a clear commitment, to the renovation of the buildings of the most vulnerable people.  Secondly, I reiterate and join the claim of a European framework for self-consumption that guarantees this right, because today it is not a receipt that in Spain it is prevented, even retroactively now through legislation against consumers, that solar panels be legalized or that the establishment of new facilities should be prevented , while we see in Germany the efficient and effective functioning of cooperatives in neighbouring communities. And thirdly, I think it is essential to talk and address fair taxation. We all know that more than 50% of the price or invoice component paid by citizens for energy through the European Union as a whole are energy policy taxes, other than the cost of production or distribution. We need to have a fair and transparent debate, that we deal with taxation progressively, within the design of the energy market. In short, there are tools to ensure access, democratize energy and eradicate poverty. What we have to put on our part now is the necessary political will. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Mr President, honourable Member, I do not know if the translation was accurate, but it seemed to me that you had approached a colleague in the chamber with the 'comrade'. This is probably because you did not live in a communist state, and therefore you do not know the true meaning of this word.  When you talk about state-organised energy, don't you think it's better for consumers in individual countries to be able to make decisions about switching their supplier through the bid comparison mechanism rather than on the socialist planning line?

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – For me, all the people here, all MEPs and MEPs, are partners. The meaning, connotation or definition you put it. He is known to the vast majority. For me, Theresa Griffin, you and I are co-workers. The meaning you give him by communism is different. As regards the democratisation of energy, it is precisely what this report advocates and it is precisely what it seeks to ensure, as well as the guaranteed access by citizens to energy. Therefore, I do not understand what your problem is or where you see the problem. You talk about socialism and talk about communism, and I think we have different views on it, and you know it perfectly well.

name: Ashley Fox
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, my Group supports the concept  of an energy union. We believe the best way to ensure energy security for the whole of Europe and to provide the lowest prices for our citizens is a properly integrated gas and electricity market. I want consumers and businesses in my constituency to be able to buy their energy from any company in the EU. I want an energy system that is fair on consumers and helps to protect the energy-poor. I am happy for the Commission to share the best practices of Member States in combating energy poverty. Customers should receive clear information in their bills, and switching energy suppliers should be a simple and transparent process. I support the call that energy providers’ websites and digital invoicing should be fully accessible to disabled people. Whilst energy poverty needs to be tackled, the best way this can be done on a European level is through having a properly-functioning and competitive single market that delivers low prices. It is not for the EU to say how Member States deliver their social policy programmes. I doubt that the broad common and non—quantitative definition of energy policy that the rapporteur calls for will achieve anything at all. I do not want the Commission to bring forward an action plan or to propose legislation on this subject, because these are matters for the Member States. The rapporteur calls for a legal maximum percentage increase in the costs that distribution networks can charge. This is surely a matter for national regulators. We do not need EU legislation on this subject. We also do not need her recommendation that certain levies and network charges should be ‘progressively applied’. Has she thought what this means in practice? It is not the EU’s business, and it is also inappropriate for her to call for a ban on doorstep selling by energy companies. This is not for Europe to decide. I do agree with the rapporteur that the third energy package has not been fully implemented. Commissioner, we need you to defend consumers and to ensure this law is enforced in all EU countries.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The European energy market is undergoing profound change and we need to ensure that consumers are at the heart of this change. Only a competitive, transparent and liberalised internal market will ensure that consumers also benefit from this change. Therefore, a New Deal for energy consumers is urgently needed. However, it must become a New Deal that also empowers consumers to make informed decisions and actively participate in the market, rather than patronising them. As the shadow alDE rapporteur for this report, I am convinced that the best measures for reducing consumption and costs are more competition, better information and better consumer involvement. Firstly, we must ensure that there is real competition in the energy market and that the switch between suppliers is simplified. Similarly, regulated prices must finally be phased out. Secondly, we need comprehensible, transparent and easily accessible information for consumers, especially with regard to energy bills. Thirdly, it is important to improve the opportunities for consumers to integrate into the market, including as producers and investors. Information technologies such as smart meters, smart grids or online platforms can open up new avenues, especially when it comes to managing demand. In the same way, we need to break down the existing barriers for prosumers. Prosumers can actively contribute to improving energy efficiency and will play an important role in the further development of the energy system in the future. Only in this way can we create a successful European internal energy market.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this report may be an opportunity, a spearhead, for the actors in the necessary energy transition to be the people, the citizens themselves. This transition should not be handled from above, by private interests, but by a real energy revolution of popular participation, democratization and empowerment of people in something as basic as energy. It is therefore necessary to establish a legal framework for energy producers and consumers. A European framework prohibiting retroactive measures and 'taxes on the sun'; drastically reduce administrative and financial barriers to promoting investment in renewables, and that this investment is by households, cooperatives or even local administrations. Fifty million people in Europe suffer from energy poverty, while energy oligopoly accumulates benefits — to name just one example, Gas Natural declared a profit of 1.5 billion euros in 2015. Combating energy poverty is socially necessary and financially possible. That is why an energy poverty definition should be established at European level, as well as policy coordination between different EU member countries. Let us shield the rights of European citizens by recognizing access to energy as a basic social right.

name: Ernest Maragall
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President. Thank you, Mrs. Griffin, for your work and for your willingness to agree. This own-initiative report on 'Establishing a New Agreement for Energy Consumers' certainly comes to this house as a positive part of the building of the energy transition we are trying to build. The main thing about the report is that it is right in the point of view. The view of the citizen, of the passive ex-consumer, now become a producer, distributor, storageer and consumer of an energy whose marginal cost is getting closer to zero every day. That is why this new European regulatory framework, general and aware of the real diversity of the situations to which it should apply, is necessary. But we go to the decentralized, democratic market—despite the fear this term generates in some groups—and based, of course, on renewable energy. A market with transparency, price comparison, conscious demand to decide freely, smart meters, open competitiveness and effectively reduced prices. This is the not-too-distant scenario that this report draws and which we are now calling on the Commission, Commissioner, and the Member States. And that is why it makes sense that we are also dealing with the question of energy poverty and the answer it needs today. And so, by the way, it is unacceptable for the Spanish state to act against a law like Catalan that seeks only to respond properly to one of the most dramatic social effects arising from the economic crisis. We understand perhaps that this new broad horizon does not please those who would like to continue to operate in an opaque and centralized market. It is no surprise that they are trying to postpone and lengthen the energy transition that citizens, on the other hand, would like to see in force and complete in the short term. Therefore, we value references to quality and completeness in invoices, energy sources consumed, possible polluting effect, mechanisms available to manage consumption, tax overloads or fees, supplying company changes, etc. Indeed, we are approaching a conception of clean, abundant and cheap energy as a basic citizen right, as we will vote tomorrow. That is why we hope that this report will be intact and complete from tomorrow's votes, despite any attempts to pour water into the wine, the reverse that some would like to give to the vision and positive ambition that the Griffin report contains and which we share.

name: Dario Tamburrano
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is often said that the future of energy is a distributed system of production from renewable resources, where individuals and communities, local administrators and small and medium-sized enterprises cooperate in the production and distribution and storage of energy. Yet this future is already a reality, represented by prosumers, energy producers and consumers, for whom there is still no clear, shared and open definition in European legislation, which will create the space within which to establish unequivocal rights and forms of support.  Ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will vote on the Griffin report, which recognises the reality and role of the prosumers, enhancing the objectives of freedom and prosperity that the prosumers pursue, giving them legal dignity within the Energy Union. Tomorrow we will also have the opportunity to go further, supporting Amendment No 1, which recognises distributed networks, renewable energy produced and consumed in the context of prosumers as a common good, as well as water. Let us try to look beyond the windows of these buildings, where things happen, where the real demands to be collected are: it is our primary duty as elected representatives. We give real answers for 21st century society.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, the forced introduction of hugely expensive wind energy will further increase the already sky-high consumer prices of electricity. The Commission believes that prices will rise less if all European households are constantly monitored by hundreds of millions of so-called smart consumption meters. In the Commission's view, a household cannot simply consume electricity without the consent of that meter approved by the Commission. For households, however, the bill is mainly determined by the environmental taxes to pay those same windmills, in addition to energy taxes to satisfy the endless hunger for money from our socialist governments. Mr President, I believe in the market. If it can be cheaper, then so will consumers and producers. They don't need Europe for that. If your proposals have some realism, why is there not yet a small-scale energy economy? The answer is simple: because it is expensive, because it is complex, but mainly because it is unreliable. And the report makes no mention of this unreliability of small-scale energy. But the wind doesn't blow constantly, the sun doesn't always shine and not everyone has a forest in the backyard. What remains is a report in which the Commission, in a view to a bright future of total control, far exceeds its mandate, since, in accordance with Article 194 of the Treaty, the EU must not interfere in the choice of a Member State for its energy sources or the structure of its own energy supply.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – We have read very good words in the report about the free market, about competition. Immediately afterwards, it turns out that all this is worth nothing, because there are better types of energy, worse types of energy. The Commission or Parliament know better what people should heat their homes and how. We also learn that access to energy is a social right, in short: without communism, there is nothing to say here in the European Union. There is no reason for us to believe that man has a social right to energy, because if we continue down this path, we will soon come to the conclusion that a man should be guaranteed social access to women – especially the nice ones – and that would regulate one very important social problem. More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Commissioner, i would like to begin by thanking the If we want to reduce poverty in Europe, then the right medicine is to find new jobs. In order to have new jobs, we need investment. So we need to think about an investment environment if we want to reduce poverty. If we want to help the low-quality people who are unable to participate in the labour market, we must use the social assistance systems of our country, each Member State, and these systems can, as always, be improved and improved.  But if we want to reduce energy prices, then medicines are competition. If there is a market with competition in any area \u2012\u2012 be it the gas or electricity market \u2012\u2012, prices will decrease. Colleagues, we have a solution to this, which we have been implementing in the specific laws for a long time now, with the Commission's leadership. It is to develop, to create a European Energy Union, the main objective of which is to improve the single market for both gas and electricity, because when we improve this market and create the necessary interconnections, and improve or reduce regulation so that trade can also take place across national borders, this competition will result in an improvement in the quality of supply, a reduction in the dependence of imports and a reduction in the price of electricity and gas for all consumers.

name: Dan Nica (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Energy Union must have as its central element an efficient and functioning internal energy market, ensuring the competitiveness of the European economy, growth and jobs, affordable and competitive prices for individual consumers and industrial consumers and the protection of vulnerable consumers. Mr Vice-President, I welcome your strong commitment to address ingpoverty, and I think you agree that future legislative proposals should contain measures in this direction, and the S&D Group will give you all the necessary support. Together, we need to develop a strong and comprehensive approach to energy poverty, support Member States in adopting the best strategies to combat energy poverty by identifying best practices and exchanging information, for example a greater opportunity for Member States to know what best practices are at the level of the 28 Member States. Local authorities and national regulators, energy companies play a critical role in ensuring that markets operate in a way that does not disadvantage vulnerable consumers by guaranteeing supply, establishing codes of conduct for market players and identifying vulnerable consumers by companies. Our common aim should be low energy prices for household consumers and European industry, and we need to find long-term solutions to solve these problems. I want you to know that we will oppose any measures and decisions that would lead to an increase in electricity prices. This would mean a new economic crisis in Europe, a new blow to European consumers, and we will strongly oppose any such measures. And to put citizens at the heart of the Energy Union, we must enable and facilitate their strong participation in energy markets, while providing adequate information to vulnerable consumers. I want to congratulate our colleague Theresa Griffin for doing a very complex job in this direction, and the report will be voted on tomorrow. And once again thank you, Mr. Vice President!

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – We must look at the Energy Union through the lens of the consumer, and the question of reasonable electricity bills is undoubtedly one of the most important issues. The report on the table contains some positive points, such as the use of our own energy sources. Unfortunately, it also has a number of unacceptable proposals for me.  Of course, I perceive that there is a phenomenon where the poorest part of the population cannot afford to pay for energy. But: Do we need regulatory intervention at EU level? Do we need a Europe-wide definition of energy poverty? I'm sure you don't. After all, aid to the social systems of the Member States is primarily a matter for those in need. We can solve the problem of high energy prices through the energy market. But we should look in the mirror first. The third energy package is not fully implemented in all countries. At the same time, the question is to what extent support for renewables contributes to prices for consumers in a number of Member States, which is subsequently also the case for our citizens.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I will be very brief today, partly because I can subscribe to what our ALDE shadow, and also a number of other colleagues, have said and partly because I am losing my voice today. So I will just make a few points. I would like to say to my colleague Mrs Griffin that I have very high respect for her, and she knows that. I must say that her report does contain a number of very relevant, useful elements which I am happy to support, but it is also a matter of fact that it does go beyond what I think we should be dealing with at European Union level and here in the European Parliament. As has been said, we have poor people in the European Union. That is a fact – some more, some less – but it is also a fact that our economies and our industries need restructuring – that we really need to have policies that are oriented on growth, and we need to improve the business environment, the entrepreneurship skills, etc. If we still have a certain percentage of our citizens at poverty level, then this should be addressed by the national Member States through their measures. Yes, there is a lot to do at European Union level. In my opinion, the Commissioner has described this, calling its shortcomings very precisely. By all means, energy union, energy diversification etc. But let me stress and finish by saying that what we really need is a new energy market design, because we have a distorted market. This is something that we need to focus on. It does not function the way it should, and obviously we are then facing lack of competition and high prices that some people, even with support, cannot afford.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, my congratulations, first of all, to the rapporteur. With more investment and research and fewer challenges, we need to develop an energy model based also on projects at the local level, i.e. points of self-generation and self-consumption attached to citizens, which should mean that these decisions are also made at the local and regional level and together with citizenship. Increasingly, citizens, small businesses and institutions are collaborating in systems or networks of production, distribution, storage and consumption of renewable energy at the local level, in community-based models.
