These efforts, which are positive from any point of view, should be encouraged, driven and accompanied by the Commission as a common good, and I believe that this should also be encouraged in cross-border cooperation environments to expand local networks that will eventually shape a real and sustainable energy transition at European level and, moreover, as the rapporteur pointed out, will be a cohesion factor.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr. Vice-President of the Commission, in order to achieve our energy climate goals that we have committed to in Paris, we need to move more boldly into an energy transition that will increase citizens' involvement.  Individual and collective action of citizens in the form of energy cooperatives is crucial, as it contributes to energy democracy. It sustainably stimulates the growth of the local economy and employment and effectively solves serious social problems such as energy poverty. In order to achieve this, I believe that several important preconditions need to be met: to provide citizens and cooperatives with access to cheaper capital and to encourage innovative financial instruments and business models, to encourage the development and widespread use of advanced smart grid networks, to implement the smart city concept in cities, and to introduce an obligation in all Member States to use smart numbers. The Commission needs to define general guidelines for national energy strategies and Member States must change energy strategies and national action plans by involving citizens and cooperatives and change legislative frameworks, support policies and market access.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, there is some good stuff in this report. Transparency is an excellent thing, which we approve of; competition – the ability to switch suppliers: that too is extremely positive; completing interconnectors so that we can trade energy across Europe: that too is very positive. But with great respect, I point out that we are ignoring the elephant in the room. These measures are merely fiddling at the margin. The reason why we have very high energy prices in Europe and the reason why we are driving our industry into an uncompetitive situation compared to the rest of the world is that we have chosen to rely obsessively on unreliable, expensive, intermittent renewable energy which exports inefficiency to the backup and across the grid. That is the reason, and if we fail to address that reason, we will not solve the problems of competitiveness in the energy market in the European Union, and we will not deliver secure and affordable energy to our consumers. The fact is we have chosen as a deliberate policy to drive up energy prices; we have chosen as a deliberate policy to drive many consumers into fuel poverty; we have chosen to undermine the competitiveness of our industries and to drive energy-intensive businesses offshore to other jurisdictions with lower environmental standards, where they actually emit more CO2 than they would do if we remain. It is a lose-lose policy, and until we start addressing the fundamentals we will not solve these problems.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Mr President, because in the 21st century with such technological development, while energy is fuelling competition and wars, more and more households are being condemned to energy poverty. But because the capitalist path, the European Union's policy of liberalisation and privatisation of energy is a class policy, i.e. profits for the industry's bees and poverty for households.  Typical is the decision of the Greek government SYRIZA - ANEL to reduce the gas tax on industrialists, while increasing the same tax on households in the midst of a tax storm, further reducing wages and pensions with the 3rd and 4th, without end, Greek Memorandum.  This is the energy democracy invoked in the report, even recommending energy production by the consumers themselves, i.e. liberalisation that is supposedly pro-grassroots. There is no good and bad liberalisation, it is always in favour of monopolies. Only with another economy, labour power, can energy from merchandise become a popular right to meet modern needs. In other words, what was a conquest in socialism today is the aim and purpose of the people's struggle.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to thank the Vice-President for his comment, his positive comment, to the report by our colleague Theresa Griffin, which I rate highly. Of course, with some detailed solutions that may go too far, it is difficult to agree, but overall this is a very useful report and I thank my colleague very much for his work. I wanted to highlight three things. Many people have talked about the need to strengthen our approach to energy efficiency and end-use of energy. This is the number one problem in every energy issue. Secondly, prosumer energy cannot be developed without well-designed electricity grids, smart meters, smart grids. These are huge costs and Member States must consider spending these costs, because not all costs can be charged to energy companies. It must also be the responsibility of the budget. And the third thing that is extremely important: cheap, safe and clean energy for consumers requires the creation of the right conditions for energy companies. The common market has already been mentioned. These are those who produce, transmit electricity, work on new production technologies, transmit, store energy and also transmit and produce gas. Without a well-developed market and without good energy companies, we will not be able to cope with energy poverty.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – One of the most passionate goals of the European Union is to create a new, better, reliable, better-priced, consumer-oriented energy policy. It is driven by climate change, the technological possibilities we have and new ways of using renewable energy. Madam Griffin has done a great job bringing also the energy poverty into the central question. One thing I am especially happy about is the fact that now we have some ideas on how to really fight energy poverty. That has a role nowadays in Europe. I worked in the Employment Committee on the issue, and the figures I learned are tremendous. There are people dying in Europe because of the cold, so then in wintertime you may not cut the electricity if it is an electricity house. I learned it is done in Finland, but there are countries in Europe who do not do that, and then I also learned that there are still some countries where the customers cannot change from one company to another, and there are also termination fees. We do not have them in the telecom market, so why do we still have them in the market-oriented energy markets in Europe? We have to get rid of that. I am very happy that the Commissioner is listening here and wait for the proposal on that. One other point is that we also have to make sure that companies pay their taxes. It is normal to have natural monopolies as they operate in areas where customers cannot change their operator. The natural monopolies market pressure does not work, so we have to be very careful they do not practice tax avoidance.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it has been said in many speeches this evening that energy in Europe is too expensive and the market is not working. From here, the Commissioner has received very strong support for market reform and for the need for more transparency and competition in Europe and for consumers to have the opportunity to switch their energy suppliers as well. After all, one of the big reasons why the market is not working in Europe at the moment is that we currently have inadequate energy transmission links, we have too many energy islands and, on the other hand, various subsidies for energy have confused the market. The European Union subsidises energy by around 100 20 billion every year and, in practice, it has led to no one investing in energy without some form of permanent support, and this cannot continue. It is acceptable when new technologies are being built, that it receives some type of investment aid, but if energy is based on the need for continuous, support, it is not sustainable.  The Commissioner has received strong support here in such a way that the European Parliament wants to reform the energy market, to achieve competition and transparency. This is, of course, a major problem for European consumers and industry. In Finland, wholesale electricity prices are thirty per cent higher than in the USA, and there are big differences in consumer prices between Member States.  It also emerged here that not all countries have sufficient support from the Member States for their most vulnerable citizens, so that they can cope with the cost of housing. Above all, it is a matter for the Member States.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the realisation of the energy union is essential for Europe to be able to strengthen its sovereignty, guarantee and diversify supply and lead the energy transition to a model based on clean and renewable energy. But when we talk about energy transition, we also have to talk about the social model that allows Europeans to have the energy they need for a decent life. Achieving this means putting in place a mix of policies appropriate to each regional market and to each sub-regional market. We have to know very well the concrete data of energy poverty in each country to verify the conformity and quality of responses and, on the basis of the concrete data, we have to act both in the field of energy efficiency and in the field of market regulation. Eliminate aggressive business practices for the most vulnerable, establish social referral tariffs, use incentive systems to foster efficiency practices, and lower costs. These are some examples of what much can be done.  In my speech I would like to congratulate rapporteur Theresa Griffin on the suggestions she makes, for the theme she has put to the discussion and for the fact that she has integrated the social dimension, because we need to ensure in the energy transition economic gains in competitiveness, environmental gains in sustainability and social gains in equity. That's our challenge. It's big, but it's strong and it's good.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – The report we are debating is very interesting. It raises very important issues, especially in the social aspect. There is no doubt that we need a well-organised, well-created deal for energy consumers in Europe – or a new one, I am not convinced. However, this report mixes – I would say – many very beautiful ideas, ideals with unrealistic demands. And you have to be fully aware of that. We must also bear in mind that it is not allowed, it should not be misunderstood the role of certain actors or sectors in the state. Social assistance and social assistance are the responsibility of public actors, including states and we as the European Union, and it is difficult to imagine that this state, public responsibility should be passed on to the commercial private market. Nor should we confuse professional energy with individual energy, and the demands that 100% of energy, for example, come from green energy or distributed prosumer energy, are not only not realistic, but if they were to be realised, they would be fundamentally dangerous not only for energy security, for the economic security of the European Union, but even for the beneficiaries of this report, that is, for citizens. , for consumers.

name: Martina Werner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to my colleague Theresa Griffin for the really very good work done, because energy poverty is a very serious issue, including in the EU. More than 50 million people – one in ten European citizens – are unable to heat their homes adequately and at a reasonable cost. Nevertheless, energy poverty is officially recognised or even mentioned in legislation in less than a third of EU Member States, and so energy poverty cannot be adequately combated there. That is why gag ginger contracts must finally be banned, which provide for penalties or fees when switching to a cheaper energy supplier, and we also need more transparency in electricity bills. In addition, we need a better framework throughout Europe for citizens who produce their own electricity. Only in this way can we take people with us for the energy transition and thus jointly shape the path to a sustainable, efficient and citizen-oriented Energy Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: Mr. President, I thank Mr. Šefčoovich, Vice-President of the Commission, also our colleagues, Mr. Kelly and Ms. Griffin, who have made a good report. It seems to me that while the debate is on whether to continue North Stream 2, whether we should jeopardise European security, make the EU dependent on Russian gas, we are doing this topic and bringing the topic of energy back to the centre, towards the citizen. We're putting citizens in the spotlight and it's really good that we're dealing with eradicating energy poverty.  I believe that the term prosumer, originating from producer and consumer, is a very good term that speaks of citizens needing to become aware, they should also become energy producers, but also users. I hope that the aim of this report is to seriously reduce the consumption of other energy sources, to put the economy in a state of exclusive use of renewable energy sources, and I consider this to be the goal of this report, and I hope that this is an ideal that we all need to aim for together.  In any case, energy policy should be directed towards consumers, not suppliers, they must be transparent. I hope that we can do this even after this report and I believe that the key is clean and safe energy.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Griffin, on her excellent work. I would like to point out that with this step we are giving shape and profile to the role of the European Parliament in the construction of the new retail electricity market. On the one hand, with market design, we rewrite the architecture of the wholesale electricity market, to overcome national distortions and favor a decentralized, flexible, competitive and eco-sustainable European market. On the other hand, with the Griffin report, we support the simplification of the retail regulatory framework, more and better information for consumers, exceeding tariffs for determination, stringent measures to combat energy poverty. In other words, we are put vulnerable consumers back at the centre of the debate, those who often have to decide between heating up and eating and who we cannot leave at the mercy of the big energy companies. It is no secret, in fact, that many European consumers pay inconvenient electricity tariffs because they are not adequately directed by operators towards the most advantageous tariff formulae. This practice must stop and I am optimistic that, with the contribution of the Griffin report, we will be able to add this piece to the wider mosaic of the construction of the Energy Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. - I have a simple question for you. Do you think that the problem of energy poverty is a problem to be addressed by the whole EU, by extension, the Commissioner, or is it the sole competence of the EU Member States?

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I think we can make our contribution as the European Union.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, the opinion from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) strongly welcomes the Commission’s proposed initiative on a new deal for energy consumers. Active and empowered consumers should be the main drivers of a competitive European energy market. The market is not really functioning well and is failing to provide competition and also better prices for consumers. So what is the cure for this? We must move away from regulated prices, make switching easier, and provide incentives for the deployment of smart technologies. Also, we must make data available for app developers to help consumers to manage their energy consumption. This is essential to get active consumers on board. One important point on consumers that we should not forget is that ‘active consumer’ does not mean a ‘presumer’, and not every consumer wants to be a presumer, so it should remain up to them what level of engagement they want in their energy consumption.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I am aware of our obligation to create a single energy market and, of course, the Energy Union is an ancient rest that the EU should have created. I am very glad that the Commissioner is taking a very active position on this matter. On the other hand, Commissioner, it is, in my opinion, really important to weigh heavily on the pharmaceutical weights that the EU will retain, that it will therefore regulate from the central EU level and thus, to some extent, interfere with the competence of nation states, and which will therefore be left to the very competence of sovereign nation states. In my opinion, it is really important to proceed de facto on those pharmacy scales in this matter. You have my full support in the fact that I firmly believe that you will succeed in this task.  In fact, when it comes to energy poverty, it does not tear my ears off if we say that energy poverty and access to energy is one of the fundamental social rights. I think that's justified nowadays.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I share the approach of putting citizens at the heart of the Energy Union with measures to enable consumers to save money on the energy bill and to facilitate competition and supplier change on an agile and free nature. The objectives agreed in Paris cannot be achieved if we do not place citizens at the basis of energy market efficiency. Citizens who produce their own energy should be treated fairly and not penalised with taxes or abusive charges, as has been the case in my country with the 'sun tax'. The fight against energy poverty must be a vital objective and affordable energy must be a basic social right. No one should have to choose between eating or paying for heating. The Commission should give priority to measures aimed at alleviating energy poverty in the forthcoming legislative proposals. And before tomorrow's vote, I ask those within this House for reflection contrary to these objectives.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, in Greece, Mr Šefčovič, where you were a few days ago, the energy costs for consumers are borne not by the lack of competition, but by the excessive taxes they have to pay, which is a great responsibility of the troika and the memoranda.  Energy poverty affects 36% of Greek households, according to a study by the European Parliament. Last winter, 100,000 households were found, or at risk of being found, without power. As if this 3rd Memorandum were not enough, it added excessive increases in taxes on heating oil and agricultural oil, increases that only manage to reduce the consumption and receipts of the state, while at the same time imposing energy security and burning of inappropriate materials for heating, which has led to smog in many parts of Greece.  For all this I have asked written questions, but I have not gotten an answer. In a debate at ITRE last January, Mr Cañete pledged to address the issue of overtaxation pan-European. What about it? Will you give clear and substantiated answers or will you continue to hide? I want an answer, please.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, according to surveys, 50 million EU citizens were unable to keep their homes adequately warm in 2012, with similar numbers reported making late payments, overpaying etc. Those consumers are all over the EU and, as a Liberal, my conviction is that European challenges need common European answers. Therefore, I support the Commission and the rapporteur to entrust coordination to an EU level to combat energy poverty. Three measures seem to be essential: the coordinated definition of energy poverty is needed, however you weight it in different countries; Member States need to develop measures to specially target energy—poor citizens, especially by removing the fee for switching suppliers; and better information on prices and transferred billings. These are found in the EU Member States with the most liberal energy markets. Consequently, I believe that the liberalisation of the energy market and the fight against energy poverty go hand in hand.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – We certainly agree that it is essential that the energy union tackles the problem of energy poverty, which is still plagued by more and more people within Europe. Energy poverty creates non-payers in the case of electricity. Whereas in the case of thermal energy, people are drowning with cheap and non-environmentally friendly fuels that harm both them and the environment. In this context, however, the common definition of energy poverty must also finally be approved with regard to the problem of energy poverty. There are currently different thresholds within member countries for determining when energy poverty can be discussed. A common definition will therefore allow us to harmonise the importance of this concept in individual countries in order to set precise parameters by which the incidence of energy poverty can be measured.  The aim of the Energy Union should therefore, above all, be to address this fundamental Pan-European phenomenon in order to create a safe and truly functioning energy market at the same time. I thank the rapporteur, I firmly believe that these things will not remain on paper alone.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to thank my colleague and fellow North—West Labour MEP Teresa Griffin for her report on a new deal for energy consumers. Completing the European Energy Union and lowering energy costs across the EU will have an enormous direct positive impact on British citizens, and it is yet another reason for us to vote to stay in the EU. I welcome the report’s recommendations on fighting energy poverty and I am here to stress that we must include a holistic gender perspective in all of these proposals. Single mother households are much more likely to face energy poverty than male—headed households. Energy and household costs are strongly linked to household indebtedness, which in turn plays a role in female homelessness. These are issues we need more European research on. Economic data on households is important, but household income can be unequal and vulnerable women or children can end up facing de facto poverty – in effect the feminisation of poverty – and this should also be taken into account when we define what energy poverty is.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, we finally have the right guidelines for creating a real European Energy Union. Namely, here we see a clear desire for decentralisation in relation to system centralisation, demonopolisation in relation to monopoly in systems, in Member States and also a clear commitment to more renewable energy sources in relation to fossil fuels.  Of course, this is why it is extremely necessary that consumers are in the forefront of the Energy Union guidelines in relation to suppliers. This is real proof that they are on the right track, because both on this occasion and in this report we see how important it is when we put citizens at the forefront, how we can then get their proper trust.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members for this very rich debate, where I think from one side we clearly highlighted how important are the problems we’ve been tackling in this evening’s debates and at the same time how complex the issue is with which we are dealing. I would like to tell you that I was listening very carefully to all the ideas which I think have been mostly recurring in the interventions of the honourable MEPs: how important it is to have a well-functioning market; how needed it would be to restore the real price signals of the energies; what we need to do to have our prices comparable; and what kind of focus we have to attach to crossborder trading, to the interconnectors and to the proper financing of the necessary infrastructure. I very much welcome the support for the democratisation of energy generation, and I agree with you that we still need to do well and ought to make sure that the third package in all our Member States is properly implemented.  I think there was an overall agreement that the best recipe to tackle energy poverty is to focus on energy efficiency, and today’s technologies are already offering us to do a lot to use the smart solutions, to smarten our grids, our households and to use the proper information to customise the services and empower our consumers. I also have been listening very carefully to all the calls from those who want the EU to do the most but at the same time to find the appropriate balance between Member States and European competences. I would like once again to thank the rapporteur for a very timely report because we are now working hard to deliver on the remaining proposals which he promised we would deliver these year – the year of delivery for the Energy Union. In September, we would like to present the package on energy efficiency. We want to include also proposals on how to make our buildings more energy efficient, and many of the proposals which we heard today will be reflected in our proposals for the new electricity market design and for the revised Renewables Directive which would follow later – hopefully before the end of the year.  Despite all these regulatory proposals and the legislative regulatory framework which we are going to create, what I think was also very much reflected in the statements by the honourable Members was the importance which they give to proper investment. We need the financial instruments. We need the investment so we can start this wave of energy efficiency across Europe.  We have already done a lot, because thanks to the budget allocations which have been already proposed, one million households will benefit from EU cohesion policy support to make their buildings more efficient. In this financial period, we will spend EUR 5.4 billion for energy efficiency investment in housing, which is a threefold increase in comparison with the previous period.  But the question is, is it enough? I think it’s not. So therefore I think we need to work on the new instruments, the instruments which we are currently developing in the Commission: smart financing for smart buildings, because I believe that this would play a very important role for the future. Another element which was echoed in the speeches of several honourable Members was that we need to offer more assistance and help to local authorities, to mayors, and to provide them with better technical assistance to help them to develop the necessary capacity, so they can tackle these very complex issues of smartening cities or increasing energy efficiency in their electoral district. And I am very happy to say that we feel we have very strong grassroots support from local authorities, from mayors, for this energy transition, for tackling energy poverty and for transforming their cities into the smart cities of the future. In the Covenant of Mayors we have already 6 000 mayors and we know how they appreciate working on this platform. We are looking for ways to cooperate even more closely with the Compact of Mayors, which is a similar organisation, which was developed in the United States to make sure that these big entities of mayors have more platforms and more possibilities to exchange best practices.  To conclude, I really would like to thank you for all the ideas, for the support for our work, and I believe that together we can really empower consumers in the energy market, and I think that through this it can make a real contribution in the fight against energy poverty. Thank you very much. I very much look forward to our close cooperation in the coming months.

name: Theresa Griffin
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues very much for their comments and I would particularly like to thank the Commissioner. We look forward to working closely with him. I really hope that the vote tomorrow in plenary will be positive, but I see that some political groups question the idea of a ban on unfair commercial practices, of the need for a social tariff for low—income citizens, and of peer—based comparison on bills, and are rowing back from the votes in committee. I am very disappointed in that. To those people voting against these issues, Ashley Fox – is Ashley still here, no he has gone – are you really prepared to go back to the UK and to your region to face your constituents and say that they still have to put up with aggressive doorstep or phone selling, especially your elderly residents? I don’t think so. Are other groups ready to say that you voted against social tariffs for low—income citizens? And are you really willing to tell that mother of three that she cannot be automatically told the amount of energy she is using and why she is paying for it? We have to end termination fees. We do not pay them in telecoms. Why on earth should our citizens pay for them in energy? And fantasy from UKIP as usual. This is about the exchange of best practice – as the Commissioner said – between European citizens and local authorities, between consumers, NGOs, and local organisations coming together to develop innovative projects.  The EU is not the problem here. It is part of the solution to eradicating energy poverty. We should be proud of a Europe of jobs and growth, a Europe that acts to protect its most vulnerable citizens. It is a scandal that we have 50 million citizens in energy poverty. I repeat that, in 2016 and beyond, no one should have to choose between heating and cooling or eating.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The joint debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, May 26, 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to stress that the Energy Union should provide citizens with stable, affordable, sustainable, efficient and sustainable energy, as well as high-quality energy-efficient products, services and buildings. The transformation of the energy system should aim at a more efficient, transparent, sustainable, competitive, stable, more decentralised and inclusive energy system that benefits society as a whole, ensures greater involvement of citizens, local and regional actors and communities and empowers them to produce, distribute and store energy from renewable sources themselves, or share responsibility for energy production, while protecting the most vulnerable individuals and ensuring access to energy efficiency measures and renewable energy. We therefore call on the Commission to analyse the issue of aggressive tax planning and tax evasion, which is primarily carried out by natural monopolies, such as distribution network operators, in the energy market. In addition, the Commission and the Member States should take the necessary measures to ensure that the benefits of increasing the capacity of national interconnectors are not borne by distribution system operators but directly by end-users. We also call for better coordination at EU level in order to combat energy poverty by sharing best practices in the Member States and by creating a broad, common but not quantitative definition of energy poverty, which emphasises the idea that access to affordable energy is a fundamental social right.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. – Our objective remains and is a top priority to operate a well-functioning energy market that is beneficial to citizens. I therefore believe that the objective of the third energy package is to create a truly competitive, transparent and consumer-friendly retail energy market.  Unfortunately, however, so far it has not been fully implemented by all the Member States. This is reflected in the high levels of concentration in the market, the non-transfer of wholesale reduction costs to retail prices and the low levels of supplier change and consumer satisfaction.  The objective of serving the consumer first and foremost remains stable.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – When we talk about the Energy Union and the development of competitive energy markets in Europe, we must make sure that consumers are at the centre of this strategy. They must be empowered in order to make them participate in demand response, thus saving money for their households and businesses. Innovative solutions to shift to a smart, efficient and sustainable energy system using modern technologies can unlock significant energy and budgetary savings for companies and citizens. It can also help to improve air quality, increase well-being for individuals and provide benefits to society as a whole; benefits also to the most vulnerable consumers.  Too often energy-poor consumers are living in inefficient accommodation and paying too much for energy. Instead, these vulnerable consumers should receive adequate safeguards, including preventing the disconnection of electricity and gas at critical times, and assistance to implement energy efficiency measures in their homes that can serve as long-term solution helping them to avoid energy poverty and in many cases improve their health and quality of life. Energy is essential and access to energy services is a basic social right. The Energy Union and the EU’s framework of energy legislation must keep this in its focus.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The current energy transition from a fossil fuel-based energy system to a renewable energy system should result in stable, sustainable, affordable energy and energy-efficient products and housing, and consumers should have an advantageous energy market for citizens. Reducing Hungary, saving energy and prioritising energy efficiency is the most effective and effective way of increasing security of supply that is so important to energy consumers. The parliamentary proposal currently under discussion places great emphasis on energy efficiency, protecting consumers from unfair practices and increasing the transparency and clarity of bills. For hungary, as a poor, export-oriented country with economically fetilable fossil fuels, it is particularly important to reduce energy consumption through energy efficiency measures by using innovative technologies and by developing a targeted approach and environmental awareness of social actors. Sustainable and secure energy systems should be established, which will also enhance the competitiveness of the economy. In addition to saving energy, all these measures have other positive effects – a healthier environment and quality of life, greater independence from energy.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Last December, I supported the directive, of which Mr Gróbarczyk was the rapporteur, as a balanced and serious proposal to identify the best compromise for the Commission and the Council, without succumbing to unrealistic 'ambitions' to 'defend' the climate, in the hope that it would become the basis for more realistic legislative proposals. What is needed is a rapid revaluation of the existing energy policy – an exaggerated, scientifically insufficiently documented so-called 'European climate policy' and a separation it from a real energy policy. It cannot continue to be shaped by lobbying from some countries and large gas and financial corporations. A genuine Energy Union should bring about such a change in the Climate and Energy Package, which would combat unfair competition between Member States and lead to increased competitiveness on world markets. I would like to stress once again that energy security, solidarity in supply and the fight against energy poverty while maintaining competitiveness on third markets, as well as the modernisation of infrastructure that would maximise energy efficiency and transparency in negotiating energy prices from third countries, as well as the use of local energy sources, including green coal burning technologies, should be a priority for the Energy Union. The greatest benefit for citizens (and a possible Energy Union) will be a complete move away from the existing EU ETS in favour of a system that is not as bureaucraticly confusing and conducive to speculation as the current one.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – The 'New direction for energy consumers' report is an important stage in achieving the objectives of the Energy Union. Ensuring stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy is in the national interest. The development of consumer-friendly, competitive and well-functioning energy markets is key, and full implementation of the third energy package is essential to achieve these objectives. As the report emphasises, adequate consumer information is a prerequisite for energy-conscious behaviour. As a result, improving the transparency of invoices and ensuring comparability of service provider accounts is in our common interest – as this can lead to lower overhead costs. It is particularly practical for consumers to create up-to-date and easy-to-understand comparison tools and interfaces and to provide information on these options. After all, ensuring switching is an essential condition for competition. Although I do not fully agree with all the points in the report, the direction is good and should be supported.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, as a result of the general state of the European economy, the prices of the most necessary goods and services have increased significantly, leading to difficulties for hundreds of European citizens, especially those belonging to vulnerable groups – the elderly and the unemployed. According to Eurostat, 40% of the population of Bulgaria is not able to keep their homes sufficiently heated. This is due, on the one hand, to factors such as low population incomes and low energy efficiency of buildings and, on the other hand, to the lack of diversity of actors in the energy market, leading to high energy prices. The need for an effective and comprehensive energy strategy is therefore more pressing than ever. Consumer rights must be a focus of our efforts by limiting regulated pricing, improving energy efficiency by reducing energy consumption and improving energy infrastructure, providing an open and competitive market as a prerequisite for reducing energy poverty.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Energy poverty affects a large share of the world’s population. Within the EU 11% of the population is not able to adequately heat their homes at an affordable cost and energy poverty affects around 54 million people (2012 figures). The problem is particularly prevalent in Central, Eastern and Southern Europe. At the global scale the climate agreement achieved in Paris as well as the Sustainable Development Goals adopted last autumn (SDG 7 in particular, ‘ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all’) contribute to an enhanced cooperation in this field.  Yet the EU should make sure these global commitments are translated into actions. Combatting energy poverty requires a complex and pragmatic approach. Many EU member states do not assess energy poverty properly, they do not even identify vulnerable consumers, making it impossible to adequately target measures. Energy efficiency improvements in low-income and vulnerable households should be strongly incentivized. Raising awareness and enabling informed decisions would be also important.  Besides, the European Commission should allocate a much higher share of EU funds to energy efficiency programmes for vulnerable, energy-poor households and it should provide recommendations to its Member States on improved monitoring and on specific energy poverty measures.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The debate on energy poverty is constantly being mixed up with the general debate on renewable energy. This is factually incorrect and requires the following clarifications: (1) If price spikes are allowed in renewables, then conventional power plants are needed, which provide capacities as a back-up. This secures demand and protects customers at risk of poverty. (2) It is not the energy source per se that harms disadvantaged customers, but unfair marketing practices, which lead to a loss of trust and ultimately reduce individual commitment. In principle, it can be said that the more competitive the energy market is, the better for consumers. The increasing number of customers switching their energy provider is proof of this. The options for making customers more involved in the market should be as broad and standardised as possible. Joint exchange campaigns and standards for the invoice layout are in addition to apps, brochures, hotlines, one-stop shops, etc. opportunities to involve consumers more closely. Regulated requirements, on the other hand, are hindering. Similarly, there should be no subsidies, both for switch campaigns and for in-house production.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. – The aim is to enable citizens to produce, use and store and trade their own energy individually or collectively. Citizens must have the right to active participation in the energy market as well as the right of consumer choice and demand management. The introduction of smart 10s would help consumers reduce their energy costs and improve energy efficiency.  The growing problem in the European Union is increasingly becoming energy poverty, affecting some 54 million Europeans who are unable to adequately heat the space in which they live or achieve some other energy services at an affordable price. Well-targeted social tariffs are important for vulnerable citizens. The application of social tariffs should be transparent and member states' good practices should be highlighted and recommended to others.  The realisation of new benefits for energy consumers will contribute to eradicating energy poverty and better engaging citizens in the energy market as consumers who manage their own consumption and have the right to choose.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – Firstly, secure and reliable sources of supply are needed to create a viable energy union in order to achieve a well-integrated and well-connected energy market. Genuine liberalisation of the EU internal market is directly linked to the diversification of sources of supply. The EU needs to step up investment in the Eastern Mediterranean corridor to alleviate dependence on Russian gas in Southeast Europe. I also stress the geostrategic importance of the Black Sea region for the EU's energy security, in particular for the development of multilateral energy cooperation in the Caspian Sea region, the Middle East and Central Asia. On the other hand, the Commission must come up with the necessary legislative proposals to enable consumers to have control over energy costs and to have access to the full real costs of electricity delivered, including those associated with transport and distribution. Last but not least, I consider it necessary to create a reconfigured wholesale/retail market model in order to avoid a situation where, in the long term, regulated tariffs would harm the interests of domestic consumers, instead of protecting them.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Eradicating energy poverty is one of Europe's most pressing tasks in the 21st century. While around 50 million people in Europe live in energy poverty, statistics show that one in five households, or up to two million people, live in Hungary. This situation is unsustainable, which has not been solved in Hungary by the policy of official pricing, i.e. 'reduction of overheads'. The average Hungarian household uses energy per square metre, almost twice the EU average. On this basis, the energy poverty of a quarter of Hungarian households is not caused by high energy prices in relation to income alone, but in large part by the low level of energy efficiency in buildings. We need to change that as soon as possible. It is unacceptable for someone in 2016 not to be able to heat their home, bathe in cold water, turn on their reading light or charge their mobile phone. Therefore, in my opinion, we must guarantee in EU legislation the minimum supply of energy, the fundamental right to energy, which is a subjective right for all citizens. At the same time, we need well-targeted social energy tariffs for those most in need. In the medium term, the solution is to start up its own energy production, i.e. 'home', to support the uptake of domestic windmills and solar panels, and to support large-scale energy efficiency improvement programmes.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Consumers must be able to obtain adequate information on the cheapest prices for energy, the possibility of better comparing different offers and certainly the right to exchange suppliers quickly, easily and free of charge. It is also necessary to address the causes of energy poverty by using EU funds and self-production subsidies for low-income and vulnerable citizens.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – Considering new benefits for energy consumers, while supporting new models that contribute to a greater diversity of energy market participants and thereby stimulating the growth of the local economy and employment, especially at local level, we must not forget those who are on the fringes of society and their own livelihoods. Unfortunately, energy poverty is a growing problem across the EU, with a European Commission study showing that 11% of the EU population is unable to heat their households at affordable prices. It is estimated that this situation affects about 54 million people. The problem is particularly pronounced in eastern and southern EU Member States, where in 2012 the largest share of the population at risk of energy poverty was recorded in Romania (40-50%), while in Croatia this share is estimated at 30-40 %. Together with Cyprus, Latvia, Romania and Slovenia, 36-48% of the population cannot afford to pay their bills regularly, which says a lot about energy availability. These problems are due to rising energy prices, low incomes and poorly energy efficient homes. A large number of EU countries do not identify vulnerable consumers so they cannot adequately target measures against energy poverty. This situation needs to change.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – Given its irreplaceable role in all the activities of everyday life, I consider energy to be an important asset that should enable every citizen to live with dignity indiscriminately. It is gratifying that, in Europe, the former problems with energy availability have largely been solved, but on the other hand, I am concerned about the global situation where, for 1.2 billion people, electricity is still inaccessible and 2.8 billion people are still using wood or other types of biomass to heat their dwelling or cooking. Although some progress has already been made in the field of energy in Europe, energy poverty is nevertheless manifested by a growing number of people (over 50 million) who have problems with energy payment or for which energy is only available to a limited extent because they have a low income, their apartment is un insulated, they have low-performance equipment (heating, cooking, heating hot water heating) or energy prices are very high. As I consider this to be unacceptable, I agree with the introduction of a system in the EU that ensures that overall costs are kept low and that the deficit caused by electricity rates does not increase further. I believe that the measures taken will protect all citizens in no way from energy poverty and prevent their social exclusion.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Energy poverty is a real problem that affects also public health. The Commission has the obligation to address this issue in its specific legislative proposals. On the other hand, Member States have to take the necessary measures to ensure that all the population has access to energy sources, they do not pay excessive electricity and gas bills, and do not have to choose between basic needs that they can afford to satisfy. It is not just at EU level, but at national and regional levels as well that we need to see more action with regard to the eradication of energy poverty. We need transparency in order for the population to make informed choices regarding their energy consumption, and we need as well EU funds to be allocated for energy efficiency and for programmes to support self-generation of energy.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – In recent years, Europe's energy sector has undergone significant transformations. However, more than 50 million EU citizens live in energy poverty because there are still elements that prevent consumers from taking full advantage and having significant control over their consumption and thus reducing the amounts on their bills. This is an increasingly difficult social problem, which requires an urgent resolution and which should be dealt with as far as possible directly through social policy measures. A common European approach is needed, aimed at removing imbalances and inequalities in the market in order to find sustainable solutions for consumers and for our industry to access energy at affordable prices. I consider the Commission's approach to identifying, taking and supporting the Commission's approach to being adequately identified, taken into account and supported, actively involving local participants. At the same time, the role of the consumer needs to change so that he can better and faster benefit from energy offers and services by taking advantage of them.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Aside from efficiency gains, the raison d'être of our Energy Union is to guarantee security of supply, in other words energy security. Russia has demonstrated on countless occasions that it is not a reliable partner to the European Union, and that it does not hesitate to wield energy as a political weapon. This is precisely why we should not increase our own dependency on Russian gas by doubling the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline.  Furthermore, we would be helping Russia in destabilising Ukraine. The current Nord Stream pipeline is only used at half of its existing capacity; therefore, doubling its capacity makes no economic sense. This is clear evidence that the only reason to double the capacity is to be able to reroute all the gas that is transiting through Ukraine. Not only would this have disastrous consequences for Ukraine, but it would put eastern European Union Member States in a more precarious position since we do not have sufficient interconnections for that gas to make its way from Germany back to eastern Member States.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – Mr President, the issue of energy is one of the most important in the European Union. This is also an important issue for EU citizens, especially those who live in the new Member States. Eu policy in this sector should move towards the introduction of regulation aimed at lowering energy prices, particularly for households and not for industry. It is ordinary people and families who feel the energy costs in their budget. This they should be best protected. The energy market needs to create a truly competitive, transparent and user-friendly system for retail consumers. In addition, in order to combat energy poverty effectively, Member States must fully implement the provisions relating to switching. National legislation must ensure that consumers are entitled to a quick and easy replacement of the service provider without incurring additional charges. In order to protect consumers, in particular those most vulnerable, it is necessary to introduce proper implementation and enforcement of rules on unfair commercial practices and consumer rights in relation to related sales, unfair terms or aggressive marketing practices. Let us remember that, in a well-functioning energy system, local authorities, cooperatives and individuals should be encouraged to become energy producers if they so wish. This is a project of the future that we should, as the EU, support, because it can certainly help stabilise energy prices.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – Energy poverty has been increasingly threatening our citizens in recent years. In the fight against it, we must enable access to affordable and safe energy. It is important to support the development of domestic energy sources, which will increase the competitiveness of the EU economy. I believe that Member States should make greater efforts to find a solution for energy independence. They should invest more resources in the production of own energy and the development of energy technology through alternative, renewable sources. Moreover, we must not forget the renewal of the existing energy infrastructure, which will also have an impact on the development of new jobs.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: A brief description of Maria Arena's report: Poverty: Gender Equality (2015/2228(INI)) (A8-0153/2016).

name: Maria Arena
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, finally, these two debates that follow touch on issues that are very close and which are linked to the issue of poverty. We talked about energy poverty. Here, if it is more specifically the approach to poverty in a gendered way. What is the poverty situation of women in Europe? Today, unfortunately, more than 64 million women live in poverty in Europe. 48% of them - single women - are unable to meet unexpected expenses. These single women are seen as more vulnerable to poverty. Single-parent families in which women are the head of household more often than men are also at greater risk of poverty and social exclusion, resulting in a vicious cycle of poverty for their children and families. Today, 27% of European children are at risk of poverty. This represents 22 million children in poverty. We have seen that austerity measures, which are often indiscriminate austerity measures, taken in recent years in Europe, have increased inequalities and also the risks of poverty for women and children. The wage gap persists today. We also have the issue of the working poor, precarious statuses and, finally, the pension gap, which represents a gap of 39% and which poses risks of poverty for the oldest people and women. Is it necessary to recall that the europe 2020 strategy aims to reduce the number of people at risk of poverty by at least 20 million? We are a long way from that today. We must break the cycle of poverty, which now affects 127 million people in Europe, including 22 million children. And you should know that, especially with regard to adults, women are more affected by this cycle. Finally, we made a series of recommendations to ensure that this cycle of poverty can be broken. The first recommendation calls for quality public services and free access to education, health and justice. It has indeed been shown that, when public services are of good quality and have a good first line of good quality, there is better efficiency and redistribution of wealth, which is a real social safety net to fight poverty. The second recommendation is the fight against discrimination in employment, which is a source of poverty for women. We therefore call for coordination of parental leave - maternity leave, paternity leave and parental leave - to combat such precarious situations experienced in precarious contracts by women. The third recommendation: an important reflection on minimum income as an instrument in the fight against poverty. We therefore do not ask in the report today that there may be a minimum income, although this could have been the case, but we are asking for it so that there should be an analysis of minimum income systems throughout Europe and identify good practices in this area as a tool to combat poverty. A fourth claim: when you know little about the phenomenon, you can less well provide the solutions. We therefore call for a more reliable statistical follow-up of the issue of gendered poverty in Europe today. We also call for a child guarantee system, as we have been able to obtain in terms of the 'youth' guarantee, that is, where there are significant outbreaks of poverty in Europe today, it is essential to provide budget lines and specific actions to combat child poverty in particular. Finally, we are asking - and this is in connection with the report that was discussed just before - social tariffs for basic goods, such as access to energy and water, which effectively prevents people from falling into this poverty trap. Finally, we are asking that there be tax incentives to fight poverty. I thank all of these recommendations for all of these recommendations, all the members who participated in the development of this report. It was a very constructive discussion and I hope that tomorrow it can be voted on by a large majority. This would send an important signal to the Commission.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – The report on gender poverty provides important data from which it is clear that even in European society, more women remain at risk of poverty than men are at risk of poverty.  In particular, the report cites labour market discrimination and pay discrimination as the reason. This is the sixth report in 2016 that deals with a similar subject and unfortunately does not bring, in my opinion, any new better solutions. I believe that there is another discrimination. Children's parents are discriminated against because they care for their children instead of saving and making money and putting money into pension funds. I think that mothers and fathers who care for children are discriminated against because society does not recognise this work as socially beneficial, and as long as this approach persists, these women and parents will still be discriminated against.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – This report provides a set of pectoral facts showing that women are also the most vulnerable and vulnerable group in society from the point of view of social deprivation. In the past, I have also made initiatives to ensure that, from a law enforcement and judicial point of view, women are automatically given priority protection throughout the Union, in addition to other groups particularly vulnerable to crime, such as children and the elderly. In the spirit of today's debate, I think it is appropriate to apply this type of preference with similar naturalness and automatism in the social and labour field. Along the lines of similar facts and arguments in many respects, it would be worth uniting our efforts.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Poverty and the situation of women are key social issues. We know this well in Poland, because at the moment we are introducing a pioneering family assistance program that will greatly improve the situation of women. I just don't understand why the extreme left is involved in our report on such important issues, which is nothing short of what we are talking about. Why do we in this report ask European countries to recognise LGBTI families? What are families? What kind of families are they talking about? What is a bisexual family? What is an intersex family? In which European country are such phenomena recognised? Because this is not the case, for example, mariage pour tous. After all, these are things that we have not defined at all. All this shows that we are dealing with a revolution that is supposed to destroy the world in which we grew up and to which we owe our freedom.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, poverty in Europe still has a woman's face. We access the labour market in worse conditions and with more difficulties. We earn less, and that gap is reflected in our pensions. We almost alone take care of the family and household chores, and they are wasted, because of gender, talent and capabilities that it is a luxury to do without. That is why I are adphasing procedures and policies to ensure a decent income for all European women and their access to health and education.  More women in economic decision-making centres ensure better governance, more profitability in business, a feminine view of the labour market, lower female poverty and a better future for minors, for whom we also support a European guarantee.  That is why I strongly reject the cuts that austerity imposes on these programmes, which should be considered an investment. That is why I am defending this Resolution, this 'essential revolution', on which I am not talking about memory, because the Basque Country ranks fifth in the European gender equality index thanks to the implementation of some of these measures.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the European Union can no longer conceal the consequences of its neoliberal policies. The impoverishment of peoples is just one of the faces of the implementation of austerity policies, memoranda, economic governance of the European Semester.  It follows that today 25 % of the population of the European Union to 28 is at risk of poverty before social benefits, more than 120 million citizens. Policies that aggravated inequalities and social exclusion, with a particular impact on women, which were consummated in attacks on the social role of the State, destroying and privatizing public services, attacking workers' rights and collective hiring.  Combating social inequalities, poverty, discrimination against women and raising their economic and social status can only be through the breakdown with exploitation policies, the appreciation of wages, labour regulation and security and collective bargaining, the increase in the supply of free and quality public services in the areas of health, education, social security , among others.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the author of the report, because I think it is a necessary and courageous report. A very important report that sends us a very clear message. Austerity policies have been terrible, austerity policies - let's not forget – directed from the European Commission. And they've been even more terrible for women. Women are much more vulnerable to the closure of public services, education, health, social services and justice. They suffer much more, and this shows that this equality of which we are so happy in the European Union is really just a mirage. There's no equality. There is a lot of way to go, and we are talking about millions of people, millions of women who feel discriminated against and who suffer more because equality policies stay on paper, stay in theory and do not apply. I hope that tomorrow this will be adopted with great scope and that those recommendations in the report will be taken into account by the European Commission.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, it is good to see the European Parliament debating gender discrimination and poverty tonight, although you would think they might have allocated more than five minutes for such an important debate. I note, for example, that all of the top seven EU jobs are currently held by men, so the EU certainly has a little bit of a way to go in this respect, whereas the UK has, of course, led the way in many of these issues – for example in science and research, where the UK leads the way in terms of having 6 of the top 25 universities in the world , but also the percentage of women in science and research jobs are much higher than across the European Union.  We had our Equal Pay Act in 1970 – three years before we even joined the European Union, and well before the European Union legislated. We have 52 weeks of maternity leave guaranteed in UK law, compared with the EU requirement of 14. In fact, EU rules put car insurance premiums for women up by GBP 300 a year. So is the EU really part of the solution, or is it actually part of the problem?

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – I wanted to point out, first of all, that a colleague said that there are 120 million poor people living in Europe, and the rapporteur said that there are 29 million women living in poverty. It follows that there are 91 million men living in poverty, and I do not know why we are dealing with women. But not in this thing: I wanted to say that single women live in poverty, because they were not taught to be good mothers, they were not taught to be good wives, only in schools they were taught completely unnecessary things, among other things, they were taught their gender theory.

name: Maria Arena
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, our colleague has not been paying attention to the figures. Out of a total of 120 million women, 64 million now live in poverty. The 27 million were for poor children in Europe.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Madam Vice President, thank you very much for giving me your word for being the shadow rapporteur on this report. Mrs Arena and I have worked very well together and this report contains a number of good things concerning women's poverty and the causes of women's poverty. The data is really alarming.  However, unfortunately, despite our well-working efforts, we have failed to reach compromises and neither I nor my group will be able to support this report because it contains a number of sensitive topics that should not be the subject of this report, which are not directly or indirectly related to the causes of women's poverty, and these are items that are not in line with the values inherited by the European People's Party nor are they related to the causes of women's poverty.  In particular, I refer to subsidiarity and some topics that I really don't think should have been part of this report. This is why we will not be able to support this report, although we are in a state of elimination of the causes of women's poverty.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – We have been dealing with poverty in the European Union for many years, with this problem, with social exclusion, and in our political group we are committed, of course, against all forms of poverty. But the fact is that women are more at risk and still quite discriminated against, so it is right that we deal with them in particular. Some parts of the report are very good and I will be able to support them. However, I find it unacceptable that we are repeatedly entering ideological themes in resolutions that have a good purpose and need them. This is really unacceptable. We need to shape labour market policies in such a way that equal opportunities are guaranteed for all in employment, social security, wages and everywhere else. No discrimination is good – not negative, not positive. However, since you have also ignored the principle of subsidiarity, as other colleagues have already said and pointed out, we will not be able to support this report.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I’d like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Ms Arena, for her report on gender inequality in the world of work and on the implications that this has for our society. I would also like to thank her for setting out the recommendations in the report so clearly. While the female employment rate has increased to just above 64% in 2015, women’s lower earnings and under—representation in the labour market continues to mean that their financial situation is less secure than men’s. As we heard, many more women than men are living in poverty in the EU and – as she explained – the risk of poverty is especially high among single mothers, and also among older women. Women’s lower pay and the fact that they often do part—time work and take gaps in their careers often leads to gender pension gaps; women’s pensions are 40% lower than men’s and, of course, women are less likely to have a pension at all. In June last year, the Council agreed some conclusions on the gender pension gap, and these called for work to continue to narrow this gap, and for Member States’ social and employment policies to be assessed as part of the European Semester process.  Last December, the Commission published a strategic engagement for gender equality that set out the overall framework for European initiatives that were aimed at improving gender equality and, in that, priority areas included increasing the numbers of women in work, reducing the gender pay gap and the pension gap, and also making women more financially independent. We continue to keep a close eye on these issues and we have provided country specific recommendations to those that face the greatest challenges. As set out in your report, adequate work—life balance policies are needed so that women who want to can play a full part in the labour market. Last year, the Commission launched a ‘new start’ initiative to improve work—life balance for parents and other people caring for family members. That looks at a range of measures to promote adequate leave and flexible working arrangements and to support affordable professional care services. The second phase of the consultation will be launched shortly, on the legislative parts of the ‘new start’ initiative, and my colleagues will be tabling proposals on that by the end of the year.  The Commission’s plans to create a European pillar of social rights have gender equality also at their heart. The draft pillar that’s now been agreed for wider consultation puts the emphasis on improving the situation of women in the labour market. I think that fairness, which lies at the heart of this report, is central to the Commission’s agenda, and the principle that no one should be left behind will continue to drive forward our work to support greater gender equality in Europe.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, May 26, 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Eurostat figures show that the number of women living in poverty is consistently higher than that of men, with currently around 64.6 million women and 57.6 million men. It is also clear, as my colleague Arena's resolution reminds us, that austerity policies have only exacerbated this gap in recent years.  In particular, the resolution stresses the priority of setting working conditions conducive to family life. MEPs also call on the Commission, in close coordination with Member States, to take comprehensive and comprehensive legislative action to meet the needs of mothers and fathers regarding different types of leave. The resolution also stresses the major importance of public care and quality services, in particular in promoting the integration of socially marginalized groups of women.  With regard to the fight against women's poverty in particular, the resolution calls for the development of the social pricing and assistance mechanisms of the poorest, the empowerment of girls in social, economic, cultural and political life, or the active promotion of a positive image of the mothers employed and combating the phenomenon of "penalization of motherhood" identified by several studies.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The European Union simply cannot conceal the consequences of its neoliberal policies. The impoverishment of workers and peoples is just one of the faces of the implementation of so-called austerity policies, memoranda, economic governance, the European Semester. The other is capitalist accumulation and concentration, the fattening of monopolies. 25% of the EU-28 population is at risk of poverty before social benefits, more than 120 million citizens. EU policies have exacerbated inequalities and social exclusion, with a particular impact on women: attacks on the social role of the state, destroying and privatising public services, attacking workers' rights and collective bargaining. Combating social inequalities, poverty, discrimination against women and raising their economic and social status can only be the break with exploitation policies, the appreciation of wages, labor rights and security, collective bargaining, the increase in the supply of free and quality public services in the areas of health, education, social security , among others, which requires a clear break with EU policies.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – After years of austerity as an ineffective recipe for combating the economic crisis, there is finally a much need to focus much more on the needs of the most vulnerable. In terms of the threat of poverty, such a group are demonstrably women. At the same time, combating their poverty is a question of social justice. At the same time, effective measures to improve the standard of living of women–mothers reduce the threats of child poverty. The persistent problem is the indefensiblely high pay gap compared to men, which on average are close to almost 20%. This, in turn, translates even more significantly into different levels of pensions. Women also have more than a third less. This is indeed a vicious circle that must finally be cut. In doing so, measures must be positively targeted towards women. At both European and national level, we must go down the path of fixed priorities with clear, enforceable penalties in the event of non-compliance. Otherwise, injustices about women's pay will persist for decades to come.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – The economic crisis and austerity policies have increased the number of people exposed to poverty and social exclusion, affecting more women (64.6 million) than men (57.6 million). Women remain overrepresented in precarious work, are forced into career interruptions to care for their children and other dependents in the absence of effective rules of work-life balance, occupy worse-renumbered positions, often as a result of sexist stereotypes, and top up part-time jobs , not by free choice, but rather forced by the need to have to care for their relatives. In addition, there is a wage gap that remains and is very difficult to eradicate. All this means that women receive lower pay than men, which also translate into lower pensions. To combat female poverty, urgent action is needed to improve conciliation, combat stereotypes, reduce the pay gap and facilitate the integration and permanence of women in the labour market.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – The results of statistics inform us about a number of interesting things. Historically, several more boys have always been born, but the mortality rate among boys is higher than among girls, and therefore, already at a relatively early age, their numbers are equal. Women, virtually everywhere in the world, have significantly longer life expectancies in 2014 in 2014. In developed ies, in so-called rich countries, we see that women are more educated than men. Yet inequality in family care and the associated inequality in employment progression remain. This phenomenon also results in a greater risk of poverty among women than in men, at all ages. In recent years, we have seen a new phenomenon in many countries – working poverty. The fact that even in some EU countries the minimum wage falls short of the social emergency threshold is a clear indictment of the current economic system. Capitalism, which incites free competition, is unable to solve the problem of poverty. Despite all the measures, whether social investment or legislative steps to make men and women equal in the labour market, the increased threat to women remains a fact. The motion for a resolution seeks to bring positive proofreading to this poorly functioning system. Although it does not address the substance of the problem, the motion for a resolution is supported by the GUE Group.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. – In this period of financial crisis, and especially in the countries that have been impoverished by the Memorandums, women are the biggest victims, since their rights are affected every day at both social and labour level.  According to recent Eurostat data, the number of women in poverty exceeds that of men, with 64.6 million women in poverty compared to 57.6 million men. More generally, women in most EU Member States are more affected than men - especially when it comes to mothers and pensioners, while they are over-represented in part-time and precarious jobs.  In order to end gender inequalities and reduce high poverty rates, the EU should put an end to its austerity policies in its member countries. Indeed, the violent fiscal adjustment implemented in Greece by the Third Memorandum further deepens gender inequalities and irreparably affects women's rights.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. – Whereas the phenomenon of poverty significantly affects more women than men – 64.6 million women suffer in Europe – and aware that gender inequality, as well as discriminating against women, is a brake on growth and economic development, and assesses the growing inequality caused by the economic crisis and austerity policies, which particularly affects the most vulnerable groups , we strongly support the Arena report. With this vote, therefore, we are emphasising the importance of the gender perspective in the determination of social measures. In particular, we note the strong need for the inclusion of women during the training and professional phases. It is with dismay that we note that the higher rates of schooling and academic success of women result in lower employment rates and wage levels than men. The pension gap between the two genders is also the result of much more fragmented careers for women workers, forced, in a hostile environment, to juggle professional careers and family care. The Member States and the European Union must acknowledge the lack of progress and step up their efforts to ensure equal opportunities and social justice for all, regardless of gender.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. – The ongoing austerity policies of recent years in the social field and the gender pay gap that still exists are placing a particular burden on Europe's women, making them the biggest losers in the economic crisis. The fact is that around 65 million women are affected by poverty and social exclusion across the EU, compared with 58 million men. Poverty in Europe is female. We must take specific measures here, identify the main triggers of female poverty in concrete terms and combat them effectively. The adopted report by my Socialist colleague Maria Arena sets the course for the effective fight against female poverty, which must be implemented if we are to solve this problem at European level.
