One thing is important, above all: to boost investment in social infrastructure. Especially in the area of childcare and caring for relatives, there is an increased need for financial resources in order to be able to relieve women effectively. Equal opportunities are also of fundamental importance here, because full access for all to high-quality public education and services must also be ensured. Europe must now take active action to stop the poverty cycle of the next generations and their children. Strengthening women's rights must mean achieving equality, but also guaranteeing equal opportunities and protection against gender poverty. That is why: My full support for the report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. In the European Union, poverty affects more women than men. In fact, 64.6 million women suffer from it, compared to 57.6 million men. It is also important to note that single-parent families are more vulnerable to poverty and social exclusion. The economic crisis and the various austerity policies that have followed in recent years have only exacerbated the situation by exacerbating inequality.  To break this dynamic, it is now essential that working conditions conducive to family life, such as adaptable working hours and the possibility of telework, be put in place to ensure that women can be as active as men in the labour market. I also call for European legislative action to be able to meet the needs of fathers and mothers on different types of leave, be it maternity leave, paternity leave, parental leave and leave for carers.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I strongly support the call for the European Commission to carry out an impact assessment of EU minimum income schemes and to consider further measures. These measures must also include an analysis of the situation and a proposal for measures in the area of minimum national pensions, which should not be below the at-risk-of-poverty threshold.  The growing impoverishment of the elderly population (especially older women) requires immediate measures to give the elderly to the poor with human dignity and a decent quality of life. Poverty among older generations is also directly linked to the labelling of the elderly as a cost to society, which is only a major financial - budgetary problem for local communities, Member States and the European Union.  It is therefore the duty of political decision-makers to say NO to this type of stigmatising of older people and finally approach decision-making, which will benefit intergenerational respect and ensure a calmer age even for younger generations today. Dear Sirs, the time has come when we will also have to speak more decisively about a more binding document aimed at protecting the rights of the elderly internationally.  The call for Member States to take decisions on minimum pensions therefore, in my opinion, also represents an important contribution to the thinking that older people are a vulnerable social group, whose rights must also be protected at European Union level and beyond.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. With this own-initiative report, the Committee on Women's Affairs of the European Parliament insults all people and families who actually live in great poverty. This is not about the fight against poverty, but about ideological education by the EU. This is also demonstrated by the rapporteur's self-image: she does not even even consider the basic principle of 'help for self-help' in the fight against poverty. Combating poverty for women is just a pretext here, because the Committee on Women does not concern the poorest in their entirety, but preferably lesbian, bisexual and transgender women and their sexual orientation or gender identity in connection with social policies.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: A brief description of Daniel Dalton's report: Non-tariff barriers to the single market (2015/2346(INI)) (A8-0160/2016).

name: Daniel Dalton
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the single market has been a significant achievement. It’s more integrated than India’s market and that’s not bad considering we have got 28 countries. But although tariffs have gone, non—tariff barriers (NTBs) still exist. We need a proper single market that delivers for consumers and for all businesses. At the moment the single market works for big businesses. They have the economies of scale and the wealth to get around barriers to trade that small companies do not – they just give up. As I’ve gone around my constituency from Stratford to Stoke, small businesses tell me that they often find it much easier to trade with Canada or the US than they do with France or Germany. Artificial barriers and red tape block the free movement of goods and services. So they give up and we lose that trade, and then they watch big companies come in and take over that trade. This fuels a feeling that Europe is just for big business and not for the little guys.  At the same time, consumers lose out. They don’t get a wider choice of products or lower prices through economies of scale that the single market should give them. We know the problem and we’ve been trying to solve it for years, but we haven’t looked at it from the perspective of international trade. It is sometimes forgotten in this house that trading in another EU country is still international trade and it involves different rules, different regulations and different languages. This is what this report is about. It is trying to identify technical barriers to trade within the internal market. Now the term ‘non—tariff barriers’ is well—known in international trade, but it’s fair to say that we had quite a lot of discussion about what it is and what it isn’t within this house, and the definition was tricky to agree on. But one thing that isn’t a non—tariff barrier is workers and social rights. Let’s be clear about that. These apply to everyone in a country and they are non—discriminatory. Nor is it an NTB when governments legislate for legitimate public policy reasons, but their actions should be proportionate. So it is not a non—tariff barrier if an action is proportionate, non—discriminatory and serves a legitimate public policy objective. But protectionism isn’t fair; it kills jobs, it kills growth and it kills competitiveness and it penalises consumers. It exists in a variety of sectors within Europe, and we would challenge third countries if they employed such methods.  Now I believe in competition, and I believe in different economic and regulatory models in EU countries is a good thing as it allows countries to have competitive advantages. This isn’t about harmonization, but where there are problems we’ve got to highlight them, and we found problems in a number of sectors, including retail, construction and professional services, to name a few, and we need to address them. Lack of mutual recognition of testing on goods or professional qualifications is a key example. Do taps really need to be tested 28 times to be sold in 28 different EU countries? Why are British kit cars with type approvals not allowed to be sold in Belgium, for example? Why is does a UK hairdresser with 30 years’ experience have to train for 4 years to be a hairdresser in Germany? It makes no sense. Why does an Austrian ski instructor have to retrain to be an instructor in France? It makes no sense. Why does an online betting company have to have an offline establishment to trade in another country? Why are there fees on global income for supermarkets in Eastern Europe which only hit foreign companies. These are Europeans blocking other Europeans; there’s no solidarity here at all.  Now we don’t need new legislation. We need a change in mindset in national ministries and we need better and clearer enforcement of single market rules by the Commission. We need more collaboration between Member States and we’ve identified these gaps in the report with regard to goods, but I think it’s in services where there are real problems. The notification regime under the Services Directive is a prime example of where Member States have not matched their commitments. The single market should be a partnership between countries and their governments should commit with their actions.  As we’ve seen with this report, Parliament is fully behind this objective, and I hope the Commission is too. It won’t be easy but it’s in all our long—term interests, and I hope this report will provide a new impetus to tear down barriers and create a free single market that delivers for businesses – both big and small – for consumers and for workers.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I would address the aspect of competition within the single internal market, as my speecher also mentioned.  In my opinion, this is precisely the point where we must consistently insist on our values, on the procedures and rules that apply in the EU. I believe that if not only the big companies, but also the small ones, are to be generally competitive, then we must insist on the values of competitive competition. I must say that, unfortunately, on this subject, I feel that even the European Commission is lagging behind to some extent, because, for example, yesterday it was announced that the European Commission had authorised the merger of two world beer producers, number two, in a way that defines some breweries that have to be squeezed out of this joint venture. This means creating 30% of the world's beer production giant. I do not know if this is in line with economic policy and single market policy.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – This report has once again made us realen that, in the way of reducing non-tariff barriers, there are governments serving the interests of producers with great economic and political influence, which often see the often arbitrary use of non-tariff barriers as a kind of political and tactical tool. Of course, the principle of common sense and subsidiarity also require that the use of non-tariff instruments in justified cases, timeframes and places be possible in the future. However, it is time to focus on the interests of local small and medium-sized enterprises and consumers throughout the EU, including promoting healthy, quality and price competition. The frustrating, decades-long backlog in limiting non-tariff barriers can only be filled by such a social and politically supported approach to trade policy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the single European market has greatly strengthened the large enterprises and industries of the North. In fact, they have not invested their profits in the countries of the European South in order to develop and reduce public deficits and debts.  At this juncture today, with Germany's record surpluses on the one hand and the huge deficits caused by these very surpluses in the South on the other, non-tariff barriers are the last embankment for many professional sectors in the South before their total disappearance. Therefore, the only thing that further deregulation under discussion will achieve is the rapid increase in disparities between Member States.  The myth that deregulation stimulates growth and increases jobs must finally be stopped. The political decisions of the European Union cannot be directed with myths. Non-tariff barriers and restrictions are tools for states to control and direct their economies independently. Subsidiarity and respect for multi-level governance are recognised principles of the European Union and the single market strategy must respect them.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Dalton for this report on non—tariff barriers in the single market. I was grateful to him for the way he set out his arguments in a way – if I may say so – that I found very convincing. I think that we are all clear that deepening the single market is the best way not just to improve the investment climate, the business environment and the productivity of the EU economy, but also to improve service to consumers and to our fellow citizens. As he said about the importance as well of making the single market work for small businesses, as a former small businessman myself, that’s a sentiment that I share entirely.  I think although we have successfully removed tariff barriers to trade across the European Union, it’s right that there are still too many non—tariff barriers in the way of the proper development of the single market, and those are the focus of our work today and of the communication on the single market that we are set to adopt in June. This will set out our approach to making sure that agreed legislation is consistently enforced across the EU, and I agree with the importance of enforcement, as well as a series of more targeted actions to make sure that the single market is working as well as it can. So, for example, we will present an EU—wide action plan to ensure the mutual recognition of goods is respected, we will revise the mutual recognition regulation – and the goal is that more companies should know their rights and make the most of the opportunities that mutual recognition could create for their businesses. We want authorities to be aware of their obligations and to apply mutual recognition properly, and we also want to create a culture of mutual recognition that’s based on trust and legal certainty across Europe. We will be taking action to deepen the single market for services, and here I think that digitalisation offers great new opportunities. The free movement of services is of course enshrined in our Treaties. It is fundamental to the single market, but our analysis shows that providing services across European borders or setting up a branch or a subsidiary in another Member State could be simplified further. The Commission estimates that more ambitious implementation of the Services Directive could add 1.8% to EU GDP. So it’s a price worth having.  We want to make the provision of services easier inside the EU. We are developing the services passport, which is a voluntary electronic procedure to reduce the burden for service providers who want access other Member States’ markets. In my own area of financial services we are working to build a single market for capital in Europe – the capital markets union – and at the heart of that project is the goal of channelling investment to projects that need financing. So, to make it easier for companies to invest, we will bring forward proposals to reduce non—tariff barriers that complicate cross—border investment, like differences in insolvency law for example. I think the way to approach this is to identify the barriers that there are to cross—border sale of services, identify those barriers one by one with Member States and work out ways to address them.  I am looking forward to working with the European Parliament in all these areas to take the single market further and to support competition, to support investment and to support growth in Europe. I hope, like the rapporteur, that this report will give us impetus and some of the evidence as well that will help guide us in our work.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The single market, which is, after all, one of the most important achievements of a united Europe, does not function fully in all its dimensions. While we have managed to eliminate tariff barriers, non-tariff barriers are still a huge problem. However, it should be borne in mind, as the report clearly emphasises, that some of them are used to implement public policies in the Member States and that their removal is not advisable. The problem, however, is any protectionist measures that aim to protect domestic companies from foreign competition. Such measures include the multiplication of formal and bureaucratic requirements for companies from other Member States or the use of excessive unjustified control of economic operators, which effectively discourages traders from exporting their goods or services. Such actions are to the detriment of the European Union as a whole and undermine the competitiveness of the single market.  I agree with the rapporteur that the legal basis for the full functioning of the single market is in principle already being shaped. It is therefore essential that we all – politicians and entrepreneurs – start to see the European market as a coherent whole and see it as an opportunity to exploit the full potential of national economies.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: A brief description of Jakob von Weizsäcker's report is Virtual Currencies (2016/2007(INI)) (A8-0168/2016).

name: Jakob von Weizsäcker
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, this the last item of the day and visibly I am speaking not as a backbencher, but really from the last bench in this house. Furthermore, it’s a technical subject; it’s virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology, so one would be forgiven by thinking well, this is a dull and somniferous subject that perhaps will gently put us into sleep at this late hour of the day, but of course one would be wrong, because this new technology has a lot of promise; it has a lot of potential. Some people even liken it to the kind of revolution that was sparked by the introduction of the internet, and I have to say – although not all my fellow shadow rapporteurs are here – we had a very exciting, very interesting and frankly very enjoyable time exploring this particular subject.  Let me briefly explain to you what this is about. Fundamentally what this is about, this distributed ledger technology that underlies the bitcoin, which is the most prominent virtual currency, is a decentralised database that keeps a record of any sort of transaction done within that database in a way that is surprisingly safe, resilient and trustworthy even – and that’s particularly interesting – when there’s no central authority in play. This technology can be used – as the title of the initiative report would suggest – for virtual currencies and in order to reduce the cost of financial transactions significantly. Some of you may have wondered why it is so much cheaper to send an email or an SMS than to transfer funds, for example from somebody working in one country and sending remittances back home, because in the end this transfer of funds is not much more than an electronic message even today, but still it can be rather expensive – 7% or 8% of the funds transferred. This technology could help us to reduce these transaction costs significantly in the long run, and I think that if we regulate well we might even have open—access electronic wallets where the transfer of funds would be decided by some sort of least—cost routing.  But of course there are also other applications than virtual currencies. You could use this for clearing and settlement, automatic contracts – for example implementing derivatives on the distributed ledger – far beyond the financial sector. You could use it for digital rights management, for music, films or electronic football tickets. If you want to resell these today there might be a danger that you resell them and then the first person who bought them gets into the stadium and the others are kept outside because they bought the same tickets. This is something you could deal with using distributed ledger technology. It could also be an interesting area for government applications – fighting VAT fraud or using it to implement an innovative land register. Of course, with such new technology it is early days; we are not at a stage where the risks that come with any such technology are systemic. So what we advocate in the report is not to stifle innovation by regulating now, but instead to closely monitor what is going on by the creation of a taskforce which we suggest should be created at the level of the Commission, and then to regulate – if and when the time is right to do so and if and when the structures to do so are in place. That of course doesn’t mean that we shouldn’t do anything right now. For example, in the report we greatly welcome the suggestion of the Commission to apply the Anti—Money Laundering Directive immediately for virtual currencies.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I will admit that, in this matter, I have become acquainted with the report precisely because of a certain interest in study. I thank the rapporteur for presenting this report to us, and I must say that what I appreciate about it is that it mentions not only the negatives, but also the positives. Unfortunately, I can't deal with the positives in my minute, so within the negatives. I find it somewhat questionable whether we can allow an element into the financial system that may have the character of a mine that can actually explode because it has the various instruments of the financial system attached to it. Only if I mention two negatives. These virtual currencies can cover black-market transactions and legalise the proceeds of crime. There is a risk of high volatility in these virtual currencies and the potential for speculative bubbles. I think these are the risks that must call for predictable regulation, which will be first, not after.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, virtual currencies occupy an increasing space in our economy. Personally, I have my doubts about the state-of-the-art of technology, the level of security of financial transactions and the increase in cybercrime, about their concurrent or coordinated spread with traditional currency or their widespread use in financial markets. It's not just a payment system, like a credit card, but it uses so-called mining to mint money. Its security is based on extreme encryption protocols and open source software: the cautions of the relationship therefore have a common matrix. The currency and financial markets are not ready for this revolution and the banking markets do not want it: the banks, as this currency makes transactions cheaper; currency markets because of the huge volatility of the stock that can destabilize markets. The big absentees are precisely the institutions, which incomprehensibly do not close the technological gap and do not even bother to regulate its spread immediately, despite the fact that these systems can seriously put world economies in crisis, much more than subprime.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, is our future a virtual currency? Is our future cryptocurrency, digital money, bitcoin, whatever you call it, really a big question? And we all rightly set it up for ourselves.  However , I want to point out that it is interesting that estimates suggest that about two million people today use this digital money. Of these, as many as 25 000 are Croatian citizens. Atms were installed in three Croatian cities, in Zagreb, Split and Rijeka a few days ago. A really very interesting future that has in some way already begun in the cash world.  I want to emphasize two problems. The first problem is exchange rate volatility and the second problem is the problem of saving because no one guarantees eventual savings in this digital, virtual money. All other problems have already been mentioned, new problems will be found, but in any case I want us to deal with this theme in the near future.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Virtual currencies are certainly a very interesting innovation that allows citizens to be less dependent on banks and their often extortionate fees. Nevertheless, we cannot close our eyes to the fact that this opens up space for black market transactions: the legalisation of proceeds of crime, terrorist financing, tax fraud and tax avoidance, and other criminal activities.  I believe that we must call for adequate regulation at EU level, which will not, however, suppress innovation or unnecessarily increase costs at this early stage, but will seriously address the regulatory challenges that could arise in relation to the expansion of the use of virtual currencies. I hope that the Commission, too, will realise that it is on very thin ice and will not use the situation to give greater oversight to citizens who very often just want to break free from the overwhelming subdue of insoat banks.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, digital currencies are the epitome of the free market at work; they know no borders – whether national borders or European Union borders – and yet they work. They are not backed by some sort of gold standard, and they are something which can be mined online. This is something which is perhaps very strange to a lot of us. Their value fluctuates like any physical currency, and this works in a bubble which is unregulated and pretty much unregulatable.  So what does the European Union do? Well it wants to do the same thing that it does with everything that it does not currently control – it wants to interfere and to regulate. To me, that is completely the wrong approach for anyone to be taking on an issue like this.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Virtual currencies represent a promising technology, no doubt, but it still does not guarantee that it can be considered as a currency with all its prerogatives. In this sense, we believe that the report is balanced, it seeks to avoid a false message of total peace of mind to the potential users of this new instrument.  Since the creation of the blockchain concept, many currencies have been created, many have died, many have yet to be born, others have been forced to compulsorily shut down for covering illicit activities. We are still experiencing a period of uncertainty, doubts persist about the limited or even finite nature of the money supply, at least in the current mining format. Doubts persist about his still very volatile character.  We therefore follow the report which points out these shortcomings, but it recognises the need to keep up with this phenomenon which already arouses the appetite of the large economic groups.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I should like to thank Mr von Weizsäcker for this excellent report – and I do not think he needed to fear that he was going to send us to sleep. It is a shame we have not got longer to develop this discussion, but I am sure it is one that we will be able to pursue separately later on, and I am grateful for the work on this technology that underpins virtual currencies, the databases that enable a secure online ledger of transactions to be kept.  I agreed with him wholeheartedly that this is both an important and an exciting area, and I also welcomed the very balanced approach that he advocates that we take, which was not to regulate everything, but to keep an eye on the developments of this, to recognise and embrace the opportunities, but also to be aware that there could be some dangers to which we need to be alert. That is the approach I agree that we need to take.  We have been monitoring this issue for some time as one of the areas of potential risk. We have in recent months accelerated our work in order to investigate some of the concerns raised by the Justice and Home Affairs and Ecofin Councils that virtual currencies could in fact be linked to the financing of illegal or terrorist activities. So I am grateful for the support set out for our plans to bring virtual currency exchange platforms into the scope of the Fourth Anti-Money-Laundering Directive. That proposal is set to be adopted in June; it will ensure that people exchanging virtual currencies for hard currency on exchange platforms can be more easily identified, and it should improve our ability to trace transactions, if the need for that arises.  But, as Mr von Weizsäcker said, while it is crucial that we are attentive to these risks, it is extremely important to remember that the technology that supports virtual currencies has many other uses, and brings with it exciting new opportunities. The distributive ledger technology offers the potential to speed up transactions, to make it simpler and cheaper and safer to gather data and to use it to improve business processes. To give just one example, Blockchain, the technology behind Bitcoin, has recently launched a claims record system for reinsurers, and it will use Blockchain technology to record details of claims, so that insurers and reinsurers can more accurately divide the costs between them.  So we need to keep a careful eye on how the technology is evolving and being in used. In the Commission we plan to set up a FinTech task force to monitor developments in new technologies, including those linked to virtual currencies. We will continue to work with the EBA and ESMA, governments and the European Parliament, and also we need to pursue this internationally, in our work with IOSCO and the FSB. We need to be on top of developments, and if the evidence shows that action is needed, be ready to act, but at the same time, we should not choke off the potential that this technology has.  That is why, for instance, I am very interested in ideas being developed in, for example, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, to develop a regulatory sandbox, in order to create a space for some of these FinTech developments to be properly considered. I think it has potential to support the collation of safer, more up to date and more reliable data, it has potential to increase the financial sector’s competitiveness in Europe, it has the potential to improve customer services, and I look forward to working with Parliament as we monitor and develop our approaches to this important new area.

name: Elnök asszony. –

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – For us 'virtual currencies' are not a new phenomenon, as the existence of 'alternative' means of payment has a long history behind it. Also the bubbles associated with them, even if the technology of cryptocurrencies is relatively novel. In this regard, we are concerned that confusion about the security of their use may be encouraged as a new phenomenon, either by avoiding that their speculative potential or limitations as a means of payment replicate that of any other private financial instrument or by envaluing their potential monetary nature, even though it is an instrument of sovereignty that does not depend on technology , but the endorsement of the State. That is why we believe that they should be regulated— at the very least — as the financial instruments whose functions they replicate, and we would have liked more clarity in this regard. Otherwise, we continue with the fallacy that digital services—in this case financial—are essentially different in nature, rather than ensuring that the regulatory standards conquered in their traditional analogues are maintained.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. – Two aspects are essential in discussions on virtual currencies. First, virtual currencies are a necessity of the present in which we live. Through ease of use, along with our traditional currencies, these virtual currencies are being used by more and more citizens around the world. They offer the advantage of transaction anonymity and a greater degree of security of personal data. The second aspect concerns the legality of these currencies, i.e. the creation of a coherent legislative framework adapted to both the present and the future. Currently, virtual currencies do not meet many legislative criteria, making it impossible to legalize them today. However, even without existing legislation, transactions with virtual currencies are made easy and their use is taking off, which is why we are obliged to prepare a set of possible solutions for debate. The fluid, national nature of this type of currency and the inability of competent institutions to monitor the flow of financial transactions oblige us to constantly re-evaluate both the benefits and disadvantages of these instruments. Taking into account the innovative dimension of virtual currencies, how do we respond to market demand in a regulated manner? More specifically, do we even know what steps we need to take for a smooth, distortion-free regulation of this area?

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. – Digitization in many aspects of our daily life is a reality, proof of this is that more than seven years ago the launch of bitcoin, the first and most important virtual currency. Virtual currencies are destined to have a significant impact on the financial sector, as in many other markets, as it offers a decentralized, fast, resilient and fairly secure means of recording trades of any kind along with the history of previous operations. In 2015, the European institutions taken further steps towards advancing a more digitized payment market, reaching an agreement for the payment package, composed of the Payment Services Directive (PSDII) and the Multilateral Exchange Fees Regulation (MIF). We must continue our efforts to encourage electronic payments and continue to work to create a true digital single market for European consumers.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: –  Madam President, many Europeans believe that corruption seriously harms the economy and society. Another common thing in these reports before us is that they all point to public procurement as the field that is particularly prone to corruption in the EU countries. Hungary, where one can witness cronyism at its finest, is a perfect example to demonstrate this problem.  In this country, even the EU fund that was awarded to government agencies to fight corruption was misused. Let us take one egregious example from Hungary. name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, today's eurogroup decision on Greece imposes a new supplementary memorandum and tough supervision of indefinite duration. It imposes tax evasion of the incomes and real estate of the Greek people, transfer to control of the troika of public revenues, sell off energy potential, take over the management of banks by foreigners and sell off red loans to crows. It imposes primary surpluses from 2018 of 3.5% of GDP, which will go to the annual repayment of debts.  Moreover, instead of returning to Greece the profits of the ECB and the eurozone central banks from Greek bonds amounting to EUR 10 billion, the ECB and the eurozone central banks will be able to repay the profits of €10 billion in greek bonds. Between 2014 and 2020, this eventually goes back into the pockets of the ESM, while EUR 19.5 billion is back in the ESM's pockets. The third loan package will be provided to cover any losses of the lenders of the first loan package due to a reduction in interest rates and an extension.  The Greek people, however, no longer tolerate national humiliation and the loss of national sovereignty. That's why he's going to fight united to throw the troika out of our country and take Greece back.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: –  Madam President, Estonia is the only EU country where remote internet voting is an additional voting channel for all elections. Other European countries do not use it, mostly for security reasons. We can vote in Estonia via the internet during the advance voting period when the election campaign is still under way, and it is possible to change the electronic vote without limitations. At the last European elections i-votes made up 31% of all votes, and there was a considerable difference between the results of electronic and paper voting. Estonian politicians and international experts have raised numerous concerns regarding the i-voting system as such. Experts have presented numerous examples of how it is possible to change votes, compromise the secret ballot or even disrupt elections. E-democracy is becoming a part of our everyday life and therefore we need to revisit the practices of i-voting that provoke deep distrust in Estonian society. Elections should be fair both in practice and in the eyes of the people. Otherwise i-voting will compromise not only e-democracy but also democracy as such.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Peter Praet, member of the Executive Board of the ECB, was recently in Portugal where he was speaking to the media. In these, he expresses doubts about the budgetary policy of the current government, democratically elected last October, and calls in practice for the continuity of the policies followed in the last four years, the failure of which is now clearly confirmed.  But it goes further: in addition to questioning the reduction of working hours to 35 hours, it advocates the need to concentrate the banking system for its internationalization. It even made veiled threats with rising interest rates, as if they were not already completely manipulated by the ECB. These statements are intolerable and show that the ECB has long exceeded its mandate. The ECB is far from being a neutral central bank today in the service of the economy. The ECB is now at the service of large financial groups, promotes neoliberal policies and goes over the sovereign will of national states.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: –  Madam President, I have a message for my London constituents: Do not believe the opinion polls in the EU referendum campaign. I am getting quite a different picture when I am out campaigning. The overwhelming majority of people I speak to tell me they are voting to leave. They represent all sections of society and ethnic groups, but they are generally working people who have simply had enough of the European Union. Last week, I spoke to a young Romanian woman whose been in Britain for just one year. She said she wished she could vote to leave. Her reason was because she could not get  a school place for her young child. What does it mean when recent a EU migrant voices the same complaints as British citizens? Don’t listen to David Cameron’s increasingly ludicrous and scare tactics. I exhort my constituents to vote to set themselves free from the European Union on 23 June.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the memory made today by President Schulz of our dear colleague Marco Pannella is only partly acceptable, it has made him a kind of icon of this European Union; but those who knew him, and we have known and appreciated this Jaurès of the contemporary era, were certainly not an admirer of the hyper-bureaucratic drift of this European Union. He was a man of freedom, who has always defended – and I appreciated him for this – the right of all to political expression, to freedom of expression, and this is the founding value of his political commitment, of a man 'against', who was such, with courage, independence and freedom on these benches too, and for this reason we must remember him, without transforming it, to remember him as he was : a man "against", a man of freedom. Hi Marco.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Madam President, tonight, at almost 11:15 p.m., I would like to talk about the presidential elections in Austria. The highlight of these elections is that the sovereignist candidate of the FP-A won almost 50% of the vote, which is absolutely extraordinary compared to the result he had before. What are the consequences for Schengen? In the short term, of course, there will be none, since the European Union is like an autistic person, it does not want to see anything, it does not want to understand that people are worried and it will continue to try to save Schengen, at the cost, moreover, of an absolutely calamitous agreement with Turkey, which will soon earn us to issue visas to 78 million Turks. In the medium term, however, things will change, because Austria has sent a great message of hope to the people. From 2017, the French people will be able to draw the consequences and, from 2018, the Austrian people will return to the charge in the parliamentary elections. More generally, the people of Europe are worried, they no longer want this European Union and, for them, these Austrian presidential elections are a great sign of hope.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – The great Polish politician Stefan Kisielewski once said, "this is not a crisis, this is the result". Europe is in a permanent crisis, and this is not just the result of the occupation of Europe by a bureaucratic creation called the European Union. It is sad to see how many people are sitting here, wanting the best, and the results are such that the rate of development is slowing down, the number of children is falling. Europe is no longer developing at all. Europe is dying. Where nature does not tolerate vacuum, there are hordes of people who want to settle, where there is a demographic gap. This is all the result of the Action of the European Union, and in fact of people thinking typical of the European Union. I therefore believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – I will not talk about the problem of destroying the European Union, but I will talk about the problem of controlling European projects. Very often, as a member of the CONT Committee, I draw attention to the fact that many European projects are not treated transparently and that corruption and fraud related to European projects are taking place even in the country where I come from. However, the second extreme that I see when driving around the Czech Republic is that three or four more checks will come to one of the projects checked, which are looking for whether there was a mistake in the project. I personally consider this situation unprecedented and I call on the EC to really consider whether every project needs to be checked four or five times.

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I will be talking tonight about the visa policy regulation, which obliges the European Commission to introduce the principle of reciprocity for third countries that refuse to liberalise the visa regime for nationals of Member States of the European Union, in this case the US and Canada for Bulgarian and Romanian citizens. Instead of a delegated act, the Commission was content to say that no progress had been made and considered the matter to be over. At the same time, the European Commission is ready to compromise with countries such as Turkey on visa liberalisation without meeting all the criteria. Europe is ready to take this decision under pressure for the European Union-Turkey agreement to readmission refugees from Greek to Turkish territory to work. By the way, so far there are more ultimatums on Erdogan's part than real results. The legitimate question is posed – is the European Commission able to protect the interest of all citizens of the European Union or is it an electoral responsibility? Is he capable of not exhibiting double standards? We cannot ask for trust from our citizens when we do not comply with our own laws.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – The European Commission continues its action against Poland against my country in a completely open manner, usurping the competences of the European Council. Article 7 makes it very clear that our Parliament, the European Commission or a third of governments can accuse a country of moving away from the rules of the European Union, but only to make a complaint. The judge of this charge is governments, there is an intergovernmental mechanism, it is the European Council. The fact that the European Commission is so denied our freedoms shows how incapable it is of governing. Opens the conflict behind the conflict. The immigration crisis was not enough, the financial crisis in the euro area was not enough, the crisis of British membership was not enough, because that is the nature of the Brexit referendum. Hungary had to be attacked, today it was necessary to attack Poland. The greatest measure of the threat to our freedom is that these people see criticism of their policies and criticism of their power as criticism of the European Union as such.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I take this opportunity to once again highlight the serious problem we have at the Kaštel-Sečovlje border crossing between the Republic of Croatia and the Republic of Slovenia. Namely, this border crossing and the road leading from it to the town of Buje are truly a disgrace to both the Republic of Slovenia and the Republic of Croatia. As istrian prefect, I tried to interest the authorities in Ljubljana and Zagreb in order to finally resolve this problem, but there is no hearing or interest from the authorities in Zagreb and Ljubljana. name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: –  Madam President, how many lobbyists does it take to persuade an MEP? Forty, apparently, because with 30 000 lobbyists in this city, there are 40 for every single Member of this Parliament. The European Commission is currently carrying out a consultation on whether a transparency register should be mandatory. Only in the European institutions would a non-mandatory transparency register be considered anything other than an oxymoron. Seventy per cent of the 30 000 lobbyists represent corporate interests. Nine members of the last Commission are now corporate lobbyists, making sure that the revolving door remains well oiled. Industry representatives outnumber academics, consumer groups, and trade unions by four to one on commission expert groups, and 75% of all EU legislation shows visible progressions owing to corporate pressure. With these facts in mind, can we really be expected to believe that agreements such as TTIP, CETA and TISA are being negotiated in the interests of EU citizens?

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, yesterday the Eurogroup assessing the third Greek Memorandum rewarded, like the representatives of the chapter, the unpopular barbarity of the SYRIZA-ANEL government, continuing the New Democracy and PASOK memorandums. Only the organized struggle of the people to redraft their movement, the popular alliance towards the overthrow of capitalist barbarism can put an end to this descent.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the European funds allocated under cohesion policies are intended to ensure that the standard of living of citizens in the European Union is increased. The procedures established in Brussels for their absorption tend to be increasingly simplified, but Member States sometimes impose barriers that cannot be crossed. In Romania, under Measure 7.2, which encourages an end to the phenomenon of depopulation in rural areas, limits have been imposed which I appreciate inadmissible on the minimum population that an administrative-territorial unit must have, namely two thousand inhabitants. It was ignored, knowingly or out of incompetence, that there are hundreds of town halls in Romania that have less than two thousand inhabitants and cannot benefit from European funds for minimal water and sewerage infrastructure. The European Commission must move to another stage, namely to limit Member States to impose additional conditions which, in most cases, make it impossible for beneficiaries to access these funds.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, European citizens expect european Union rules and standards to protect them. One example is the crisis facing Romania in the field of health, in view of the fact that the third largest producer of disinfectants in the country has diluted the products sold to 300 hospitals in Romania. We are talking about tens of thousands of possible medical problems arising from this situation. It is extremely worrying, all the more so as they could be avoided if we had adequate legislation and serious checks in hospitals. The crisis facing Romania can occur at any time in any other European country, in the absence of firm measures applicable to all medical systems. I therefore call on the European for a to draw up a set of clear rules applicable to all Member States so that such situations are no longer possible in any European health system. I believe that the European Union must have more competences in the field of health in order to be able to properly finance this area and support the development of a quality health system in all Member States, including my country, Romania.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mr Juncker has asked for a further tax adjustment from the future Spanish Government of more than EUR 8 billion and threatens a fine of EUR 2.2 billion, or the equivalent of 0.2% of GDP, after the elections. Mr Rajoy, the Acting President, says in public that there will be no further cuts, but in a private letter to the Commission he says there will be more adjustments after the election. These statements seem to us to be a mockery and a hoax to the people who on 26 June are called to vote in the Spanish State. The peoples who make up the multinational reality of the Spanish State demand that they stop deceiving us, that they do not try to condition our vote by making us believe that there are no alternatives other than neoliberalism and that they respect the decisions we make in the small exercise of democracy that the ballot boxes entail.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – In the European Parliament, we often deal with critical situations in the areas of democracy, security and human rights. We should also see positive changes. These include taiwan's election of a new president and the new government of the Democratic Progressive Party, which is now being replaced by the ruling Kuomintang party. I attended the inauguration with the EP delegation, where the new President, Chhaj Ying-wen, called for the unity of the Taiwanese people and for a joint work on reforms. Taiwan has such a great chance for further democratic and economic growth and is interested in working with the EU and individual Member States, and we should take advantage of this offer. The second good news is that we have received the release of Nadi Savchenko. The EP has repeatedly called for its release, which is why we are very happy to see it here in the EP. Ukraine and Europe need brave people.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again exceptional weather events are devastating the territory of southern Italy, causing enormous damage to production activities. This time it was Puglia's turn to count the consequences of a very violent hailstorm, which hit the metropolitan area of Bari and in particular the municipalities of Casamassima, San Michele, Conversano, Putignano, Turi, Rutignano and Castellana. A 20 cm ice cover covered the crops with particular consequences, especially for the cerasicolo sector. Damage is also being done to olive groves and vineyards and, according to initial estimates, the wave of bad weather seems to have caused damage of around EUR 100 million. Unfortunately, especially in the Mediterranean area, heavy rainfall and other extreme weather events are becoming increasingly frequent. At the present time, consideration is being given to the possibility of seeking recognition of the state of natural disaster and verifying the existence of the conditions for the adoption of the European Solidarity Fund and other measures for which Europe, if called upon, I am sure will not fail to support it.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I would take the liberty of getting the Institutions of the European Union to look at one problem concerning the transport link, the Danube-Odra-Elbe canal. In the Czech Republic, there is already some debate, this problem and this channel affects several countries, the Czech Republic, Austria, Poland, Germany and Slovakia. By looking at the map, we will all accept that such a channel should have a place here, because when looking at the map of the European Union, it is a certain white place that may be calling for interconnection. I personally am a cautious supporter of the construction of this canal. However, I would like to ask the Institutions of the European Union to tell the Czech Republic and, of course, to the other EU Member States concerned whether they, too, are interested in such a project and whether they see the meaningfulness of such a project. I think that this would be quite good for the level of debate on this matter in the Czech Republic.
